Did he not mention that bit? Well, then allow me to tell it. Quite the gripping story.
Olgierd once loved a beautiful maiden named Iris. Yet her parents chose to offer her hand to the crown prince of Ofier. Olgierd grew to hate the poor sot.
At first, he wished to kill him, then decided this would be too simple. So instead, he condemned the prince to a base life in a toad's bloated corpus.
Yet he grew bored of watching him suffer and decided to end it. By your hand.
Remind me, O'Dimm - who is to fulfill my last three requests?
My assistant. Geralt.
Then begone. I don't wish to look at your face any longer than I must.
Come.
Where to?
The stables. My men are preparing to depart.
Not so fast. Haven't agreed to anything yet.
But you'll do it, of that I'm certain. Did you know Olgierd was the one to turn the Ofieri prince into a toad?
Haven't agreed to this yet.
Here for my reward.
Know what this is?
I cannot be certain, but I've my suspicions.
That's a dangerous man you've chosen to deal with, witcher.
Recognize the mark?
Can't help wondering… man whose life I just saved - what was his crime?
He slew the lass's father, the lord of the manor.
Bloke joined our band recently. Quick to draw his blade, eager to fight.
When we arrived, I made it plain - we'd arrived as guests. And as such, we would treat our hosts with honor.
But the hosts would not have us. My company responded with ire, and the man you saved finally killed the master of the house.
The chivalric code knows but one punishment for his crime.
Why'd you condemn that man?
So, you're immortal?
You're… immortal?
Depends on your understanding of the term. Indeed, I cannot be killed.
But it's not at all what folk imagine. Not dying does not mean eternally living your life to the full.
So it's a curse?
A curse? No, wouldn't call it that. I'll put it this way - you must be careful what you wish for lest your wish be granted. For there are consequences.
Not sure I follow.
You know very little can hurt you, so you take wild risks, chase extreme sensations. There comes a point you've done it all, and all seems boring and monotonous.
The trick's to plough through that moment, go further, reach beyond what's known as possible.
Really necessary - that whole show?
Beh, "show"? Come, now.
A man must display some madness from time to time - helps him feel alive.
Daresay you know what I mean - judging by the mark on your face.
Aaargh!
What is this row?
Are you not done with him? My ears wither from the screams!
Ah, Geralt. As you've returned, might I assume you've cleared the sewers?
Or have you not been there?
You killed my father!
Not I.
You lie, whoreson!
That man killed him - alone, unbeknownst to me. Out of fury, for your father refused us hospitality. For this willful violation of the chivalric code, he was summarily executed himself.
Anythin' else I might do for you?
Take her away.
Now where were we?
Wait. I know Olgierd wants him dead. Still don't know why, though.
Just what the fuck is it to you, anyhow?
Nothing, really. Just curious.
Cocksucker violated our chivalric code! Just one penalty for that - death!
No need to be edgy. Let's talk about this.
No, you don't. Let him go.
Oh, this is bloody rich! Can't ploughin' believe me ears! You switch your brains with your cock, or somethin'?
Get your mutant witcher arse out of here!
Or?
Or I'll kill ye!
Go ahead, try.
Whoa, whoa! What the bloody hell's this?!
Geralt. Have you decided to play defender of the downtrodden?
More like gutter of sons of bitches.
Long as I'm here, you'll gut no one.
That a challenge?
Why not. I've not fought a witcher before. Defeat me, and I shall let him go.
Stand aside!
Would you wait, sir, for the dribble to subside?
Makes no difference to me.
Justly said. Stand and fight!
Let him go or face my wrath.
Whoa, nerves a little raw? Why?
You deaf? Get the fuck out of here, freak!
All I want is to know what exactly's going on here.
Well you're not gonna know! Sod off!
I'll leave soon as you tell me.
Calm down, let's talk.
Lemme go! Leave me be!
Shut it!
I ate with youse, drank with youse, fought beside youse! And you'd kill me now? I'm one of youse!
You might've been. But not no more you ain't.
Got a growth on your platter, there. You catch some kind of Ofieri pox?
Could say so.
Manor's burning - you noticed?
That? Oh, right. You know how it is - feast drags on with plenty o' dancin', merry-makin', rough play, hehe. We got a bit carried away, truth be told.
Plain to see. Where's Olgierd?
Damned if I know. Must be somewhere hereabouts.
No, please! I beg you!
Shut your trap!
Well, look who's here! The witcher with a stick up his arse! What's new?
Witcher, sir, you flail your blade like a peasant.
Shame to die in this rain.
A witcher shall soon be buried. The skies weep.
Bloody fight, looks like. Folk in the caravan didn't stand a chance. Tracks lead north.
Someone was wounded. Started bleeding heavily.
Ofieri diagram, another one. Useless if you don't know Ofieri, though.
Interesting. Another diagram with Ofieri markings. Could use someone fluent in the tongue.
Trail's gone cold. Tsk. Need to look around, see if I can't pick it up again.
Lost the trail. Gotta look around for something else.
Hmm. A diagram? Seem to be Ofieri markings on it. Might find someone who could explain them to me.
Ofieri diagram, again. Should look around for someone who knows Ofieri.
Found it! Leads this way.
Hmm. Took a traveler hostage, I guess. Blood trail's the hostage's. Must've been a burden if they left him here to die.
Trail ends here. Hmm. Dirt and ground cover concealing a hatch. Secret passageway?
Who's Kendrick?
Kendrick fellow - who is he?
I-- We's partners. Sneak into derelict 'ouses. Always somethin' valuable lyin' about.
Mhm. So you're a thief.
Thieves steal from the livin'! What's the 'arm takin' from the dead?
Kendrick went to open the door, I stood watch. Suddenly heard his lamp smash… then nothing, quiet. Called out to 'im, but…
Wh-wh… what was that? One o' them foglets you spoke of?
No.
Phew, that's a stone off my--
I'll see what that was and look for your partner. You--
Ain't about to wait around. I'm out of here!
Good question. What are you doing here?
See… Kendrick and me, we thought, manor's been empty all these years, full o' fine things goin' to rot…
Good question - what are you doing here?
Kendrick? Kendrick? You there?!
Not so loud.
Aaah! Gods, scared me half to--
Not so loud, I said. Fog's not natural. Could be something in there, hiding. Foglets or err-nymphs, for example.
Don't want to attract them. Believe me.
F-foglets? Ah, Sweet Mother Melitele, why'd I ever come 'ere…?
Hey! Ye hear me?
Anyone there?
Kendrick? Kendrick!
Talk to the wife.
Fire Swallower
Very well, sir witcher. Show me what you've got.
Go on! Give them hell! Massacre the fuckers, Geralt!
Now that's fun! Just like the old times. When I was alive.
Damned fine show, witcher. A feast for the eyes.
My, my. Ornery whoresons, those von Everecs, eh?
Who are you?
The rogue you seek - Vlodimir von Everec, brother to Olgierd.
Uh! Forgot I cannot even scratch my stones. Though in point of fact, they've not itched much since I died.
Didn't want to fight your family. They started it.
I'm dead, not blind. I preferred to see how you'd handle those snobby pricks. And grandmum, too. Besides, what harm could you do them…? They're dead as it is.
Now tell me how you came into Olgierd's blood. If you hurt him, I fear I shall have to kill you.
Got it from a… mutual acquaintance of mine and Olgierd's. I'm here on important business.
I'm a swiving corpse. With no interest in important matters - yours or any other bugger's. The sole thing I miss is feasting, corporal diversions, so to speak, but alas…
Folk come here often?
Get a lot of visitors?
At times, not often. For when someone does drop by, the whole band comes out to play.
Fun-loving family.
True. We're famed for our love of revelry and rumbles. We von Everecs have brawled and raided for generations. It's tradition.
Naturally, with raids comes loot. So we always had the means to celebrate right lavishly.
Towards the end of my life was when things went sour…
But… no point poking at old wounds. Just days before I died, my brother claimed he'd found a way to dig us out, restore our state.
Your brother sent me.
Your brother sent me.
Mentioned you like to enjoy yourself. Well, just so happens that's why I'm here. Your brother sent me.
How is the old rogue?! Ehh, what I wouldn't give to ride by his side again…
No chance of that happening. Could experience something else, though. Something a corpse should find interesting.
Interesting? Out with it - what do you have in mind?
Tell me about Olgierd.
Listen, feels like I should know Olgierd better. Tell me something about him.
Oh, a fantastic chap, a true cavalier. You won't find another like him in all Redania.
The best there is for a drink or a brawl. We were pups when we started riding out on raids. Wet behind the ears.
Borderland villagers shat their trousers at the very sound of the word "Olgierd." I was his second-in-command, leading a band of rogues who'd ride through fire for us.
Sound like common bandits. Any difference?
Us?! Bandits?! Watch your words. True, some of our swordsmen were mindless brawlers, but not Olgierd.
Always curious, took an interest in all things. He devoured books, adored paintings… and loved the most beautiful maid in the world.
How'd you die?
Don't mean to pry, but… just a little curious how you died.
Bah, no need to be shy. Folk love such stories. I'd love this one, too, were it not to end with my death.
So, how'd it happen?
On raids, it was our custom to storm the ealdorman's hut, then order the local clods to bring us kegs of spirit…
…And provide willing wenches to squeeze and churn about.
Then, sadly, an ambush. Outmanned five-to-one, we were overwhelmed. They killed me. Crushed my skull like an eggshell between an upturned oak table and the stone floor.
Supposed to show you the time of your life.
Listen, Olgierd gave me a job. Odd as it may sound, I need to show you the time of your life.
Is that so?! Now that, sir, is a brother! I've been dead for years, yet he still looks after me, after my spirits!
How much time do we have?
Think one night should do the trick.
Splendid!
Wait just a moment while I hoist my saber and--
What the blistering devils…?!
You're a ghost. Can't grab things.
Argh, I keep forgetting. But how am I to revel and ruck and fuck?! Can't lift a tankard to my lips! Can't wield a saber! Can't squeeze a wench as we dance a jig!
Guess you'll have to do without. Let's go.
I will go nowhere.
You're to see I enjoy myself, correct? Well, then think of a way to make it possible.
How?
Revive my flesh.
No can do. Besides, body's probably decomposed.
Then bloody come up with another way. I'll not go anywhere in this state.
Hm. Guess I could bring someone here… and you… you could… hm… borrow their body. Just for the night.
You wish me to possess someone?
Uh… yeah.
Hm. Say I agree - whose body would I inhabit?
Dunno. One of Olgierd's men, maybe? Or a peasant who'd agree to do it for coin.
Oh, no, no, no. I shan't crawl into the skin of some unwashed bandit or dung-eating swineherd!
I've a better idea.
Guess I could bring you someone to possess.
Stop complaining, let's go.
Come on, we're wasting time.
I'm not to waste time? Sir, time is all I've left.
You this big a pain in the ass when you were alive, too?
Do not anger me, boy. If I've but one night, I want to revel properly, not watch others enjoy themselves.
So what do you propose?
I've an idea.
Oh, no. Not gonna happen.
Oh, yes. Yes it is.
Geralt! Wake up! Open your eyes! Where are the smelling salts…?
Death was a small price to pay to lie on a lap so lovely… and so near the wonders concealed a bit higher.
Have you gone mad?
Yes. As soon as I laid eyes on you. Promise to stay and stroke my chin and I shall spend the rest of eternity in a hound's body, trodding along by your well-turned calves.
Geralt! What's happened to you?!
Geralt? I'm Vlodimir.
What?
Blast! Fine, fine, give me a moment.
Yeah. Definitely don't like being possessed.
You'd not have fainted had you not resisted so fiercely.
Geralt. Care to explain what's going on here?
It's his fault.
A pleasure to meet you, my sweet.
Whose?
His. You know, Olgierd's brother.
It's Olgierd's brother's fault.
Sorry about that, Shani.
Sorry about that, Shani. That wasn't me.
So who was it?
Me.
Shut up.
I didn't say anything.
Sorry, wasn't talking to you.
Who to, then?
Well, to him. To Vlodimir.
Geralt, there's no one else here.
Seems your lovely maiden friend can neither see nor hear me. Hm, there's potential in that.
Leave Shani out of this.
Ah, is that her name? Lovely! A perfect name for a perfect lass!
Leave her out of this.
Let's set some ground rules.
Need to set a few ground rules.
And I needn't do a thing save have the time of my life. Which is exactly what I aim to do.
You're testing my patience.
As you are mine! Can you please explain what's going on here?!
Ooh, fiery. Temperament matches the drapes.
Listen, I'm supposed to show Vlodimir von Everec the time of his life. Turned out he's a ghost.
So… willing or not, I gotta lend him my body.
Wait a minute - are you saying you're possessed?
Not at the moment. Just now he's standing next to me, coyly grinning at you..
But off and on he'll enter my body. So anything I say or do will actually be him, his mind, his intent.
Uh… What if I want to talk to you, not him?
Huh. Well, she should approach me and ask me to jump out for a bit.
Just come up and ask him to leave for a while.
I see.
Splendid.
Right, then, sugarplum, what say you we leave this dank crypt? There's a charming grove nearby where kisses taste sweeter than anywhere else in the world.
I take it you're Vlodimir now. Doesn't seem like I'll have trouble telling you apart from Geralt.
The problem is, he turned me down.
The crook-pated churl.
Uh, don't call him that.
What choice do I have when he is a churl? I'd never say no to as fair a face as yours.
You see, I've a friend who's getting married. She invited me to the wedding, but I need an escort.
I had hoped that when Geralt saw me weaving the garland for the wedding, he'd invite me, but, uh… well, I hoped wrong.
Hmhmhm… all is not lost, pudding. I shall escort you! No better dancer in all Redania than Vlodimir von Everec!
I must say, witcher, a man could lose his head for a lass like that.
And that comes from none other than Vlodimir von Everec - famed for his taste in women.
So tell me, honestly now, man to ghost - are you her paramour?
For if so, you have my word I shall keep my distance. But if not, then… hohoho, the haylofts we shall devastate together…
Only ever been friends.
We're just friends. Always have been.
Never professed your love? No heartfelt admissions, confessions?
Never anything between us.
You mean to say you never gripped those gorgeous-- Whohohuh.
Never cherished those beautiful, nay, stunning-- So, soft in the head or the loins?
Excuse me?
Ahh, a pederast… Fine, if it's not your flavor, you needn't taste. All the better for me. I'll see she's properly satisfied.
So, witcher, time for the wedding?
Let's go.
Onward. I'll be right behind you.
Let's say we were more than friends… once upon a time.
Hah! You tried to hide it, but I smelled a tryst! I know a thing or two about men, you see.
A shame, though, I'd have satisfied her well. But no cavalier would rut in another's garden.
Cared for Shani deeply once.
Wonderful. I must stop by my home first and change, so we'll meet at the temple.
Oooh, I don't like the sound of that.
Why not?
I'm not fond of temples, see. When alive I'd only set foot in one to loot it, and in death I find I despise them all the more.
Could we not meet after the ceremony, go straight to the feast?
Uh, all right. Seems we've no other option.
Splendid! Hahahaha. Then I shall see you at the wedding manor!
No better dancer in all Redania than Vlodimir von Everec! My ginger muffin, with me, you shall enjoy an evening to top all others!
Just before Geralt entered the crypt to summon you, I invited him to my friend's wedding.
Good heavens! That's damned good luck!
I'm afraid I have to turn you down, dear ghost.
A shame. In that case, point me to the nearest brothel!
I've got a better idea.
My sentiments exactly. Between you and me, this witcher fellow is an awful bore…
Hahaha! Only sometimes.
Hah! Seems we're kindred spirits. So, off to the nearest hedgerow?
Geralt's a bore.
Don't change the subject, darling.
Don't change the subject, my sweet. If a grove's not to your liking, we can cut straight to the chase and make for the nearest haystack.
Spooking my horse. Roach doesn't like ghosts.
This whole witcher's life - what's it like?
Don't want to know.
If indeed I didn't, I'd not have asked. Go on, tell me.
You wouldn't like it.
Why do you paw through my ancestor's bones?!
On your way - leave the dead to rest in peace.
See what they're doing? Marking down caravan routes.
Those scribbles mean many a wagon will not make its destination.
You realize how much fisstech they have here?
You could buy half of Temeria.
Are you a witcher or a scavenger?! Hands off the family heirlooms!
Shut up. I do what I want.
A comely maid. You're quite the fool if you've not ploughed her yet.
Keep your paws off her.
I'm to enjoy myself. Can I help it that I best like tumbles in the hay with fleshy lasses?
My, my - bloody impressive treasures.
I remember that mill. Whenever Olgierd and I got up to mischief, we'd hide out in there.
Once we snuck off with some moonshine. Old cocksucker Yaromir caught us, heheh. Ah, those were the days.
I'm in the mood for fun. You've no notion how long it's been since I fondled a perky pair. Let's go to this wedding.
This wedding - we will go there soon, yes?
Bloody fine mount. Good stance, powerful rump, stable withers… Well, well.
See you know your horses.
I should say so! My two greatest passions in life - mares and maidens, heheheh!
I detest spiders. The creepers make my sphincter shut tight.
A small graveyard and a white chapel. I know this place. The ealdorwoman hanged herself from a dried out bough.
Ah, ages past, that was. I was but a lad.
So this is what's become of the Flaming Rose's fallen petals. Heheh.
They're churning out clouds of fisstech. Air's thick with it.
Fat fucking beast.
Careful, or the buggers will eat you. And that would ruin my fun.
Those Signs - I'd like to try one.
What Signs?
Your witcher Signs. Never done it. Could be interesting.
Rather not waste any time.
Till the stroke of midnight what I would rather is what matters.
My nose tells me they hid some treasure here. I've a very trusty sniffer.
Charming spot. Scaled monstrosity's made itself a lovely nest.
There's something there, Geralt. Beyond that wall.
You meander, why? I was to have a good time, not wander about like a knight-errant.
You want to be a witcher, so you need to survey the terrain. Know which way the wind's blowing.
Just don't drag me into any brawls with beasts, mind you. With men - have at it.
Grave robber. Tried to crawl in through the well, broke his neck.
Meaning the scabby runt wished to rob our family crypt.
Hmm. Probably shouldn't touch that.
Wha… what's going on?
Ah, he's finally come to. And he can speak human, turns out.
Started thinkin' I'd not converse in Common the whole way. 'Cept maybe with me reflection in the piss bucket.
Where… where am I?
On the "Albatross." Or the "Phakbarthojl," as their strange tongue has it. En route to Ofier.
Don't remember signing on as a sailor.
Haha, oh, you didn't, mate. They dragged you aboard. Seems you killed their prince.
Shit. Means I'm in trouble.
Oooh… Toad in the sewers. Dammit.
Should consider myself lucky, I guess. Coulda killed me on the spot.
Tried to break out yet?
Beh! Used every ounce of charm I got, and nothin' doin'. Might be my Ofieri's rusty.
My Ofieri's non-existent.
Well, we'll be at sea at least a month. Could teach you some in that time.
Elkhahl! Ohrijahle!
What's that mean?
Told us to shut up.
There's been a misunderstanding. Can I talk to your captain?
Elkhahl, sokhan. Ghalaveth kharh u albahta a'ghell.
Quiet, dog. You killed our prince and you'll pay for that.
Gyhle'am vallarh, quar verrethe ner.
Were it up to me, you'd be dead already.
Revhaghr ner'am ea kharher, Annar. Dhorgatte ye'allami.
Vengeance is not ours to reap, Annar. It's the king's. We swore on our honor.
How do I say "Take me to your captain"?
Vhajlth alle'khe uhl eghullath.
What?
Elkhahl!
V… Vhajlth…
Elkhahl! Inhkal avr ikhell urgherevng aul vihter.
…alle'ghe urh yghilleth!
Vhajlth… alle'ghe urh yghilleth!
Insh'avahl kho llayath.
What just happened? What'd he say?
Said to sit quiet. And that you'll hang in two weeks.
And then he added something like, "We'll see who's in the mood for jokes, then."
Why? What did I say?
Heh. Along the lines of "I want your nose bouncy-bouncy!". Utter nonsense.
…alle'khe uhl eghullath!
Vhajlth… all'khe uhl eghullath!
Great.
Give it a rest. No point talkin' to that lot. All you get's angry gurgles. And they puff up, you notice? Like them fish, uh, what's it they're called…?
There anyone here who speaks Common?
Uh, there's this mercenary with them. Looks Aedirnian to me. He's the one recruited me to show 'em through the sewers.
Oh, and the mage what leads them knows a bit. Heard him talkin'. But I doubt either'll talk to you.
Ah, I was you I'd catch some shut-eye, not go on flappin' me tongue. Got a long voyage ahead.
Sleep's not what I need. Someone I could actually communicate with, that's what I want.
Greetings, Geralt. Remember me?
No.
Not really.
Gaunter O'Dimm, known also as Master Mirror. We met in White Orchard - I helped you find your… Yennefer.
We meet again. And it seems you need my help. Again. Heard a noose awaits you.
That is… if this slop doesn't kill you first.
What are you doing here?
How'd you get in here?
Long story, it'd bore you. I'd prefer to focus on something more useful - like getting you off this ship.
Who you gabbin' with?
Wi-- No one.
Ah, never liked boats. Not one bit.
They heave like devils, make me stomach churn.
Ah, it'd be prime to sleep through the whole thing and wa--
Because you do wish to disembark, do you not?
Yeah, sure. But what on earth could you--?
Oh, more than you'd ever expect. I shall help you, Geralt. But before I do, I must know you'll return the favor.
Right. Can't possibly get something for nothing.
Indeed. When all's said and done I am a merchant. So, do you want my help?
Yes.
It's a deal. Once it's all over, we shall meet at midnight at the crossroads 'neath the willows near the village of Yantra.
Ah, and I must give you something - to remember me by.
Ssss! What's that?
A mark to show we're… associates.
Haven't tried it yet.
Hm. Doesn't look promising. Not unlike your situation. I could try to extract you from here, you know.
Haven't tried it yet.
I remember. We met in White Orchard. You're…
Gaunter O'Dimm, known also as Master Mirror. I helped you find your… Yennefer.
Yes.
That you wanted his auntie's hat. That was the gist, anyroad.
Vhajlth… alle'khe yhll eghallith!
…alle'khe yhll eghallith!
There any way out of here?
And who might you be?
Phelippe Calagrande at your service. Petty thief, professional fence, and your guide about Oxenfurt when I've a bit of time.
Mhm. And why're you here? You kill a prince, too?
Well, to their thinkin', I had a hand in this one's death. See, I was their guide. Led them down into the sewers, but not until after you'd cut their prince's gut open.
Sorry about that.
Not your fault, mate. When all's said and done, could've sat on me arse in the Alchemy playin' gwent. Didn't have to brag about knowin' Oxenfurt better than me own breeches.
Who are you?
Listen, there was a young woman, a medic. Red hair. They capture her too?
Don't recall seeing anyone of the sort. You were alone.
Good. Means she managed to flee. Hopefully made it home.
What about Shani? She here?
We been sailing long? Where are we?
We been at sea long?
Hmm, dunno, rightly. Not that long. Though, on the other hand… But what's it matter, anyroad?
Matters a lot. If they're hauling me off to hang me, I'm not in a hurry to arrive.
Me, I'm glad to be sailin' to Ofier. I hear they got wild horses there, white with black stripes. Always wanted to see one o' them.
Sure they're not black horses with white stripes?
Nay, black horses with white stripes they've got in Zanguebar. That I'm sure of.
Depends how you look at it.
Happen to know a bit of Ofieri. Heard them sayin' they'd come here on a mission. Dispatched by their king to find their prince, lift his curse.
Wagered their honor - and that of their families five generations back - that they'd bring him home, safe and sound.
And I killed him. Great.
So, must think they can save their honor by bringing the prince's murderer back - to face the king's justice.
Dammit. Don't remember a thing. Just some sewers, a giant toad, then some boots…
If that toad was their prince, guess I'm lucky to be alive.
Don't remember a thing.
Ah, my kind of tune! Let's do some dancing!
In my experience, witchers and dancing don't exactly mix.
Today they mix like fire and oil, my love! We'll dance the barn down!
Faster! Faster! Till we expire!
And now, a special treat for our special guests - the witcher Geralt and his enchanting partner, Shani. Musicians, something lovely for the loving couple…
At last, music for a loving embrace!
Come, Shani. It's time you discovered my romantic side.
Huh. You're rather good at this.
A chair could dance a jig with you as its partner!
Oh, how humble you are.
I strive to be. Yet should the need arise, I can strut as proud as any peacock.
Oh, the perfect combination. Women must love you.
Well, not to brag, but…
Call it idle curiosity, but… how many have you had?
Many. And not a scrub hag among them, I should add. Women with true class, all - though none to match your charms.
You're quite skilled yourself.
Not a man here who could out-dance me. It's a gift, my legs are preternaturally skilled.
I never expected the members of Olgierd's band to have a taste for dancing.
Yet it's so! We'd dance and dance - at every opportunity. As fond of fun as fighting - our motto!
I am the lord of the dance.
My dancing skills are a mere foretaste.
They say dance is a mere foretaste of… hmm… more intimate interaction.
Who says this?
I do, for one.
I do wonder what you mean by "intimate interaction."
Ohhh, it's a fascinating process. One you, as a scholar and medic, might find especially interesting.
I'd gladly explain it in detail, but it's horribly loud in here…
Hmm… see the ladder? Leads to a loft. Surely there we'd not be disturbed while investigating the nature of intimate interaction.
I couldn't resist.
Don't be upset, my peach. I couldn't resist.
I'm not upset. Just, next time don't lunge at me like that.
I'd had a long fast, so to speak. Hunger overwhelmed me. But yes, next time I shall ask.
Shani, may I kiss you?
Hahahaha! You're incorrigible.
Was it good for you?
Yes, yes… but admit it - it was fantastic, eh?
Is there anything you do that's not fantastic?
The ladies loved my kisses. Not to mention the other tricks I perform with my lips.
Yes, we'd best not mention those.
I'd probably have done exactly what he did.
Probably I'd a done what he did. Still like to…
Then why don't you? Well? Answer me!
Thing is, normal folk don't act like Vlodimir von Everec.
Because they are churls.
Don't be too hard on him. All in all, he's actually rather fun.
Hah! See that? I'm fun! And you've got a pike so far up your arse, you can't wear hats!
Wouldn't force myself on you.
Well, I probably wouldn't 'ave forced myself on you.
Forced myself?! It was an innocent kiss, naught more!
I don't know if I should thank you or if that should make me… angry.
Don't get me wrong - I've thought about doing just that a few times, but…
But what?
But I'm not going to talk about it with him here. We can discuss it once he's gone.
I'll hold you to that.
Perhaps a bit of thanks is in order? Seems I've snared the little robin for you.
You can shut up now.

Whoa! Hold there, mate! You said you weren't interested back in the crypt. Now, suddenly, after I've beat the cream all night, you swoop in to dip your berry? And aim to delight in it without me present?
Shut up.
What's going on now?
Nothing. Never mind.
Beh, I was to make merry, carouse, yet here I've stood the last five minutes listening to you talk. I'm going back in.
Ah, better! Come, Shani. The night beckons us not to jabber it away.
Happen to see the man who announced our-- your song?
Yes, he acted as though he knew me, but we've never met. I was surprised. Who is he?
Gaunter O'Dimm. Master Mirror. Wonder what he's doing here…?
Then perhaps you should just ask him.
Yeah. He didn't show up without a reason. Need to talk to him.
Considered that he might have simply been nearby and dropped in on a whim?
Promise you this much - he never does anything simply. And certainly not on a whim.
Can't say what would've happened. Probably wouldn't have danced at all.
Oh, really?
Shut up, shut up! You'll ruin everything!
At any rate, I wash my hands of all my actions till the stroke of midnight.
I see.
Wouldn't do it. Not my thing.
Could I talk to Geralt for a moment?
What for? He'll have nothing of interest to say. The man's a drip.
Please?
Very well.
See how I've reeled her in? Now don't fuck this up.
Geralt, I'm curious what it's like when that ghost's inside you. Do you feel anything? Have any control?
I feel everything. Don't have any control over what I do or say, though. Why do you ask?
Because I wonder what it would've been like to dance with you. Just you.
What do you mean, hands to myself? That'd be no fun at all. Besides, I thought you too would enjoy it.
Oh, I like to kiss… and get kissed. But mostly with one person at a time - and there's two of you in there.
Aye, yet only one did what set your heart aflame. Me.
Aaaaa…
If I'm to play, I will play.
Seems the music and the evening draw to a close. Know how a true dancer thanks his lovely partner?
I'm… not sure I do.
What're you doing? Have you lost your mind?
I have! My mind, my heart - for you.
We must agree - you can say whatever you please, but you shall keep your hands to yourself. Understood?
Look there, Shani. The ladder begs us to scamper to its top, where we can… converse.
Then let us scamper.
But… how so? Just like that?
There aren't that many ways to scale a ladder.
The night is young. Come, let's do something wild!
But… what's just as you thought? I find you intimidating!
Loudly lowing cows only ever give a little milk.
I've only ever dealt with simple maids. Whereas you're a surgeon!
I believe I was right not to just take you and, well-- I was right to take the more romantic approach.
Oh, all right. Now come. We were to enjoy ourselves. Let's do just that. Romantically…
Let's sit. Come now.
Just… like that?
I'm all ears. What would have us talk about? I'm sorry - converse about.
Well… when it comes right down to it…
Yes…?
You see… the thing is…
Come now, spit it out.
Akhem. I…
Yes, just as I thought. Come, it's time we returned.
Bodyguard
Having completed all of Olgierd von Everec's wishes, Geralt went to the Alchemy Inn, where he was to meet with the ataman's representative...

With Shani's help, Geralt managed to enter the Academy grounds and speak to a Professor Shakeslock, who had earlier helped Olgierd in his attempts to break the pact with Master Mirror. The professor revealed that O'Dimm could be cheated – one needed only propose a wager, and, as an inveterate gambler, he was ligely to agree to take one up on it.

Geralt took Professor Shakeslock's advice and proposed a wager to Master Mirror. Mirror agreed, but only if it was played out on his terms. He transported Geralt to a strange, dark world and made him solve a riddle. Geralt, who has always had a keen mind for such puzzles, soon found the solution and defeated Gaunter O'Dimm. Was this the last our world will ever see of him? No man can say...

What mattered most at the moment, however, was that Olgierd von Everec was safe, and the pact which had bound him had been dissolved.
Geralt decided not to dispute the arrangement between Gaunter O'Dimm and Olgierd. The pact was fulfilled, and Olgierd's life came to an end.

To Geralt's surprise, he found Master Mirror waiting for him there. So that they might chat undisturbed, Mirror raised a hand and... stopped time. If prior to this Geralt had had any doubts O'Dimm was a demonic creature, this act – and the dark talk that followed – surely erased them.

Mirror made it clear Geralt had no choice but to see their bargain through to the end. Whether as an implied threat or just for some twisted fun, O'Dimm then killed a nearby man... with a spoon.

Geralt knew he had to do as Mirror asked. First, however, he decided he should visit Shani, who, according to Olgierd's messenger, wanted to meet with him.
Meet Olgierd's man at the Alchemy Inn.
Meet Olgierd at the Temple of Lilvani.
Find the solution to Master Mirror's riddle.
(Optional) Talk to Shani at her home.
(Optional) Follow Shani to the Academy.
(Optional) Enter the Academy grounds.
(Optional) Enter Professor Shakeslock's house.
Whatsoever a Man Soweth…
I'm not a hired assassin.
I'm a witcher. Not a man hunter.
Kill an awful lot of them, though, don't you?
When they deserve it.
And my friend's murderer - he don't deserve it? At least hear me out!
Need to think it through.
Kluivert's got a scar on his forehead not unlike yours. Spot that, you'll know it's his body.
Said I'd think about it.
Know what, Puss Peeps? One look at a bloke and I know what he's made of. You'll do what I ask. I'd bet anythin' on it.
Look for me in Oxenfurt! The Alchemy Inn on the main square!
Find the bastard who did this. Find him and kill him. I'll pay top coin.
Kluivert dealt fisstech. A few days past he rode to Bowdon - to take a delivery. Never came back.
Been there? Actually seen his corpse?
No, but Kluivert was one damned reliable whoreson. We was to meet, he didn't show. Can only mean he's dead.
Keep talking.
Keep talking.
Seem able enough. Why not take care of this yourself?
Why not avenge him yourself? Seems like you all relish swinging your sabers.
Aye, we do. And if I knew who'd axed Kluivert, I'd 'ave gutted him ages ago. Thing is, I don't.
But you see a lot with them puss peepers. You'll track him down.
Hey you! Puss Peepers!
Name's Geralt.
But I'm gonna call you Puss Peepers. That a problem?
Get to the point.
Got an offer. Potentially lucrative, Puss Peepers. Someone's killed my mate. Name was Kluivert. You're to figure out who did it. Then cut the bugger's head off.
Here to collect my coin.
Came to collect my coin, not tell tales.
Agh… So handsome and so borin'. Here, Puss Peeps - your gold. Ought to be enough for an ounce of panache.
Bastards. Brethren of the Order of the Flaming Rose.
What'd you do to 'em? Scald 'em with hot irons? Pick out their eyes? Skin 'em alive?
No. Just killed them.
Order of the Flaming Rose.
Avenged your friend.
Hahahaha! I knew you'd succeed, Puss Peepers! I knew it!
Go on, out with it - who was the bastard?
You're a right good chap, Puss Peepers.
Oh, prefer not to be badgered just now.
Raven
Boy
Horst Borsodi
Hans! Hans! Hans!
That's right! Now the other side! The other side!
Geralt! Watch out!
Oh! That must've 'urt.
Drop the damn drifter, oi?!
Come on, Geralt!
Hang tough, Hans!
Come on, Hans! Go for the kidneys!
Ofieri Soldier
Huh. Air seeping through the cracks. Passage must be here. Now how do I open it?
Nick of time. Now to get out of here.
Sewers? Should've known.
Hmm. Some spilled wine. Nothing else.
Beautiful. But first blow would shatter them.
Hm, this one probably also belonged to a sorceress… Fetish, maybe?
From the collection of the mage Aeramas…
Codex Redaniensis… Sole surviving copy.
Hm. A giant's. Or maybe a jotun's.
Lovely sculpture. Probably end up adorning somebody's garden.
Zerrikanian spears. "Excellent adornments for any parlor wall." Heheh. Good to know.
Letters must be old… String seems to say so, too.
It was true love…
Goblet of Fire. Wonder what it is…
Same paintings were on the block…
Including this fine piece by van der Knoob, the master from Maribor.
Guess this is where they store whatever doesn't sell.
No buyers, I guess. Not really surprised.
Redanians'll be here soon. Dammit, secret passage - where is it?
Wolf
Actually, I'm really just here to talk to Horst Borsodi.
Oo. Might be more of a problem than ye'd expect.
Because?
An awful hermit, that one. Not a wee bit like his da, Melitele keep his soul…
Buuut, Horst is like tae show his heid durin' the auction. I'll introduce ye then.
Be mighty indebted to you.
Think nothin' of it! I only ever collect on loans and promissory notes. All right, up we go!
I really just wanna talk to Horst Borsodi.
What'd folk come to bid on? Any idea?
All kinds o' valuables, rare weaponry, exotica… But I've got my eye on a selection of canvasses by the master portraitists of the Maribor School - van der Knoob and Longendijk.
Well, well. Never knew you to be a connoisseur.
Cause I'm not! It's all muck and rubbage tae me. Point of fact, I'll just wrap 'em in paper and lock 'em in the vault.
Why in the world do--?
What do ye mean, why, Geralt? I've got to diversify my investments, dinnae I?!
Any idea what might be up for bid?
Hm, didn't the Borsodis have their auction house in Novigrad?
Could've sworn the Borsodis' auction house was in Novigrad.
It was, but they moved it. Ye see, Radovid offered Horst a preferential tax rate - zero percent.
Hm. Pretty much unbeatable.
Aye. And I've nae seen a purer example of the benevolent state!
Appreciate the help.
Twas nowt. I've always had a mind to seein' to old pals and clients!
Business with you's a pure pleasure, Vimme.
The dear departed wifie claimed the same.
Ahah! Folk're assemblin' - auction's about to start. Time we went upstairs.
All me exes burnt me breakfast!
And breakfast's the meal I love the most!
Hee-haw, hee-haw!
The lock! Lovingly crafted! Two spring-loaded bolts, cylindrical plugs, dimeritium wards…
I'm not interested. No one's interested. We go in. Geralt, you're at the fore.
Why me?
It's why I hired you! Now move! We've no time!
A mighty fine "whoop" that was! A wee bit loud, aye, on account I had to add more fulminatin' silver than usual, but--
Mhmm. Do or die…
That's it. For now.
Shit! As if I haven't seen enough excitement.
A witcher shall soon be buried. The skies weep.
You under the delusion you'll complete your tasks, live happily ever after?
As lifeless and boring as a boulder at the roadside.
Death holds no surprises.
Goodbye, Geralt.
Fail, and you'll not be back.
That's a dangerous man you've chosen to deal with, witcher.
While traveling near Novigrad, Geralt happened across the body of an unfortunate wretch who had stumbled into a cave full of arachnomorphs. In his pockets was a yellowed letter.
The letter told the truth – Geralt found the hidden treasure and kept a one hundred percent finder's fee for himself.

The letter was from a thief informing his partner about where he had hidden their takings. To their great misfortune, the damp cave he had chosen was also home to monstrous spiders, who'd made the treasure's hiding spot the very heart of their lair…
Search the cave for a chest using your Witcher Senses.
Read the letter.
The Drakenborg Redemption
Nobleman

Oxenfurt, once a city of students, had been transformed by war into a city of soldiers. Redanian troops were everywhere – in every inn, shop and brothel, but, most visibly and annoyingly of all, on every street. Geralt had to find a way to reduce the number of patrols if the robbery was to stand a chance of success. He dug into his bag of witcher tricks and found just the thing – an alchemical mixture which, added to the soldiers' rations, would soon have half the Oxenfurt garrison out on sick leave...
The garrison cook turned out to be amenable to cooperation. He agreed to add the witcher's special sauce to his pot, making Geralt's task much easier.
Use your Witcher Senses to eavesdrop on Redanian soldiers patrolling Oxenfurt to find out where to find their cook.
Visit the garrison cook during the day and convince him to help you.
Prepare a cleansing mixture that will weaken the Redanian soldiers.
Open Sesame: Witcher Seasonings
Ofieri Mage

Vaults are, as a rule, difficult to enter. Their metal-plated doors must either be teased open in silence by a skilled safecracker – or blown to smithereens by a demolitions expert. The unequalled master of the first method was Quinto, the best safecracker north of the Yaruga. The go-to specialist for the second was Casimir Bassi, a dwarf hailing from Mahakam.

Geralt chose to recruit Casimir to join his crew. Expecting to have to persuade the dwarf to abandon his idyllic family life, Geralt found himself instead convincing the dwarf to cling to any life at all. Abandoned by his wife, Casimir was set on exploding himself and his wrecked home in a spectacularly effective suicide – until he heard the witcher's offer.

Geralt decided on Quinto. Hans of Cidaris was holding the man captive, so Geralt first had to free him… though once he did, he had the impression the famed safecracker could have waltzed out of his prison at any time without his help. The ease with which Quinto opened his cell's lock boded well for his chances of cracking open the door to the Borsodis' vault.
Convince Casimir to take part in the robbery.
Defeat Casimir.
Go to the mercenaries' camp and talk to Quinto.
Convince Hans to free Quinto.
Defeat Hans in a fistfight.
Meet with Quinto at the Academy gate at midnight to recruit him.
Open Sesame: The Safecracker
Dog
Yes, well, as I said, you're free to take what you please.
Think I'll give this ruby necklace a new home…
You fail to understand. Scrolls, documents, the will in there - none of this can land in strange hands. Not for any price.
Gents, might I appeal to your sense of reason?
You! Stand with me. Security consultant, the position's yours. With a salary in the thousands.
Lucrative offer. I like lucrative offers.
Two betryals in a row. Not an ounce of honor.
What can I say? I am a thief.
Kill the witcher!
Be happy to help you join your brother.
Nothing simpler.
Whereas you I like. Wait with me a while. We must talk. I seek someone excpetionally well versed in locks and traps and whatnot.
Why, work of that sort would be a right honor, guv'nor.
This way. Get out, witcher. And don't come back.
Admire your courage, I do, but we need to figure something out.
How? I was clear - I'll not hand you the House!
No. Said you won't hand me its contents. I don't need those papers. Casket'll do me just fine.
I see. The wolf leaves sated, yet the sheep lives on.
This wolf's pretty damn tired. So lemme have the damn casket and lead us out of here.
With immense pleasure. Believe me.
Maybe we can make a deal.
Yes, witcher. I'd sooner die than let you have those papers.
Any? You sure?
You fail to understand. Scrolls, documents, the will in there - none of this can land in Olgierd's hands. Not for any price.
And as I said…
Of course. The witcher.
I want Max Borsodi's House. Whatever it is.
As I said - take whatever you please.
At last. How I despise unfinished business.
Whaddaya say we talk about my reward?
{Khotarat teh sahleb razzif!} [A desert gale rend your flesh!]
{Shema harh teh avtah!} [The sun bleach your bones!]
{Merte, mykhun!} [Die, fool!]
Arachas
Private Kleiner. I remind you - a soldier's to stand erect, chest protrudin' with pride.
I'd be prouder to stick somethin' else out.
Yet more impertinences?! Mark my words, I'll put it in my report!
Blood… dried. A few days old.
Bear
Lovely beasts. Black stallion'd be perfect for me.
Perfect? Why's that?
Got me some new boots. Made to order, black as night, softest leather, fuckin' elegant…
Pick your horses to match your boots?
Course. Don't you?
I'm stuffed to the rafters. Fear I'll slide off me saddle.
Any truth to it? They starvin' in Velen?
Wine, wine, I want wine, dammit!
Eh, comrade?
Bit road-weary, are we?
Hey!
Stop that.
Ataman, sir. You've a guest.
Do you know what types of sculptures fetch the best prices?
Statues of deities, busts of kings… and nudes. And what have we here? A naked wench.
What do you think of her?
I prefer Gernst's works myself.
Frankly, gotta say I prefer the work of Pax Gernst.
Ah, the Koviri School. Are you an Oxenfurt man?
No. Know some folk who graduated from there, though.
Rather talk about the notice.
Too sober for that sort of conversation. Rather talk about the contract.
Ah, a man of action - plain to see.
Gotta admit I like it.
I happen to like it. Especially the two ovoid forms.
A jester. Good. I don't like men with no sense of humor. They bore me to death.
Consider the beast gone.
Confident. Bring me its head, and the reward shall be yours!
I'll take the job.
Admittedly curious about the monster. But got no time to go after it now.
As you will. I shan't force you. Contract will find a taker in time - if not you, then another.
But you change your mind, you come find me.
Sorry. Not interested.
Let's talk about the reward.
Just one formality to resolve first - my pay.
Never you mind that. Return with the beast's head and you'll have leave to take anything you wish from here.
Awfully generous. Still, I'd prefer to agree a specific amount.
Ooh, fine. How much would you like? Three, four hundred crowns?
Four hundred and fifty.
Agreed. And that'll be in addition to whatever memento you wish to take.
Look who's come back! Come in, sit yourself down!
Come to feast with us, or had a change of heart about the beast?
Monster in the sewers - know anything more?
I've no clue what it is. Only that it's deadly.
I'd not have bothered had my cook not become its victim. Ooh, the way she prepared game… Had no equal.
That why she was in the sewers? To fetch game?

Nay, she went to a fair with a sister or cousin - matters not. Daft wench convinced her a prince transformed into a toad lives in the Oxenfurt sewers. And you know women - each craves a prince and will wade knee-deep through shite to get him.
Vissy was no exception in that respect. Down she went, never to return. Wasn't the first, it seems, either.
Hey! Leave her be!
Is that any way to treat the lord of the manor's daughter?
Apologies. Now where were we? Oh yes, the contract. So, you'll take it?
The contract - let's talk.
Celebrating anything special?
This some special occasion, or just feel like feasting?
Every occasion's special. Today, we celebrate a dubbing.
Whose?
Squire Herodore's new saber.
I've hit on a name for her! Fair saber, I dub thee - Traditiana!
Hahahahaha!
Agh… I used to like Votticelli. The life he could breathe into a chunk of cold stone…
But I look at it now, and it seems just a rock, ideally proportioned, not a flaw on its surface, painfully perfect.
As lifeless and boring as a boulder at the roadside.
Heheheh.
That's better! More interesting, at the least.
Very well, and now, to the matter at hand.
Let's rejoin the company, partake of some refreshment first.
Ataman Olgierd! Long may he live!
Long live the ataman!
Long live the ataman! Long live the ataman!
Come and drink with us!
Well, we haven't a choice, now.
Fetch us some wine, dear. And a nibble or two!
Sculpture isn't really my thing.
Can't blame you. Contemporary art's become… superficial. And bland.
A century on they'll be using just such nudes on placards to hawk bricks and other banalities. Mark my words.
Sculpture's not my field of expertise.
Got a bit more coin for you. Better be all you need.
For tools it is enough, but ingredients rare also I req--
Nope. Not gonna happen. Now lemme see what my coin's bought.
Got the coin for master-level tools.
Hard at work. Good to see.
Ah, yes! Commissioned have I tools, a fitting set. From Novigrad crafters. Many arms and legs they charged, but renew my work in earnest I now can.
New runes, glyphs and diagrams created I have. An eye you should cast, find one to your liking perchance.
So, nothing holding you back now?
From making master-crafted runes, you mean? Err, much more coin I will need to do so. Sadly.
I might. First, got some painite for you.
Drowned Dead

The White Wolf, "the Butcher of Blaviken" – Geralt gathered many sobriquets on his Path, one of which was the colorful and, I dare say, apt, appellation of "Puss Peepers." This he gained during his adventure with Olgierd, when a cheeky young woman in Olgierd's company pinned him as the man best able to track down the scoundrel who killed her friend, Kluivert.
Kluivert had indeed been killed. Though much time had passed since the murder, the witcher hoped he could still find enough evidence to establish who was responsible.

It turned out Kluivert's death was not the work of common bandits or deserters, but knights of the recently dissolved Order of the Flaming Rose. Geralt realized the brethren who had killed Kluivert were but part of a much larger contingent. To prevent any further such murders and fully avenge Kluivert, he would have to find the knights' leader.

The orders Geralt found on the knights he defeated not only shed light on their activities – they'd given up defending the defenseless and switched to brewing narcotics – but revealed the location of their hideout. Geralt decided to take a short break from monster hunting to pay their Grand Master a courtesy call.

The witcher and the Grand Master did not take a liking to each other. After a short talk about the Order's past and mission, they moved on to armed combat. This fight could clearly have only one outcome – Ulrich met the same fate as his infamous predecessor, Jacques de Aldersberg.
With this Geralt of Rivia, alias "Puss Peepers," avenged Kluivert and completed the task allotted him. He collected his promised reward and set off on his Path.

While crossing the war weary lands of the Northern Realms, Geralt came across an abandoned village, and lying within it – a corpse. Geralt knew his sharpened witcher senses would help him uncover who had committed this murder – then his sharpened witcher swords would help him punish the wrongdoers.

It turned out the murder had not been the work of common bandits or deserters, but knights of the recently dissolved Order of the Flaming Rose. Geralt realized the brethren who had murdered the man were but part of a much larger contingent. To prevent any further such crimes, he would have to find the knights' leader.

The orders Geralt found on the knights he defeated not only shed light on their activities – they'd given up defending the defenseless and switched to brewing narcotics – but revealed the location of their hideout. Geralt decided to take a short break from monster hunting to pay their Grand Master a courtesy call.

The witcher and the Grand Master did not take a liking to each other. After a short talk about the Order's past and mission, they moved on to armed combat. This fight could clearly have only one outcome – Ulrich met the same fate as his infamous predecessor, Jacques de Aldersberg.

They say the world is small, and there's much truth to that saying, as Geralt found out when asked to find out who stood behind the death of Kluivert. The witcher could reply at once that it had been knights from the Order of the Flaming Rose, acting on orders from their commander, whose head he had recently lobbed off. Having completed his task before even being issued it, he collected his reward and returned to the Path.
Investigate Bowdon for clues about Kluivert's murder using your Witcher Senses.
Explore the knights' camp.
Investigate the fallen knights' lab northwest of Brunwich.
Defeat the fallen knights.
Go to the woman who hired you to collect your reward.
Find the source of the strong odor using your Witcher Senses.
Investigate around the hut for clues about the man who fled out the window.
Follow the shooter's tracks using your Witcher Senses.
Look around for signs of the man who shot the bolt using your Witcher Senses.
Read the document you found in the fallen knights' camp.
Search the hut using your Witcher Senses.
Defeat the knights.
Defeat the guards.
Follow the horses' tracks.
Rose on a Red Field
Mhm?
Yes?
Hey!
Watch out, Geralt!
Lovely!
Oh, yes!
Runewright
A good lay-down's nice at times.
Aye, just love watchin' birdies flutter about my head.
That I don't like.
You're an odd one.
Dozed off once, and one dropped a shit straight in me gob.
We'd best keep an eye open, then.
Aye. We'd best.

To this day, I do not know what caused Geralt to inquire after the contract posted by Olgierd von Everec. That famed witcher curiosity? An ominously light coin pouch? Or perhaps it was some other, more nefarious force… Whatever the impulse, Geralt decided to visit the locally-infamous nobleman and pursue the bounty on the sewer monster.

From their very first encounter, Geralt knew Olgierd was a unique character. He led an informal band who worshipped the ground he walked on, though he clearly was of a different sort than they: educated, a lover of art and an adherent to a certain noble code. Yet Geralt also perceived something indefinable within the man, something years later he would call "a void crying out to be filled."

Geralt later returned to the estate where he had first met Olgierd and his band – and found the place in flames. He soon learned the property did not in fact belong to Olgierd, but had merely been commandeered by the ataman and his men, who then went a touch overboard in their carousing. Olgierd did not begrudge them their pyrotechnic overexuberance, but the murder of the manor’s lord he considered one cruelty too far and ordered the wrongdoer beheaded. Geralt entered the stage in the middle of this execution. In the tumult that followed, he made a most startling discovery: Olgierd von Everec was immortal.

And immortality was but the start of the surprising revelations about Olgierd. Master Mirror revealed the two had signed a contract: in exchange for regaining his lost status and wealth, Olgierd had promised Mirror something very personal (what, exactly, Geralt did not yet know). This contract had a strange clause: before it could be considered complete and Master Mirror could collect his due, he had to fulfill three of Olgierd’s wishes. He could not do this personally, however, but needed instead to make use of a proxy. His choice for this role? Geralt, who in this way was drawn into a personal settlement between a powerful, immortal nobleman and the mysterious Gaunter O’Dimm.

Upon hearing Geralt would be the one to carry out his requests, Olgierd wasted no time and issued him his first challenges: to bring him the house of Maximilian Borsodi, and to show his brother Vlodimir the time of his life…

Granting Olgierd’s wishes had proven difficult but rewarding, for Geralt now knew a great deal more about the unusual nobleman – and the story that unfolded could have jerked tears from a cyclops.

Once upon a time, Olgierd fell hopelessly in love with Iris, a beautiful young lady from a well-off family. Her parents accepted his proposal of marriage and all seemed set for a happy ending when a storm of misfortune suddenly broke over the von Everec family. A chain of bad decisions and a few years of bad harvests had left the once-wealthy family deeply in debt. Then the Borsodis purchased this debt and, with their brutal enforcement of its terms, drove the von Everecs into utter bankruptcy. After this, Iris’ parents changed their mind about their daughter’s future husband, revoking their approval of Olgierd and betrothing Iris to an Ofieri prince who had come to study in Oxenfurt. Out of desperation, Olgierd turned to Master Mirror – and soon won back his coin, influence and, most importantly, his betrothed. All seemed well until he discovered his wishes’ unwanted side effect: his heart was slowly hardening into stone.

Now the witcher was on the verge of bringing the pact between Olgierd and Master Mirror to completion. Did this mean everything would soon be as it once was? Geralt was not so sure. One question kept nagging him: what was that “something very personal” Gaunter O’Dimm intended to collect from Olgierd?

Once Geralt realized Master Mirror was playing for the highest of stakes – Olgierd von Everec's soul – he decided he could not sit idly by. Instead he found a way to cheat the demonic being and win Olgierd back his soul. Free from his pact and his heart restored, Olgierd thanked Geralt and gave him his sword – a souvenir which had been in his family for generations – then walked off into the sunset.

Geralt did not have to wait long to find out what lay at the heart of the contract between Olgierd von Everec and Gaunter O'Dimm. In exchange for regaining his family fortune, clearing his name and marrying Iris, Olgierd had agreed to give Master Mirror his soul. Geralt could now only watch as O'Dimm collected his due. Thus ended the sad tale of Olgierd von Everec, a man who lived as if there was no tomorrow, feasted as if he had never known joy and loved a love so strong he was willing to surrender his own soul for it.

Geralt did not have to wait long to find out what lay at the heart of the contract between Olgierd von Everec and Gaunter O'Dimm. In exchange for regaining his family fortune, clearing his name and marrying Iris, Olgierd had agreed to give Master Mirror his soul. Geralt knew of a way to stop this, but for some reason did nothing and instead watched as O'Dimm collected his due. Thus ended the sad tale of Olgierd von Everec, a man who lived as if there was no tomorrow, feasted as if he had never known joy and loved a love so strong he was willing to surrender his own soul for it.
Olgierd von Everec
At your service, squire!
Hey!
No stranger to the bottle, eh?
My valor stands on three pillars - good food, good drink and good fun.
A devil walked a crooked path, his heart a-full of ire…
No soul would lend him coin for drink, no wench would quench his fire!
Gone daft, witcher?
Watch where you're goin'!
Got any yarrow extract?
Wouldn't happen to have some yarrow extract?
I do. In the back. Follow me, please.
Need some yarrow extract.
Let me have a look.
Show me what you got.
Yearning to play a few rounds of gwent. That oughta set me straight.
Let's play cards.
So long.
Farewell.
Know any master formulae?
Know any advanced formulae, maybe something you could teach me?
All I know I learned from Master Gremist of Skellige. Lookin' to apprentice yourself in the herbalist trade?
Nah, just wanna learn something new.
Call it what you will. You must sail 'cross the Great Sea, find the isle of Ard Skellig. There, in the Sacred Grove, the learned Master Gremist will judge whether you're fit to be his pupil.
Greetings! Is it herbs you seek? Medicines to mute a bashful maid's inhibitions? Or a concoction to raise your own courage for a second go?
That it? No other weeds or brews?
Aye. One to make your hair grow, another to do the opposite. An easer of pain, a calmer of heartburn. Tell me what ails you.
Huh. That was rather efficient.
That all you got to say? I saved your life.
Pff. We'd have disposed of that rabble easily.
We?
My, aren't we precise? You know what I mean! Are you here to trade or not? Hm?
Hey there.
Iris

While wandering the lands to the northeast of Novigrad, Geralt came across a small camp of Ofieri travelers. One of these foreigners turned out to be a skilled runewright and enchanter, able to create runes and glyphs and enchant them into powerful words. Geralt was eager to make use of his services, but the runewright had lost his tools and rare materials. The witcher thus decided to provide the Ofieri the coin needed to reopen for business.

A small fortune was all it took for the Ofieri to get started. Once he received it, he got down to work and from then on Geralt could buy simple runes and glyphs from him and have him place basic words in his swords and armor.

You can tell an experienced witcher by the way he examines a notice board. To the novice eye, these weathered planks contain nothing but clumsily-scrawled messages touching on matters thoroughly mundane: trifling announcements, offers of sale or purchase, lewd rhymes, et cetera, et cetera, ad nauseam. A witcher with years under his belt, however, will search the dross carefully, knowing that it often hides a jewel – a witcher contract, for example, or, as in this particular case, information about a mysterious "runewright" from a far-off land...
Acquire 5000 crowns for the Ofieri runewright.
Give 5000 crowns to the Ofieri runewright.
Visit the runewright and learn more about his craft.
Enchanting: Start-up Costs
Another day, another corpse -- and, the witcher suspected, another document revealing the tale of the deceased's demise. He was not mistaken.

Nicolas Vogel's laboratory notebook described the experiments the mad mage had conducted on harpies and also mentioned a hidden stash of coin. The chest's contents would be no use to Nicolas in the afterlife, so Geralt decided to secure them for himself.
He found the treasure chest atop the ruined tower. After emptying the thoroughly pecked container of its contents, the brave witcher continued on his Path.
Search the laboratory's ruins.
Read Nicolas Vogel's notebook.
The Royal Air Force
Devoured by necrophages… Poetic justice at its best.
Whoa. Herbalist wasn't joking.
For the Fire! The Fire!
Swine's castin' hexes!
The end! May the end come at last!
Go on, then! Kill meeee!
Like a lamb to the slaughter!
Let not your eye spare, nor be you moved with pity!
I'll go round 'im!
Raise the lament, brethren! Cry it out to the 'eavens!
What the flyin' fuck is this?!
Intruder! Get him!
My Dearest Wife…
Letter's from Olgierd to Iris.
Were I only as skilled with words as I am with my blade.
Especially now, when an icy void grips my heart.
I see how you look at me, and I see you wither.
I cannot help you, but I believe I can cease harming you.
This letter and this rose are my farewell. May you live in health and remember but the good times.
Olgierd.
We're almost at our journey's end.
What's there?
Iris von Everec's greatest fear.
Gaunter O'Dimm
Time to go to the wedding. Shani's probably already waiting.
Agh. Vlod's ghost won't stop pestering me until he's had his fun. Time to head to the wedding.
Geralt, old chap, mind turning your arse around and going back to the wedding? I was to have a bit of fun, not a bloody walkabout.
Keep this up, and I'll get sore legs is all. Not quite what Olgierd asked for.
Fine, we'll go back.
Hideous creatures.
You all right?
Mh. Fine.
Geralt! Are you all right?
I'm fine. You? How'd you get in here?
I told you. Vern had a key to the grate.
I squeezed through those bars.
Look, it's Franz.
What's left of him, you mean.
What kind of beast would do that?
Doubt we'll learn anything else here. We need to find the lair.
Right behind you.
Need to find its lair.
Hmm. Lotta drowners.
Does that mean anything?
Well, means our monster doesn't attack them.
Seems they get along with whatever's prowling the sewers. Some kind of symbiosis.
Hm. Wonder why there are so many drowners.
[Examine the corpse.]
Hm. Interesting.
What?
Franz had a leg wound, right?
Mhm, just above the knee.
Manage to apply anything to it?
Yes, some spirit, but that was it. Why do you ask?
Look - half of Franz's leg is gone. Monster must've chewed it off.
Other bodies were untouched. Except for the wounds they sustained in battle.
Are you suggesting… the beast likes alcohol?
Mhm. Mixed with blood.
What do you have to say…?
Pier near the Western Gate. Should be easy enough to find.
Hm. Need to brew the mixture first.
Mhm. Must be the cook.
Hm, a few drops and the boys at the barracks'll have a restless night…
That's just it - certifiably insane. Didn't pass the tests, apparently.
He mad, or what?
Volunteered. Word is he had to bribe the medics to let him enlist.
Lance Corporal Vatslav - how'd that prick wind up with us?
But to pay hard coin to enter the army… Thought at my age nothin' could surprise me.
Cook like that's a right treasure, he is. No gripin' about poor supplies. Just the gumption to enrich our gruel.
No one. Came through the Western Gate the morn. Saw Maarten on the pier, rod in hand, fishin'.
That true? Who told you?
Mh, fish chowder for supper the day.
Mh, aye. If only he'd go a bit lighter on the garlic…
Nothing about the cook...
Hmm... Nothing interesting.
It can only bring trouble, mate, only trouble.
Why the hell not?
Trust me, you'd do better not to take any interest in the Borsodis.
Well, think on it. To marry into a dynasty like that. It'd be like livin' in clover!
Why do you ask?
That, uh, Horst Borsodi - he got a daughter?
Go on, now. We'd best not be seen together.
Good day. Fish biting?
Aye, they're biting.
What about you?
What's that?
Got this mixture. Pay you to pour it in the soup for the boys at the garrison. On my signal. Nothing dangerous about it. Most they'll think is that the fish wasn't exactly fresh.
It'll cost you, mate. Something dear.
You'll help me free of charge.
Asking a lot. Too much. How about you do this free of charge, huh? Out of the kindness of your heart?
Aye, I'll help. Outta kindness…
Wait for the signal. And mum's the word, understood?
Fine. Here.
Fine. Willing to pay.
Know what? Be back later.
We'll talk later.
You're scarin' the fish away. Pay up or piss off.
Give us some sugar, han'some!
Eat, drink and be cheery!
Oh, I'd gladly take that little ass for a romp.
Negotiator
Master Casimir! Toss aside the torch, ee gads!
Aaaaa, piss off then fuck off! Ye'll not tell me what to do!
Wha-- What's going on here?
Intit plain? Master Casimir's sat upon his roof. Claims he'll blow hisself to bits!
Bought the wench pearls! Silks, satins! And how the fuck's she repaid me? Made me a heidbanger cuckold!
Family troubles?
Huh. A falling out in the family?
Aye! His Euphemia, she were fine, pretty as a picture, you might say! An' five bairns they has.
On the short side, but so well mannered! Always bow, ask after your health. Not at all grumpy like the ealdorman's laddies.
Till the day Euphemia bundled up her belongin's and their bairns. Tossed 'em all on a wagon, and that's all we seen of her!
Master Casimir's been pure yampy since - bawlin', whingin', now this!
This'll be one for the ploughin' annals! Goin' out with a bang! When this fuckin' blows, they'll see the fires in Novigrad!
Lemme talk to him.
I'll try to talk some sense into him.
An' if he should grow angered?
Wench demanded a canopied bed! And got it! Silver tableware, she said! Got that, too!
Lackin' nothin'! Not a thing! What the fuck else was I tae give her?!
Doubt he can grow any angrier.
Hail Melitele, our hallowed mother. Keep us from evil….
What kind o' knob you got?! Likely come to poke my Euphemia, eh?! Well, ye're late! She's gone!
No. I jus--
Postmaster said the same! Denied it all, swore on the balls of his gods! And the eejit I am, I believed the bugger!
Three years they bumped about under my nose! Then ran off! My granda told it right! Not a bloke out there doesnae want to get 'tween a dwarf wench's trotters!
Set the torch aside. Let's talk this out.
Care to set that torch aside? So we can talk this out? Calmly?
Calmly?! Calmly?! Wench tossed me aside, took the weans, and I'm to be calm?!
The country, she says! Fresh air's what I need, she says! So we came out here! Anythin' for my bunny!
Cept 'stead of suckin' air, she sucked off the postmaster! In my ploughin' bed! I cannae take it no more!
You're pathetic.
Know what? You're pathetic.
What?! What the fuck did you say?!
You heard me. Wanna die? Go jump off a bridge. Instead of scaring folk shitless.
Lookie here! Got us a clever one! Tellin' me how to off myself!
Even willing to help you. No chance you'll do it on your own. You're not just a cuckold, you're a coward.
Me?! A coward?! I'll not listen to this tripe! Don't ye go nowhere, ye bastart! I'll tie yer ball bag round your neck!
Actually, got no reason to live. Blow yourself sky high.
Agh, know what? Go ahead, blow yourself up.
What did you say?!
I see it now. You're fucked. If it's too much, if you're too soft, can't handle it, that's that.
What?! Me, Casimir Bassi, mine foreman from Mahakam - soft?!
Works out that way. No balls, forgot 'em somewhere.
I've no--?! Me? No balls?! You just wait, ye rotter, ye scum bag, ye pricklicker! I'll show you!
Come to think of it, doubt you're fit for the job. Not in that state.
What?! I'm not fit?! What the fuck ye sayin' I'm not fit for, ye cocksucker?!
I'd need you to blow something up, open. But--
And I'm no fit for that?! Me, Casimir Bassi, top mine foreman in Mahakam?!
More like top cuckold in Redania, now.
Top--?! Cuck--?! Whaaaaat?! You wait, ye cur, ye rogue, ye dick heid! You just wait!
Doubt you're fit to work, anyway.
You'll find someone else. You're bound to.
Forget about it. Listen, got a job for you.
Forge--! Forget it?! Here I'm barin' my soul, and ye're gonna talk me up about work?!
Ye're all the same! We dwarves, we're born tae muck about in the mines! Bend our necks 'neath human yokes! Ye dinnae give a duck's cock about it, ye ploughin' racists!
Forget about it. Got a job for you.
You'll find another.
I'm sure you know the saying - plenty of fish and all. You'll find another.
Another?! Is that yer take, that one wench'll do for another?! That I'll take any, so long as she's got a full beard?!
No, but in my experience--
Fuck yer experience! We're talkin' about my experience, mine! Agh, I've had my fill of this shite!
No. No, wait!
Relax. Let you know in due course.
I'll let you know.
What?! I was a minge hair from takin' my life. Now ye give me with the gab of a wench from personnel at a manufactury?! "Dinnae call on us, we'll call on you?!" Ye pure mad dafty?
Now talk, and don't ye swick me! Ye givin' me the job or not?!
Yeah, yeah - you got it. Now calm down.
Yeah, you're hired. Welcome aboard.
Changed my mind.
Know what? Changed my mind. Think we'll both be better off--
I'm of no use to a witcher, either. Argh! Shite luck, that. Shite life.
Dammit.
I commiserate, honestly.
Aaah, talkin' out yer fanny flaps!
No, no, seriously. I--
Aye?! Seriously?! Couldn't give a hedgehog's arse for me or my troubles! Ye're as boggin' a liar as Euphemia!
Think ye can dupe me with yer sweetened mincin', eh? Oh, no! No! That was that!
Casimir, no!
Really sorry.
Get down. Now.
Get down. Now.
What? Aw-- Comin'. I'm comin'.
Och. Aah! Ye bruised my bones, right splintered 'em!
Sorry. Would've preferred to talk it out. Thing is, you gave me no choice.
Nay, dinnae apologize. I needed somethin' o' the sort. Some fella tae knock the muck out o' my heid. Argh…
Take that! And that, ye bugger! For Euphemia! For the weans! For the canopy!
Stop! Stop it! Don't make me hurt you!
Sorry. I was consumed, pent up, ye ken? Feel better, now. Laid my fists to a punchin' bag. Cooled off.
So, uh, ahem - what is it you wanted?
Want you to open a door. Permanently, so it won't close again.
I see. And what might ye find on the other side of this door?
A reward. Big one. To be split. Enough for everyone.
If ye'd come a week past, I'd 'ave sent ye the fuck away. But now, now I've nothin' to lose. What's it I'm to do?
Welcome aboard. Go to the herbalist's hut - you'll learn everything there.
Hut of the herbalist who lives near Oxenfurt. Go there and ask for yarrow extract. Learn all you need to know. Clear?
As a Mahakaman highland stream. See ya.
Herbalist who lives near Oxenfurt. His hut. Go there and ask for yarrow extract. Learn all you need to know. Clear?
And might you be headed there about now? 'Cause if so, we could head there together, eh?
Hm, actually wouldn't mind some company for the slog.
Aye, that! And I can teach ye a cheery tune what to keep the spring in our step! It starts like this…
All in all, why not.
Got something to tend to on the way.
Need to tend to something on the way. So we'll meet there.
Och… I cannae waiit to fuckin' blast it wide!
Ach, if only my heart were whole and held dear. Maybe once I'm flush with coin?
Gone batshit barmy, he has. I told youse it'd end this way!
Fidelity, she swore! Love! What of it? Crushed heart, stones and cock, that's what!
The mutant must perish!
For the Eternal Fire!
You can huff and puff all you want, wolf!
Come now! Stop squirming.
Die, die, die!
I pity you, mutant.
All as one, brothers!
Aaah! We'll avenge thee, brother!
Very well. I won't.
So be it. If there's no demand, I shan't supply. But it would have been a beautiful speech.
It's almost midnight, time for the capping.
You're a bridesmaid, Shani - take your place.
That was unduly harsh.
Didn't have to make him suffer.
Of course I needn't have.
But I could.
Thanks. He was starting to be a pain.
Thanks, not sure I could've stood him much longer.
At your service. Always.
I hope you didn't hurt him.
I disposed of a pest. There was no need for you to suffer his cheek any longer.
Geralt had finished his task, you see, so--
Yes, I know. As soon as he finishes one task, he needs to rush off to the next.
Who knows, perhaps this time will be different? I saw you looking at each other. And it just so happens I also know the history you share…
You do? How?
Shani, darling… would you ask an eagle how it knows how to fly?
Regardless… what matters is Vlodimir von Everec will bother you no more.
I'd like to stay a bit longer.
I'd like to stay longer… but…
Don't make excuses, Geralt. I'm not angry. A witcher has to ply his trade, follow his Path.
As for me, well… perhaps I expected too much of this wedding, got the wrong impression.
Not sure I understand.
Never mind. I should find Aldona. I am her bridesmaid, after all.
Ah, there it is. The face of a man who's failed to understand a woman.
You understand her?
Of course. Women are simple. The problem is that men are hopeless fools.
Your friend will now make a show of being hurt. Pick her some flowers or bring her a drink. She'll get over it in a snap.
Rather manage without your advice, thank you.
She cares for you, you have feelings for her. Don't overthink it. Surrender to spontaneous honesty - nothing more beautiful in human relationships.
You needn't end like Aldona and Johnnus - besotted fools bound by a contract they'll never escape.
Seize the night, seize your chance. Enjoy one another - that's it. Have fun.
Should get back to Olgierd soon.
And like that, it's over. Huh, here I thought I might get some more time with you. Silly, wasn't it?
Wouldn't say that.
True. Gotta get going.
What did you do to him?
Sent him back whence he came.
What did you do to him?
Is Vlodimir's ghost gone?
You see? She asks after me. Misses me already!
I'm here, my ever-loving tulip.
That kiss as we danced made my head so light, a team of hellish stallions could not tear me away before I receive one more… or two more. Or as many as you'll give.
You seem to have enjoyed yourself. I'm glad.
A kiss! I knew it would end this way! An end that is but a beginning!
No, it's just an end. It's after midnight - your time has come.
Bah, we needn't fret such trifles. Death's not come to claw me back, so why not continue our revels?
What's Geralt think about that? You gave your word.
Shani, darling… I'm dead. Can't expect too much from a corpse.
Vlodimir von Everec - go back whence you came. Please.
Stay out of this.
Stop! I beg you, stop!
Get ye hence, or I'll take you with me, and your moldy crypt will look like paradise in comparison. The choice is yours.
Aaaargh!
Don't torture him.
I promise he'll not die, heheh.
Gods, what is this?
It's past midnight. You can take off those lovely ears. Only if you want to, of course.
Lovely as they are, think I'll put them away for now.
A lovely custom! Blushing maids, twirling in dance, their hair swirling freely, their bodices undone, their bouncing…
Will you stop?
Did you see it? Shani caught the garland. She'll be next to marry as peasant superstition has it.
Maybe. Doesn't matter. It's past midnight. Time for you to go back to the crypt.
I can't. I'm not finished here.
No need?! Why, there's every need!
Ahem. Till now I'd always considered peasant jollities unworthy of a gentleman! For tell me, who among you would rub shoulders with swineherds if born a noble?
I delighted in the beauty of buxom farm wenches, of course, and indeed still do. Given more time, I'd prove this to each and every maiden here!
Farmhands are a different story. Never took any note of them. Had one or two groom my mounts. They did this well, but were never worthy of conversation - nay, not even if you paid me!
For one must live by certain principles, am I right?!
But this day… this day has changed all! Beneath the muck and dung, a peasant is a man! I understand this thanks to you!
You've still shite all to talk about, but I don't mind anymore. For this I thank you. And say, you are well loved!
It's almost midnight. Time for the capping!
Wait, I'm not done!
Oh yes you are. All the maids join in the capping!
You're a maid too, Shani…
I shall make a speech and that's that.
I'll leave you for a moment. As a bridesmaid I need to be by the bride for the capping.
Go on, Shani. I'll manage fine alone.
Ladies and gentlemen! This night I've tasted of life's delights so fiercely, I've decided to make a speech!
Geralt! There's no need.
The midnight chime has struck, the capping time's a-come! What thoughts in young hearts prance, what dreams make young blood run?
Be they nice, be they vice, of jesterly or lordly stance, out they'll come in this hour's dance!
Let's toast the lovely couple, but afore a year shall pass, we'll toast a little bairn, who's lovelier by half.
But ne'er you mind our singin', ‘tis only meant for laughs, a pretext and a ruse, so we can drink a glass.
The bride has sworn her vows, but the groom still best beware, lest in the coming year, two horns on head he'll wear.
What's got our groom a-thinkin'? He's so gloomy now. Perhaps he's second guessin', if he'll get that cow?
You'll get your cow, my lad, and calves and milk and all, So merry make and drink, for ‘tis your wedding ball!
Be happy, daughter dear.
Gar-land, gar-land, gar-land!
As hallowed tradition holds, whoever caught the garland shall be next to wed!
That really necessary?
It came rushing back in a torrent - how we caroused at Olgierd's wedding.
I couldn't resist, had to pen a few words. Will you give him the letter?
I will.
Thanks. You're a good chap, witcher. Dull as dirt, but good.
Heheh - witcher's talkin' to himself. Must be damn sloshed, eh?
And good on it! Gotsta get drunk at a weddin'!
Olgierd's wife liked flowers. Judging by the ornamentation, this might be hers.
Seen this hairbrush. It was in bad shape in the real world.
Not you again.
Another dream of the past. Bet this one's incomplete, too.
Just a little different than the painting.
Candles also need lighting…
These were lit in the painting… but that's not all.
Fire was burning in the painting… Still something missing, though.
That oughta do it.
Castel Ravello. A Toussaint wine. Expensive.
Silver thread, pearls… Doll must've cost a fortune.
A lavish feast. Trying to impress the guests.
My darling… is everything all right? You seem pale… out of sorts.
Everything's fine, really. But why don't you tell me how you fare? I'm ever so happy to see you! Except, why didn't Grandmamma and Grandpapa come?
It's a long, rugged journey. Muddy.
They still refuse to meet me, is that it?
And what's this?
We've brought some of Iris' things. Her favorite brush, her cherished doll. Ah, and this… for you.
Bank notes.
We paid off your debts, bought them out. To avoid bringing shame to the family.
So nice of Mama and Papa to remember me.
Olgierd?
Now you see his true nature? I warned you before the wedding.
A ruffian and a boor who keeps the company of bandits. Are you not afraid to live under one roof with that rabble?
Who's in the what now?
Uh-huh?
