War, lads, is a fickle bitch. In a blink she drops one man dead in a ditch.
The next she lets live till the sun goes down, his guts all the while strewn over the ground.
Let the stricken roebuck weep, or give it an ale and aid it to sleep! Hahahaha!
Bit o' grub, bit o' drink, bit o' tit - then we hit the road!
Eh? Ants pick your stones apart!
Easy, squire.
Oi! Why there? What for? Life kick you in the arse, had enough?
Terrible beast prowls the sewers down thataway. Best avoided altogether.
Devoured dozens of maidens, folk say. And many a bold fighter's gone in and never come out.
Meryn
Pig
Light-haired halfling. Must be Folkert.
Ripped open, gutted and drained. No way to determine the cause of death.
Wanted - cradle, used but unworn… Need a beau to accompany me to a friend's wedding… Willing to trade a leaky pot for a cart…? Who writes these notices?
Need a witcher?
Any bloke willin' to kill a monster. A witcher would do.
Monster? What kind?
Big. Bad. Ugly. Squats in the sewers.
If you're interested, drop by the Garin Estate. Ask for Olgierd von Everec. He's the one ordered this posted.
Time
Aye, sugarplum?
You're lookin' pale. Eat somethin'!
Gonna slurp your oysters!
Chop you up, stick you in a stew!
You white-haired man-whore!
Wraith
Churl! Rotten churl!
I'll gobble your liver!
Whoreson!
Hrm?
Oooh, me tummy's growlin' fierce as hell….
How do you know I'm not Geralt?
Wait… you can see me? That is, me, Vlodimir von Everec?
Of course, why ever wouldn't I?
Because… I'm in Geralt's body… the witcher's… and--
Just who would I be if the true nature of things remained hidden from me?
Someone like you - meaning no one.
I wouldn't want to get blood on my damsel's dress, but insult me once more and--
You shan't touch me. I know you'd like very much to act like your brother in this situation, demonstrate how manly you are, but - let's be honest - nothing will come of it.
You're simply not him, no matter how much you wish you were.
But gingerbread's nowt but flour, honey, eggs and spices.
I beg to differ, madame. You omit the most important ingredient in gingerbread - time.
What sort of balderdash is he feeding them?
Quiet. If you listen, you'll learn.
Time? What do ye mean, time? An ingredient?
Time gives the proper consistency. Time provides that ideal crunch on the outside, the delicious moistness within.
So how much o' this time does it take?
That you will not find in any recipe. You must surrender to your senses. Let them lead you so close to time you touch it. Let you sniff it, stroke it, even… Time, time is the key.
Greetings, Shani. I must introduce myself. Gaunter O'Dimm.
My, what a lovely dress. The color suits you exquisitely.
Thanks. I've heard a lot about you, but no one mentioned cooking. Seem to know quite a bit about gingerbread.
Quite simply, I know a lot about everything.
Is that so? What do you know about me?
That you were ever the worse brother. That you envied Olgierd from your earliest days and always wished to be just like him.
I came here to revel, enjoy myself, not to discuss my brother.
That's good. Olgierd probably wouldn't want me to talk to you about him.
Olgierd was my brother and my friend. Never have there been more loyal comrades than us.
I will not listen to this.
Not true. Prove it.
Rubbish! I never envied my brother!
Of course you did. He was a shining role model. Olgierd ran faster, shot truer, lifted greater weights…
Olgierd learned to read first, although you tried your damndest to beat him. As you grew up, he had his pick of girls, whereas you made do with the leftovers…
I apologize, Shani. I'm rather sorry you have to hear this.
Stop fooling yourself. Shani isn't here for you. She's here for Geralt. Even after death, you still play the pale imitation.
Oh, by the way… Olgierd's a much better dancer.
You lying dog! That's my brother! I loved him!
The question is, were you as dear to him as he seems to have been to you?
He made a hero of me in death! In my last battle… in truth, I was far from valiant. Five came at me. I'll not deny it, I fled…
I hid in a cellar, yet they found me. Cornered me, like a rat. But Olgierd told everyone I flew at all five. Took them on all at once, alone!
I'm rather curious how you know all this.
Olgierd visits my grave. Often. Pours a drink for me, gets soused himself, and talks of the old times… he cannot see me, but I hear his every word.
Hmm. Well, perhaps one day he'll say something veeerrry surprising…
What're you getting at?
I shan't disturb you any longer. Have a splendid time - for time is… time is short.
Shani, I'm sorry, I…
It's all right. That was… Oh, forget him. We're here to enjoy ourselves, right?
Let's go. The night's still young.
The capping will begin soon. Let's take our places.
Let's. I've got an idea…
All lies. Not a word of truth.
Don't let it bother you.
Olgierd was not just my brother. More importantly, he was my best mate.
Let it go. I believe you. And now revel on. Time won't wait.
You must know, my dear ladies, that traditional gingerbread is not your ordinary baked good.
It's a culinary phenomenon. A legend. A dark and obscure object of the deepest desire.
I wish to talk to you. What you said about Olgierd…
You've not heard enough?
Go and revel while you can. The time for talk will come later.
Boy
Warg
*Sniff* Hm. Rotting meat?

Shani had been a diligent student – she not only had heard of the von Everec family, but also happened to be in the possession of a tome indicating the location of their family crypt. She and Geralt decided to journey there together. Shani was to bring a censer with her, which Geralt intended to use to perform the ancient ritual of Blood Summoning to bring forth the ghost of Olgierd’s dead brother.

Thanks to the Blood Summoning (which, as is the norm during witcher adventures, did not go off without certain complications), Geralt was able to summon the ghost of Vlodimir von Everec. Vlodimir, delighted at the prospect of enjoying a “cracking good time,” stated that to do so, he would need a body… and then promptly possessed the witcher’s, despite the latter's heated resistance. From that moment till Vlodimir had had his fun, Vlod’s ghost accompanied Geralt everywhere the witcher went. And it so happened on that day, he was going to a wedding, where he was to meet Shani. Vlodimir was thrilled at this, for he had taken quite the liking to the young medic, but, learning that she meant something special to Geralt, he promised to keep his hands off her. Yet something about his manner left room to doubt he’d keep this promise…

Thanks to the Blood Summoning (which, as is the norm during witcher adventures, did not go off without certain complications), Geralt was able to summon the ghost of Vlodimir von Everec. Vlodimir, delighted at the prospect of enjoying a “cracking good time,” stated that to do so, he would need a body… and then promptly possessed the witcher’s, despite the latter's heated resistance. From that moment till Vlodimir had had his fun, Vlod’s ghost accompanied Geralt everywhere the witcher went. And it so happened on that day, he was going to a wedding, where he was to meet Shani. Vlodimir was thrilled at this, for he had taken quite the liking to the young medic. It seemed they were all in for a night to remember.
Once Geralt and Vlodimir arrived at the wedding, the ghost jumped into Geralt’s body and threw himself headlong into a whirlwind of merriment, mirth and amusement.

Hearing Geralt recount that night's festivities, I realized it was a great shame I had not been able to attend. Not only would I have graced the guests with a performance worthy of the occasion, but also I would have witnessed its wonders first-hand, the better to now convey them to you, dear reader… Yet I consider my chance to craft an epic nuptial ballad merely delayed, not missed, for Shani caught the garland during the capping, meaning I will surely be a guest of honor at her wedding in the near future. Vlodimir, I hear, enjoyed himself tremendously, though he was forced off the stage and into the netherworld in a rather unpleasant manner by Master Mirror at the end. Before that happened, he wrote a letter to his brother in his own (that is to say, Geralt’s) blood, thus providing proof that the witcher had fulfilled Olgierd’s wish.

As the witcher had suspected, Olgierd would not simply take Geralt’s word for it that Vlodimir had not only risen from the dead (temporarily, at least), but had also had a splendid time. Yet the letter Vlod wrote in blood effectively resolved all Olgierd’s doubts. The task was deemed completed.

As Master Mirror forewarned, Olgierd von Everec asked Geralt to perform several tasks for him. One of these was to show his brother, Vlodimir, the time of his life. As I know from many pleasant personal experiences, the witcher, grim as he may sometimes seem, is more than capable of arranging a fantastic night out. Yet in this case, there was one particularly tricky catch: Vlodimir was dead. As a first step to overcoming this obstacle, Geralt decided to go see Shani, who, as a Redanian subject, an Oxenfurt resident and a woman of great learning, might just have some information about where Vlodimir is buried.
Talk to Shani about the von Everec family crypt.
Meet Shani in front of the von Everec family crypt.
Enter the von Everec family crypt.
Use your Witcher Senses to explore the von Everec family crypt.
Light the main votive to continue the ritual.
Defeat the wraiths of dead von Everecs.
Spread incense in every room in the crypt.
Defeat the wraiths as they appear.
Meet Shani by the farm where the wedding will be held.
Take part in the wedding activities until midnight.
Defeat your opponents.
Fish Shani's shoe out of the lake and give it to her.
Use your Witcher Senses to find the fire swallower.
Escort the fire swallower back to the wedding.
Give Shani the shoe you fished out of the lake for her.
Inform Olgierd the task has been completed.
Protect the fire swallower from the "bear."
Inform the bride's mother about the fire swallower's fate.
Follow Shani and meet the newlyweds.
Talk to the newlyweds.
Talk to Master Mirror at the wedding.
Juggle to amuse the wedding guests.
Drive the pigs into the pen.
Go to the barn for the capping ceremony.
Dead Man's Party
Coming or not?
I'm coming, I'm coming…
To the wedding, then. Perhaps I'll find some more interesting diversions there.
Are you always so easily scared?
You're a man who's trade is literally to play with fire. How can you fear a tiny runt of a dog?
Was a monster! A daemon!
So you said. You're a stoneless coward, sir - that's that.
Oh! Beg your pardon… I'm not a coward - I'm cautious. Know what'd become of a fire eater who paid no 'eed to caution?
Hmm… I suppose he might singe his tongue.
Guessed it. Settles that misunderstanding.
Missing man, missing mutt.
Am I seeing this right? That gammy puss ran up a tree to escape that puppy?
Guess so. You! Get down!
Oh, no. No bloody chance! I value my life!
What do we do?
Sit.
Now that is power! If I'd had that, the whoresons never would've gutted me.
Make it do some folly. Roll about on the ground, that sort of sport!
No.
Ugh, could you be any more of a bore? I'll do it myself.
Roll over!
Leave it alone.
Were I to command it to eat its own tail, it would do so, right?
Daemon! Doghouse, now!
Now what've you done? Why ever? Ruined my fun.
Have it at the wedding.
I'll calm it.
We chase the dog off.
Don't know how to handle yappy little dogs?
I'd chase it off with a stick. But that strikes me as… unwitcherly.
Effective, though.
Job done.
Climb down. Man-eating beast's gone, as you can see.
You sure it won't return?
Positive.
Better safe than sorry, I always say…
Geralt, this jester is drunk as a skunk. I hope he's not polished off that bottle yet.
I saved your life, man. Do you not at least owe me a sip?
Course. Bottoms up.
I say, cracking good mead. Now I understand why you wanted some private time with it.
Fine mead, true… But I was fleeing an 'ound? 'Ound? Bah, it was a monster, a furry, fangy devil! They chose a fittin' name for it…
Those're... excellent ears. Might try a pair like that. Just not sure they'd fit under my cap.
Your hat. Here.
Your cap, sir. Lost it running from that pup like a gutless coward.
Ohh… my dearest cap. Always brought me good luck, it has… I wear it for every performance.
You can't possibly go to the wedding like that.
You can forget about performing in your state.
And just what state would that be?
Look at yourself, man. You're a tramp, can barely stand, let alone perform.
First off - that's bollocks. Second, I'm a fire eater, not a stilt walker. Standin' straight ain't a requirement…
Oh, you shan't pull the wool over my eyes. I know your type.
Now, here's the plan - we shall head down this path till we arrive at the wedding. You'll have sobered by then.
But--
Silence! Do you know me, sir? When a nobleman speaks, you listen!
You will stay close at my side. We will return to the wedding, where you will put on a show to make our honored guests soil their breeches from joy. Got it?
Y-yes.
Good. Then let's be off.
Let's go. You can sober up on the way.
Fire eating - what's the trick?
This may be my only chance to ask - your fire guzzling trickery, how does it work?
Ooh, they'd toss me out the guild if I told. 'Cept if I took you on as an apprentice. In 'alf a year's time, you'd learn.
I haven't half a year. Come, just between you and me. We've drunk together - we're practically brothers!
Drank it all yourself. You're no brother of mine.
You dare toy with me this way?! Very well! Refuse to tell me, and I shall leave you here as a morsel for any passing boars, bears or bloodthirsty fawns. So choose wisely.
This here's assault! He's suppressin' the arts!
Out with it!
I g-- I got this special mixture I drink before every show. After that, I can eat fire, spit fire, do what I please, and it don't burn nothing.
Is that all? Where's the art in it? Any dribbling imbecile can smear his throat with a protective slurry.
I've had just about enough of this! First they release the hounds, then come and steal my mead, and now insults! I'm done 'ere! Goodbye!
Didn't mean to offend the bloody charlatan. Do something.
Now, you're gonna forget everything you've seen, said and heard in the woods.
Wouldn't a smack upside the head help the matter? Put the cheating coward back in his place?
No need.
You'll go back to the wedding and show everybody your tricks.
Ugh, your charlatan's tricks.
Yes, sir. I'll do as you say.
Not going anywhere.
Do what you want. Not about to beg you to stay.
But the scamp's already been paid!
Not my problem.
Uh-huh. Then know this - I leave now. I've never seen such behavior. This is overt lack of respect for the arts.
You two-bit honorless pricklicker!
No sense raging about it. Back to the wedding, let's go.
Do what you want.
Listen, I'll pay you.
Listen, I'll give you some more coin, and you'll go back to the wedding.
Are you daft?! This extortionist's already got his due!
Take it or leave it.
Right. Convincin'.
Honorless prick. Olgierd had it right - all artists are whores.
Let's go.
Ehh, I told him to hide. Bully good hider with a pup at his heels, why not now?
No magic delights, I suppose. Best tell the bride's mother.
Tell me, are bears often boar-shaped, in your experience?
Got weak eyes, see… Besides, I'm a fire eater, not some damned naturalist.
Indeed you are not, master, uh… hmm, believe I failed to ask - what do they call you?
David Artensborrow.
Listen here, master Hattensburrow. Stay close and no harm will come to you.
I'll see to it your drunken, fire-spitting gob gets to the wedding safe and sound.
Ahh, my first witcher contract. Done.
Fire eater - found, his arse - saved…
If I could live again, I'd be a witcher. For damned certain.
I require a rescue! Get me outta here! Before it tears me to shreds!
Help! Somebody 'elp me! Save me! Anybody!
Gads! Bear!
Bear?! That?! As much as your cock's a tent-pole. Hide, you blind fool!
Save me!
Keep calm, stay close.
Shan't stray a step. Wild animals behind every stump in these woods.
Save me! Sod off, beast! Somebody drag this drool bucket away!
Is there anyone in this forsaken hole?! Anyone at all??
Almost there. Even a buffoon like you should make it at this point.
Seems there shall be no tricks. We must inform the bride's mother the magician turned coward.
My first witcher contract.
Didn't turn out as I'd hoped. Yet I still had a cracking time.
Daemon's not half as black as they paint him.
Save me, witcher!
Wyvern
Well, well. Got an early bird in our midst.
Let's begin.
Prime. Just one patrol. Mixture of yours must've worked.
Eveline. You ready?
Are you kidding? Of course I am.
Three… two… one.
Bugger it all! Ye said there'd be no one inside!
It's clear. On your way!
Ploughin' city fowl. Shite all over, again.
Groo, grooo, groo!
What?! I'll show you...
Patrol's turnin' round!
We've one minute! Move!
Damn. Should've blown myself to bits, prick and all.
It's clear. On your way!
Ploughin' city fowl. Shite all over, again.
Groo, grooo, groo!
What?! I'll show you--
Patrol's turnin' round!
We've one minute! Move!
Hail Melitele, hallowed mother, keep us from…
If memory serves, you assured us there'd be no one inside.
Agreed. Past the point of no return.
Gotta agree. Backing out's not an option anymore. Need to see this through, whatever happens.
Hallowed words.
Whatever… Don your masks and let's go.
One guard could mean many more. You'd best draw your sword now.
No.
What now?
No one dies. Said so from the start.
Not the time, true. But we'll discuss this later. You can be sure of that.
At your service, mate.
We'll argue later. You can be sure of that.
Seems my informer was wrong.
Is that all you've got to say? I nearly broke my neck!
You knew what you were signin' up for. This is no time to argue.
Careful, now. One guard could mean many more.
Geralt, you lead. On your tiptoes, hand on your sword.
Don't fret, love. Ye're fetchin' no matter what ye wear!
Would you like a ball gown and tiara to go with that?
Shut it. And you, Eveline, no more foolishness. Come on.
Stranger! Greetings! Might you be interested in a moment's chat?
I have for you an offer, white-haired man.

Who would have expected Geralt to come across a camp of Ofieris somewhere on the Redanian frontier? Yet life can be surprising – travelers from a land far across the sea had indeed chosen to pitch their tents in just such a place. The new arrivals had come to gain knowledge and give gifts, but, since life can be unpleasantly surprising as well, they were attacked and robbed by locals. When Geralt heard about this, he felt sorry for the foreigners' loss and decided to help them retrieve their belongings. Malicious types might claim he only did so to get the crafting diagrams he'd been promised as a reward, but I am not among their number and do not believe that for one instant.

After a great deal of searching, the witcher found the stolen diagrams and delivered them to the merchant as agreed. The merchant repaid him with gratitude and copies of the diagrams translated into a tongue local craftsmen could understand.

While wandering the Redanian borderlands Geralt happened across some crafting diagrams written in a foreign tongue. He supposed the language was Ofieri, but, not being a linguist, he could not be certain. Wanting to resolve this mystery, he decided to look around for Ofieris, having made the indisputable deduction that where there are Ofieri documents, there must surely be Ofieris as well.
Look for the place where the Ofieri merchant was attacked.
Use your Witcher Senses to search the site of the attack.
Use your Witcher Senses to follow the bandits' trail.
Search the bandits' hideout.
Find all the diagrams from the Ofieri gear set and return them to the merchant to be duplicated and translated.
Read the letter you found.
Search the remaining bandit camps.
Return the diagrams to the Ofieri merchant.
Wait one day for the merchant to translate the diagrams.
Collect the translated diagrams from the Ofieri merchant.
Find someone who can speak Ofieri.
From Ofier's Distant Shores
Caretaker
Harpy
Know the one 'bout King Wencelas and the golden carp?
Uhhh? Nope, not ringin' a bell.
Heheheheyeah! Oooh, jackass! Hahahaha! Akh-akh! I spilt me drink there, like.
Treasure Chest
Eulalia von Everec

Northeast of Novigrad Geralt stumbled across a small camp of Ofieri travelers. Geralt struck up a conversation with one of their number and the topic of discussion turned to horses. Before he knew it, he'd agreed to a race to test whose mare was the swiftest. Had he been to eager in his boasting? Could Roach really go neck and neck with a fabled Ofieri steed? Time would soon tell!
Roach emerged the victor, and Geralt was able to bask in her glory. The Ofieri merchant took his loss with tremendous grace and awarded the winning horse and rider an excellent saddle.
Defeat the Ofieri merchant in a horse race.
Races: Swift as the Western Winds
Don't provoke me. Never know, might choose to take your head.
You're wounded, tired. Figure my chances are good.
At your service, mate.
Casimir, stand with me. I'll make you my treasurer, your salary in the thousands, mate.
Sorry, Geralt. But coin's coin, no two ways about it.
As I said, at your service, mate.
Hmm, dumb. But have it your way. Let's make this quick, before the soldiers get down here.
Dumb decision. But have it your way.
Give me the damn casket, and let's get out of here.
As you wish. This way.
Oooph. That's a load off my prick!
I could drop you easily. But maybe I don't have to. We could try to figure this out.
A compromise looks unlikely. We both want Max's House.
Not quite. You just need the contents. Me - the box.
They're downstairs!
So be it. Seal it with a handshake.
This is not a bust. We can figure this out.
You tricked me.
And you were prepared to let me face Horst's thugs alone. To my mind, we're even.
Now Max Borsodi's House - if you've absolutely got to have it, you'll need to take it from me by force.
Gents. Gents - keep calm!
Satisfied?
Exceptionally! You?
No. And I won't be until I find Max Borsodi's House. In this vault - or so you said.
And it is. There. But, I fear it's not yours for the takin'.
You see, it houses my father's will. A scroll thanks to which Ewald Borsodi, long missing, will assume the family fortune.
And Geralt of Rivia, who you cheated, what'll he assume?
Alas. But he's free to choose anything else.
All right. I'm willin' to take that.
A consensus was in sight from the start!
Slow down. Witcher hasn't paid yet.
Don't know about that, Geralt. Takes good will to negotiate. Afraid I've none of that for you.
You got to be mad!
Quite the reasonable offer, to my mind.
Your mouth!
Hm… don't know, don't know…
Whoa-hoh! An agreement's in sight!
No. I've no patience for your kind. Full price, and not a copper less!
Overdid it a bit, witcher. Even I'm willin' to admit that.
Aye! See? And you keep your mouth shut!
Hah! Beat your arse good! Heheheh!
Mhh, you should've passed, mate, should've passed.
The price of Quinto's freedom just went up! Twofold!
Hah! No man can match me! Not a fuckin' one! Come on now, witcher - say it!
Ahem. No better fighter than Hans of Cidaris.
Exactly! Couldn't 'ave said it better meself! Now, Quinto - you can still buy the shit's freedom, but the price just went up. Twofold!
Fine. I'll pay.
Pass for me too. Let's total it up. I win.
Heavy-handed, Hans. The Tretogor maneuver - with cards like that?!
Ugh! Get him out of here, before I fuckin' burst a--
Thought you looked wimpy. Didn't expect it to be that easy, though.
Must admit I'm fairly surprised meself.
Your trap! Both of youse! Take him, witcher. And bugger you bo--
All right, let's go. Stone's throw away.
Fine. Let's go.
Need you to open something for me. Something bigger than a cage.
Sounds interestin'. Dyin' to hear the details.
Herbalist's hut near Oxenfurt. Knock on the door, ask for yarrow extract.
Not headed there just yet. Got something to tend to first. Meet you later. Head out of the city, ask for directions. Folk'll know the way.
Sound advice. See you.
Not head there just yet.
Need you to open something. Something bigger than a cage.
Sounds interestin'. Dyin' to hear the details.
Herbalist's hut near Oxenfurt. Knock on the door, ask for yarrow extract.
Hm. Not sure I know where that is. Might you be goin' there? We could go together.
Got a job for you.
Tell you later. Got… got someone else I need to talk to.
I get that. When the time's ripe, look for me at the Academy gate. Come nightfall. Farewell.
Nothing just yet.
Wha--? But, how did y--?
Fishbone. Did it yesterday. I was waitin' for a lull, to slip out. Witcher showed up afore I could.
Let that be my recommendation. Now, do tell, what's it you need me for?
Call it my loss. Here.
Ah, nothin' quite like the weight of a purse full o' gold. Right, Quinto - you're dumb as shite, but lucky as--
My loss. I'll pay.
I'll be back.
Hm. I'll be back.
Pay you later.
So what'll it be? We got a deal or not?
Well, willin' to pay? 'Cause I'm torn, don't know if I should send him to the gallows or wait.
What now? Don't you understand Common? Stay away from the cage!
You Quinto?
The one and only. A pleasure, but who might you be?
Whoa, ho! I'll have no pleasure here! Witcher, keep clear of the cage, right?
First you use threats to extort coin, and now you want to scheme with my prisoner? Not a chance!
What'd he do?
What'd he do to step on your toes?
Ours? Not ours. But he's stuck sticks up a number of bankers' arses. Put a tidy price on his head, they did.
And as Master Hans of Cidaris is an enterprisin' individual, he decided to nab me and claim the reward.
Anyone give you leave to talk?! Shut your trap!
Quinto - can't do without him.
I need Quinto. Alive.
And I need coin. Lots of it.
Lucky thing I don't much care who pays me - you, or the bankers.
Meanin' Master Hans of Cidaris' moral spine is rather bendy.
You'll be the one with the bendy spine in a minute! I said, shut your mouth!
Just as I said, an enterprisin' individual.
And just as I said, clamp it shut! Stop interruptin'!
Where was I? Right. Want me to let him go? Pay up. But I've a special rate for you. You fleeced me, now it's my turn.
Where was I? Right. Want me to let him go? Pay up. Same as the wanted posters say.
How about a game of gwent?
Buy him out? Pretty pedestrian. How about we play a round of cards for Quinto's freedom?
Hmm. Why not. But lose, and the price on his head'll double. You in?
What the hell. I'm game.
Got my fingers crossed!
Yeah, I'll play.
Too risky.
No. Way too risky.
So pay up or piss off. No three ways about it.
You're acting like an old fishwife.
Mh, famous mercenary, supposedly, but you're acting like an old fishwife. Just counting the crowns, counting the crowns.
What? I'll not take any insults from some bloody mutant! I proved my mettle at Hagge, Dillingen, Brenna and--
All long ago and probably only half true. You're bold, sure… with your mouth.
Ooo… That must've hurt, that.
Cheat me out o' coin, then dare insult me?! Take it back, you bastard! Open your gob and take it right back!
What?! Those words! Bark 'em back, you bastard!
Bare fists. Make me take it back. If you fail, you'll let Quinto go. Deal?
Bloody deal! Lads, give us some space. I need to show this drifter what happens when you cross Hans of Cidaris!
Got a better idea. Fight me - for Quinto.
So be it. I take it back.
Calm down, now. Helmet's liable to fall off. I take it back. Satisfied?
I advise you well! Do not rile me again! Now pay up or sod off!
Let's make a deal.
Hans, to claim that reward, you've gotta deliver Quinto to the right hands. Seems a… complication.
Time's a consideration. And we all know time is coin.
Shut it! What's your point, witcher?
Bankers are far away. Whereas I'm here, saving you a lot of trouble. Think you should drop the price.
Hrmph. By how much?
Yes? What was that?
Gods, grant them happiness. My son at the least…
Goodness!
Mother
Calm it down.
Problem, gramps?
Come get me! C'mon!
Smash the arsemunch!
No touchin'. Nothin'.
Get goin'.
Hexin'! Devilry!
Oh, you mother fu--
Circus Hand
Time you took a gander downstairs. Vault's open.
Haaa-ya!
Stop him! He's not to flee!
Locked themselves in!
Bollocks!
Dammit.
Lay down your arms! You have no chance!
Perhaps not.
But we do have hostages.
Mercy, master!
On the count of three, we go in! One! Two!
Aaaarrrrrgh!
Come one step closer and folk will die!
Hold, now! We must negotiate!
What're your demands? To release the hostages!
Buy us a bit o' time, Geralt.
Drink to our health, once you're far away.
Get to work, Quinto. We'll try and hold off the assault.
Get to work, Casimir. We'll try and hold off the assault.
You had your chance! Attaaack!
Still insist on usin' that wooden sword?
I'd gladly go with ye, miss. But I'm afeared I'm a wee bit too bulky. 'Twas a pleasure.
Not about to hide behind these folk. I'm letting them go.
Are you mad? Any idea what'll happen?
Yes. And you have any idea what'll happen if you try to stop me? Out of my way. Now!
An honorable deed. The court's sure to consider it a mitigatin' factor. Now, you've one minute to come out. One at a time. Hands on your heads!
I'm going. Up the chimney and out. It's grown too hot, pure and simple. Best of luck, gentlemen.
Not about to use innocents as living shields.
Pull back from the auction house.
We have one demand. Pull back from the auction house.
You know I cannot do that!
You can! Just not sure you want to. How about I help you decide, kill a hostage?
Just do what they want! I beg you! Aaaargh!
Calm yourself! No one is to be harmed, clear?
Nothing simpler! So long as you take your boys and pull out. We'll all live happily ever after.
I repeat - that is not an option! We must bargain, reach an agreement!
Doesn't matter. Long as it rolls.
We're not picky. Any old cart. Long as it has wheels that roll.
All right. I'll get it done! In exchange, you must release the hostages!
How many?!
All of them!
Take me for a fool? No chance.
You've got to understand. Safety of the hostages is my primary concern.
No, you have to understand! One's got a knife to his neck! A sharp knife!
I was willin' to meet you half way! Instead, I hear threats!
Bloodshed - is that what you want? Have it your way. Attaaaack!
Take me for a fool? No chance.
Give you another chance, Reginald! You got ten minutes to think of a better joke! Don't fuck this up!
Actually kind of funny.
Heh. Actually kind of funny! Make that up yourself?!
No, I--!
Aaargh! For the love of the gods, stop saying "NO!"
Yes! Yes! I made it up meself! All alone!
Got talent, Reginald! Start thinking of your next joke! You got ten minutes.
Good will gesture, now! Letting one hostage go! Then another hostage for every joke you tell me! Deal?!
Deal! Ten minutes!
Ugh. Good work.
Sorry, boys. You'll have to go on without me. I didn't sign on for this turn of events.
Just one way out of here. Through the vault.
There's a second - the chimney. Believe I'll squeeze through.
Doubt you can, witcher. You've no choice, I'm afraid. Let's go. Downstairs.
You know I can't do that! Here's a compromise - one hostage now, the rest once the wagon arrives!
So be it! Agreed!
Thanks be to Melitele!
But anything smells fishy, or you dawdle even a bit, heads will roll, understand?!
Calm, now! You'll hear horses neighin' before a quarter hour's out! Matko! Chedrew! City stables! On the double!
I'll set one free now. The rest later.
Prepared to let us walk away peacefully?!
Officer's word!
All right! So be it! Let them go.
A right shite idea.
I know what I'm doing. Open the damn door.
An honorable deed! And a stupid one. Attaaaack!
Fine. So be it.
See if I can't make this clear! We're not at a food market! No bargains to be made here! Lives are at stake!
I understand, I do, but--!
No "buts!" Gonna count to three! Then heads will roll! One!
Gods have mercy! Just do what he asks!
Y-you leave me no choice!
Two!
Attaaaack!
Told you to pull back.
So we want a wagon. And horses.
It's the middle of the night! Where am I to find a wagon?!
Rather go looking for caskets?
Aaaargh! He means it!
Good point! A wagon, then! What kind?!
Bring us a wagon and horses.
Tell me a joke.
So tell me a joke! Any joke! So long as it's funny!
Excuse me?! This is no--!
Got a tip for you! No charge! Every tip after this will cost you - in the blood of an innocent!
When talking to someone who's holding hostages, never use the words "no," "not," "but," or "maybe!" Understand, Reginald?!
My name's not Reg--!
Aaaaargh! You-- You're not supposed to say "not!"
Huh, see that?! This one gets the idea! And if I want to call you Reginald, I'll call you Reginald! Clear?!
Y-yes! Clear!
Excellent! So lemme hear the joke, Reginald! And believe me - you better hope it makes me laugh!
A l-little elflin' runs up to its m-mother callin', "Poop! Poop!" Sh-she says, "It's o-over there, love, c-cut yourself a slice!"
Pathetic, Reginald! A joke that bad's a damn crime, you know?! And crimes demand punishment!
No, no! Wait!
Aaaargh! You swiving idiot! You're not to say "NO!"
Damn it all. Enough! Attaaack!
Pathetic.
You a racist, Reginald?
You a racist, Reginald?!
No! Not at all. I just--!
Aaaaargh! Don't say "NO!"
Yes! Yes! I'm a racist! I bloody hate elves! Dwarves too!
Carriage that carried Radovid to his coronation. Nothing less.
Radovid's coronation carriage! Nothing less! Drawn by two snow-white mares!
Do you think this situation a jest?!
Do you?!
Aaaargh! No! You're both right! This is no jest!
I want us to reach an agreement! I don't want anyone to get hurt! But you must not ask the impossible!
Second time you're turning me down. Shit negotiation tactic.
It seems negotiation's not my strong suit! Nor is it yours! Attaaack!
Oops. Tipped the scales.
Bravo. Splendid job you did there.
I'm a witcher. Not your negotiator.
Dammit. Explosion triggered that fight. Could've done without both.
That explosion gets us in the vault.
So? Satisfied? Conscience still clear?
Follow my own rules. Couldn't give shit if you approve.
Right. Our paths will diverge soon enough.
In the meantime, the vault awaits. Ought to be open by now.
Where's Eveline?
She's fled. All the better. Fewer hands reachin' out for loot. Come on, before reinforcements arrive.
No fear they'll send more soldiers in?
If your concoction's worth anythin', most're standin' in line to the latrines. Buys us a bit of time, that.
Walthemor Mitty
Alghoul
Clear for now. Knock on wood.
Good. Eyes in the back of your heads, everyone.
Mine are open. I've already seen several things I'd gladly take with me.
Not now. The vault - that's our target. Is that clear?
Not a problem. I'll go right away.
I shall be much obliged!
See you in a minute, Vimme.
Sure. I'll look for your earring.
Time to go, Vimme.
Countess, forgive us. Time we were on our way.
So soon? A great shame. Whatever the reason, I wish you luck on the Path.
Where you headed in such a rush?
To the door. Sooner we finish up here, the better.
Forgive me, Countess. But if there's no monster on the balcony, it's just not something I should bother with.
A pity. But I understand. The Witchers' Code.
Really. You're swine, ye know? Finding an earring - what's that to you?
Ah, Vimme... The countess didn't lose an earring. Her ears aren't even pierced.
That's right! So what's she on ab--?
Don't know, don't want to know. Don't need to get involved in yet other scheme.
Not something I want to bother with.
Does the Countess have her eye on anything particular today?
No. But Horst Borsodi insisted he would put up something that would be of interest.
Did he happen to say what it was?
No. Oh, you know what he's like - a walking enigma.
On another topic… Master Geralt, I was wondering if you'd be willing to help a lady in need?
Depends on the nature of the need.

Oh, it's quite the trifle. I stepped out onto the balcony a moment ago. I dropped an earring while there. I couldn't find it - it must have fallen through the floor boards. Perhaps you, with your cat eyes…?
Got your eye on anything in particular today, Countess?
Where'd you develop this interest in witchers' things?
Mind if I ask how the Countess became interested in us humble monster slayers?
I've some pleasant associations. Dating from my oh so distant youth.
Dinnae ye say such things, Countess! Ye look right fetchin' to me!
That's very kind, Master Vivaldi, but apart from my vedyminaica I also own a number of mirrors.
Your most prized piece - what would it be?
An armor element, an antique. School of the Wolf. From 1234.
Classic! Is it up for sale?
I fear not. It's a memento, one of great sentimental value.
But perhaps the Countess's got other witcher curios she's willin' to part with? Or acquire. Perhaps ye could trade? I'd charge… five percent - a modest, uh, transaction fee.
Vimme, afraid you'll have to finagle your coin out of someone else today.
Thanks, but no thanks.
Sure. Why not.
Vimme, never seen anyone so good at laying their mitts on coin that clinked within earshot. But what the hell… see if we can't make a deal.
Greetings to the honorable Countess! Madame, allow me to introduce my dear friend, Geralt of Rivia.
…witcher of the School of the Wolf.
Forgive me, but have we had the pleasure…?
No. But your guild is unmistakable. Your medallion…
Take note, Geralt. Countess Mignole is an eminent collector of vedyminaica.
Vedymi- what now?
All manner of objects related to the witcherly profession. Swords, gear, medallions.
I'd like to be alone, if you don't mind.
You remind me of one I used to know…
You've my utmost respect, master.
I don't have any good news.
Huh, afraid I have bad news…
Oh!
Please, tell me… did he at least die like a witcher?
No. He died like a hero.
Hhh, there is that…
I thank you for tolerating a decrepit madwoman so elegantly.
Please don't say that.
I am old and I am wealthy. I may say what I please. And now, be so kind and leave me to my thoughts.
Vesemir's fine, the picture of health. And he still wears a mustache.
I'm relieved to hear it. And, hm, did he ever find a… a mate?
No. Haven't seen him with a woman in five decades. Me and the other witchers, we often wondered what his story was.
A pity. A pity our story didn't end differently. I might have… I should have ridden out after him.
Please don't mention me when next you see him. I've reopened my own wounds. That's enough.
Vesemir's fine.
How close were you?
Don't mind at all. But before I answer, I also wouldn't mind knowing how you knew each other.
Oh, I've told no one. Not ever. But I suppose I owe you an explanation.
It was the winter of 1234. A beast prowled the streets of Oxenfurt. A fleder, I believe. A contract was issued, a notice posted, and a witcher appeared. Vesemir. Of the School of the Wolf.
He came through our estate, tracking the beast. Our eyes met, something sparked. I wrote him a message, asked my governess to deliver it.
He visited, under the cover of night, night after night. On one such occasion my father heard something. Vesemir had to flee, so quickly he left behind his gambeson.
Ah! The first piece, the start of your collection.

Yes. But also the end of our love. Father had an arrest warrant issued, then quickly married me off. I was fortunate - my husband died young, leaving me a sizeable fortune. And thus… I have lived on memories.
There's no earring out here, is there?
None.
Maybe the Countess'd care to explain what this is about? All jokes aside?
Forgive me, I-- Gods, this is so embarrassing!
Do--? Do you know Vesemir? He was a tinge shorter than you, wore a mustache…
Do I know him? Man taught me everything I know!
What--? How is he, if you don't mind my asking?
What're you doing in a place like this?
Best shoo before you get hurt.
Shame you can't talk.
What're you doing here?
Step away. Authorized staff only.
Ahem, ahem.
Might I assist you?
Yes. Yes…
Now where did I put that gavel?
I've thirty going thrice, thirty going frice-- No, that can't be right.
Here's what we'll do. I'll go in, then help you sneak in around the back.
How?
Don't know. But I'll figure something out. Usually aren't nearly as many guards on the riverside.
Agreed.
All right. Let me in.
Halt. By order of King Radovid, no one's allowed inside the Academy.
Not even lecturers?
No one means no one.
See you've become quite the stickler, Norbert. You were much kinder when I was patching you up. By the way, how's your knee?
Fine, dandy. As if no arrow ever struck it.
Consider yourself a lucky man. 'Cause if I'd not decided to operate, you'd be a cripple to the end of your days.
Ahem… Bruno?
Eh?
Maybe we ought to let her in? She's a decent lass, not like to steal nothin'.
Hm, all right. But alone. Witcher'll draw too much attention. I'd rather not get shite from the captain on his account.
Fire and blood, life and death.
I summon ye whose blood I have brought.
Fire and blood, life and death.
You have summoned me, stranger. Why?
Name's Geralt. Came to wake the ghost of Vlodimir von Everec.
Who you are and why you've come matter little. For you'll not leave this place alive.
Are you Vlod's ghost?
Who asks after my grandson?
It matters not, Honoratina. What I wonder is how this mortal obtained the family's blood. For von Everecs rise only for von Everec blood.
True. Yet to my knowledge, only one of our line yet lives - Olgierd.
Then we converse with the man who spilt the blood of your grandson, Kestatis.
Mean none of you are Vlodimir? It's Olgierd, his brother, who sent me.
You will meet Vlod soon enough. Yet Olgierd you will never see again.
Kill him, von Everecs!
For Olgierd's blood!
Man in the cage - who's he?
Dope in the cage - who's he?
Why? Look like a monster to you? No? Then he's not your ploughin' concern.
Abner de Navarette
Then let's return their coin to them.
What would you return? We've spent it all! Every last copper!
Well… you could, you know, find more.
Of course, that's your solution! That's always your solution!
Hit it square on.
Not a bad shot with my crossbow. Why not. I'm in.
Splendid! So, shall we begin? Folk have grown nervous.
What? Mean now? No rehearsals?
What's there to rehearse? You're to shoot and hit a target!
Fine. I'll perform with you.
Rather finance the refund.
Fine. I'll pay.
Hm. More, I think. I put it at six hundred at the least.
What? But I checked this morning and-- Aaaa.
Indeed, Meryn's right. Six hundred crowns.
Way too much.
Fine. I'll pay.
We end with an audacious feat by Geralt of Rivia! We thank you for attending and hope to see you soon!
It's a shame that man didn't shoot the elf. That would have been brilliant!
You know, I doubted I'd emerge from that ordeal in one piece. Fine work, Geralt.
Argh! He hit me! The bastard hit me!
Woooooaaah! Brilliant!
Ladies and gentlemen! With that, errr, singular feat we bring our performance to a close! See you all soon!
Gonna live?
Yes, I shall live! Argh… Out of my… sight, imbecile!
Sorry. Told you I'm not a bad shot, not a perfect one.
Oh, don't fret. Vann would miss occasionally, too. I shall patch Meryn up.
Well, one performance down. What of the next?
I'll let you know.
I'll let you know.
Hmm. Very well. I shall be waiting.
Finally, you're back. So, what's it to be… our next performance?
Oh? Back so soon? Well? Will we do it?
Hm. Why not. Let's go.
Why not. Let's go. Now.
Herbalist, has a hut near here. Ring a bell? Go see him and ask for some yarrow extract.
Oo, a mystery. I adore mysteries. Till later, witcher!
Got some other things to tend to.
Got some matters to tend to first. Rather meet you there.
Got a hideout, herbalist's hut near Oxenfurt. Stone's throw away. Ask for extract of yarrow - he'll let you in.
Hm.. Couldn't you just take me there?
Yeah, you're hired. Go see the herbalist.
Fine. I'll pay.
Ho, ho. You must really need my help.
Admit that freely. First off, though, I hate making a fool of myself in front of the rabble.
So, what now? Might we prepare for the other show?
Rather finance the refund.
Give me a minute.
Gimme a minute. Need to prepare.
Know what? Need to think this through.
Well, if you must, you must.
Need to think about it.
Maybe I could refund the tickets, instead?
Hm, maybe I could just give you the coin for the refund? It'd be quicker. How much would that be?
Hmm… let's see. Roundabout four hundred crowns, I believe.
Hm. Way too much.
Hmm… Steep.
So perhaps you'd prefer to help with the show?
The minute we're in trouble, you make me responsible for getting us out. As in Maribor! Remember Maribor?
Dove, please don't change the subject.
Mind if I do?
That depends. Who might you be?
Geralt of Rivia. Witcher. You Eveline Gallo? "The Ermine"?
Only to friends.
Calm down, Meryn, no need to puff up. And you, talk - what do you want?
Rather talk eye to eye.
Eveline conceals nothing from me, and--
And you were to help set up the benches. Immediately.
But--
Very well, once again - what do you want?
I'd prefer to speak to you privately.
Wanted to ask you to work with me.
Got a job for you.
Truly? Of what nature?
Hm. Anonymous performance. No audience. At a certain auction house.
Pay's as much as you can carry.
Eveline, I beg you… You don't know him!
What's that supposed to mean? He introduced himself, did you not hear? Geralt of Rivia.
Stop pretending you don't understand me. You cannot know if he's to be trusted!
Not a soul can be trusted.
Hm. You've none of a fink's features. But you see, I've a problem.
All right, out with it. What's this problem?
All ears. What is it?
Lemme guess - got a monster needs killing?
Lemme guess - there's a monster needs killing.
Somewhere, certainly - but not here. May I finish? Or would you rather keep guessing?

See, we were to do a show. The tickets have all sold. Alas, our friend and colleague, "Hawkeye" Vann… well, he's gone blind. Drank some hooch from a questionable source. A sad story, but not the point.
The crowd awaits. So either we find a replacement for him, or we shall have to return the coin. All good and fine had we not spent it already.
Ah. I think I know where this going.
Then I shall get straight to the point. Stand in for Vann, and I shall help you.
What do I have to do? Jump through some flaming hoops?
No. Shoot your crossbow, hit a target.
Eveline, I'm not certain that's a good idea.
Neither am I. It shall all come out in the wash. So, witcher - what'll it be?
Have you thought it out?
Well? Ready?
All right. Let's start.
All right. Do or die. Let's begin.
That I like! A man who boldly dares, damn the risks! Come!
And now, good folk, the highlight of our program! Standing before you - Geralt of Rivia! Victor of marksmanship contests in Angren, Dol Blathanna and Lobinden!
Wow! Prime!
What? But I--
Shh, Geralt. Grab your crossbow and get to work!
This promises to be very interesting…
When are we to start?
Toley sufferin' fuck.
Hell you want?
Ye tit. Lookin' tae ire me?
Geralt! Slice 'em! Slice the ball bags!
Gonna split yer mug in twain.
Ploughin' smash youse!
The devil incarnate!
He's castin' spells!
Come 'ere, fucker! Come 'ere!
You stink, heathen!
It shall be over soon!
Round and round the mulberry bush…
Here, witcher, witcher!
Blood for blood, brothers!

Geralt needed someone who could scale the glass-smooth wall of the tower abutting the Borsodis' Auction House. One of the few capable of this was Hugo Hoff, alias "Beef Patty" – a halfling with countless break-ins and robberies under his belt. Geralt was told to look for him in Oxenfurt, whose seedy taverns served as watering grounds for students and criminals alike.

Sadly, it turned out Hugo Hoff was in no condition to join Geralt's crew. The halfling must have stepped on some powerful toes, for someone had slapped stone slippers on him and taken him for a long walk off a short pier – and into the Pontar.
Hugo Hoff
I'll tear you to shreds.
I'll ssssuck the life out of you.
Honoratina von Everec
Don't leave me here! Help me!
Help! Geralt, save me!
Gotta look around.
Man you patched up - is he here?
Franz? I don't see him. Think the monster might've dragged him off?
Could have.
Hm. Beast probably crawled in or… out through here.
It's deep.
Lower level of the sewers has been closed off for years. But Vern, the commander, had a skeleton key.
See if I can't find it.
Need to look around.
What exactly happened?
We came in here and Miklas started looking for tracks. Then drowners attacked.
The men made quick work of them, but Franz was injured. His leg. He and I stayed behind, I tried to bandage him up, while Nols stood watch.
Then that beast appeared. Nols pushed me towards the exit and ran at the monster.
I turned around and saw him lying there, covered in a sticky substance. I ran back to get him, then dragged him to where you found us.
Where was the monster?
Miklas and Vern had driven it away from us. And paid dearly for it.
Manage to get a look at what attacked you?
Everything happened so fast. I didn't get a good look, no - only saw it from behind. I know it was large and… slimy.
What exactly happened here?
You friends with them?
Know them well?
Him I met this morning. But Vern and I served together at the Battle of Dorian.
Miklas only enlisted this Yule.
Sorry.
Once you kill this beast, we'll have to send someone down here to collect their bodies. Give them a proper burial.
Soldiers from your escort?
Yes, that's them. Vern, Miklas… poor boys.
Beast doesn't play around, apparently.
They saved my life…
Fresh bruises on the bodies. From a blunt, heavy object.
And no cuts.
Mhm. A few scratches. And everyone's covered in the same strange slime…
Interesting. See that wet spot on the ground?
Mhm. It leads into that channel.
Monster must've come in through there. And left the same way.
Any idea what might've killed them?
Not yet. For now, my bet's on something big. A zeugl, maybe.
Need to find its lair.
Hearts of Stone
Lumberjack
Seven, eight, nine, ten…
Eleven…
Twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, seventeen…
Eighteen, nineteen…
Tenteen…
You mean twenty, idiot. Twenty-one, twenty-two, twenty-three, twenty-four…
Twenty-five…
Twenty-six…
Twenty-seven…
Twenty-eight, twenty-nine, thirty…
Thirty-one, thirty-two, thirty-three…
Thirty-four, thirty-five, thirty-six, thirty-seven…
Thirty-eight, thirty-nine…
Forty, forty-one, forty-two, forty-three, forty-four…
Forty-five…
Forty-six, forty-seven, forty-eight, forty-nine…
Fifty. Ugh…
Fifty-one, fifty-two, fifty-three, fifty-four, fifty-five…
Fifty-six, fifty-seven, fifty-eight, fifty-nine…
And sixty. Sixty-one, sixty-two, sixty-three, sixty-four…
Sixty-five, sixty-six, sixty-seven, sixty-eight, sixty-nine…
And seventy. Seventy-one, seventy-two, seventy-three, seventy-four…
Seventy-five, seventy-six, seventy-seven, seventy-eight…
Seventy-nine, eighty, eighty-one, two, three…
Gads, eighty-fuckin'-four, eighty-fuckin'-five…
Eighty-six…
Eighty-seven…
Eighty-eight…
Eighty-nine, ninety and ninety-one…
Ninety-two, ninety-three, ninety-four…
Ninety-five, ninety-six, ninety-seven…
Ninety-eight. Ninety-nine…
A hundred.
One fucking hundred.
What now?
No fuckin' clue, brother.
Lookin' for trouble, are you?
What's this? Order of the Flaming Rose have a new seat? Not too shabby…
You listen, vagrant. Don't know why you're here, but take my advice - go back to wherever you come from.
So? Why're you still standin' there? I need to smash your pate in?
Wanna fight? Fine by me.
Three.
Don't like your tone, brother.
Odd. See, I thought I was bein' polite. But if courtesy don't work, we'll try somethin' else.
Don't like your tone. Change it.
I was never here.
See ya.
What's inside?
Wondering what you got inside. 'Cause it reeks of fisstech to me. Mind if I have a look… brethren?
Aye, we'd mind. Very much so.
Enough o' these games. I'm countin' to three and you're gonna be gone when I'm done, got it? One. Two.
How would you like to count to a larger number? Using Novigrad crowns. That strike your fancy?
Well… yeah, what do I care? Go on in.
Easy. Let's talk this out.
Out of my way, dimwits.
Got a better idea. You're all gonna count to a hundred. Got it?
Three, four, five, six…
Great start. Now step aside.
Errrr…
Lippy fucker! Get him!
Uhhh…
Circus Worker

As is often the case in life, Eveline was willing to help, but only in exchange for a favor: the witcher had to save her circus troupe from humiliation. He duly performed the required feat, and the limber elfess then joined the break-in crew.

Eveline Gallo performed as tasked and guided Geralt and his accomplices into the auction house. Yet as soon as the heist stopped going according to plan and Redanian soldiers surrounded the auction house, she shimmied up and out the chimney and was never seen by Geralt again.

To rob a vault, one must force open armor-plated doors and secret away mounds of loot. First and foremost, however, one needs to get inside the building containing said vault. To accomplish this, Geralt could use the help of a certain Eveline Gallo – a circus performer famed through all the North, and who, it seemed, used her considerable talents for less law-abiding purposes as well...
Eveline Gallo
Had enough, lordlin'?
That'll teach you to woo and dupe decent maids. Got my eye on you.
Nesky! Let's go!
Listen. Tongue and fists on a leash from now on. Have your fun, but don't beat the wedding guests. With my hands.
Fine. I shall try.
Uh-oh, Shani approaches. Unlikely to be happy, eh?
You made this mess, you do the explaining.
Oh, all right…
Your methods - quite unusual. To woo a woman by beating up her brothers - creative. Wonder what else you have up your sleeve.
All went according to plan.
Eliminating potential obstacles, see - all part of my plan. Usually, I take a few passing blows in the doing, and the young miss in question then swoons with pity, tends to my wounds…
So what went wrong?
It's this damned malformed body. All sinews. And this mug… were I to wear my own, oh, 'twould be another story altogether.
The maidens always fell for my melancholy eyes and the swagger in my scars… but I'll gladly try again, just indicate a lass and--
I can demonstrate if you'd like…
My dear girl, what don't I have up my sleeve! I'd gladly demonstrate… perhaps behind the barn?
I think you've demonstrated enough. Let's just enjoy ourselves, all right? You don't have all that much time left.
Your wish is my command, m'lady. I'd never deny a maid so fair-featured. Off we go.
Time for the capping. We need to get to the barn.
Go. I require a last hurrah.
All the guests must be present for the capping. That includes you.
You've proven everything amply. Let's just have fun, all right? After all, you haven't much time left.
Ehh, fine, I suppose you're right. Come, then.
A hazard of the trade, my love. I'm clearly a bit out of practice.
But point out the next young miss, and I will gladly prove I--
I'm out of practice.
Where to, my love? I was to turn you into a lady!
Geralt, you must explain I was not at fault. They lunged at me. Well? Go on, chase her!
In your dreams.
There it is. You fucked up. She's gone. Is that how you woo the ladies?
You always that charming in life?
It worked more often than not.
Had enough, peasant spawn? Thought yourself a match for a von Everec -- I mean, a witcher?
Away with you, begone! I've tired of looking at your slackjawed yaps!
Feel foolish, peasants? Learned a lesson from your better. Are the pigs penned? Indeed they are!
What's wrong, witcher? Swineherd's Dash no longer interest you?
We're to leave the sty? I thought you liked these gritty, manly games.
Vlodimir von Everec never gives up! I'll try again - that crown shall be mine!
I shall try again.
I've had enough of these swine.
Had enough of this swiving swining. Pigs are best as pork on your plate.
Come away with me, Shani.
See that? Bloke thinks our sport ain't good enough for him.
Be singin' a different tune if he'd been any good at it.
Right y'are. Like my pa always said, "When shite can't swim, it blames the runny water."
Forgive me, Shani. I've let you down.
Are you worried about that pig? You needn't be…
We're here as a couple, I wanted to win you that… that thing…
Really, it's unimportant, nothing at all.
I'm on the prowl - that's clear. I woo and woo, yet you do not succumb. So I can't help but wonder - what am I doing wrong?
Now who have we here?
Do I know you?
That's the crux of it - we've not met. I've had to endure half a lifetime without you.
An entire lifetime, more like.
A moment, my dear.
Do not sabotage me, Shani. That would not be fair.
Fine, fine. I'll stay out of your way.
Did it hurt when you fell from the heavens?
Did it hurt terribly, my sweet?
What?
When you fell from the heavens.
Oh, hahaha. Why, sir, I-- Haha…
Shh, my dear. No more words.
Forgive me, I didn't know.
Easy, lads. No harm done. An innocent conversation with an innocent miss. The kind weddings are for.
We all heard your innocent talk. Wanted to draw her to the barn. What were you gonna do there? Talk some more?
Naturally, we would speak, but first we would dance. Now tell me, what sort of fool wouldn't want to dance with a beauty like her?
Find another beauty! Or I'll dance with you meself - just after I grab me a fence post!
Geralt, you saw it - I tried to resolve this peacefully, but they wish to fight. Suits me just fine - sounds like wonderful fun. Fence boards right over there for the taking.
Fear eat your stones?
That's the last ploughing straw. No one accuses Vlodimir von Everec of cowardice!
Calm down, boys. Don't wanna fight you.
Too damn bad. 'Cause we're gonna tan your mutant-freak hide!
That does it. Rraa, hy-ah!
Show us what you got!
Hot damn, boy! You needn't ask me twice!
You shan't keep me from anything, filthy hayseed.
Lads… mutant's callin' us names.
Stand down, swineherds. Or lord witcher will give you a bloody mighty drubbing. Now where's a ploughing fence board when you need it?!
You'll do nothing of the sort, bumpkin.
I shall make a true lady of you. Arm in arm, we'll grace the finest salons.
Salons? But, really? Actual salons? In Novigrad? And how…?
In Novigrad, Oxenfurt, why, in Kovir as well! Wherever you wish. Let's make haste to the barn. There everything will be made clear.
Nesky, step away from the man.
Who the devils are you?
We're the miss' brothers. And we swore to our da on his dyin' day we'd keep those of your ilk far from her.
Ahem, my sweet, you are no mere maid, but a marvel of nature! And now, at last, fate knocks at your door!
But I… well… don't know, rightly…
You needn't know anything. I know it all for us both.
My dear girl, you are a miracle.
Hm. Perhaps you're just not my type. Considered that?
Rubbish! I'm every lass' type.
Is that so? Prove it.
With pleasure! Show me a lass, and I'll have her eating out of my hand in the blink of an eye!
That one. With the garland.
Splendid choice! Now observe as Vlodimir von Everec does his thing.
I'm on the prowl - that's clear. In Geralt's name and flesh, of course, but still. Yet the more I woo you, the less you seem ready to succumb. So I ask myself - what am I missing?
Hmm, tell me, Shani - what's the key with you?
What do you mean?
How does my heart's captor like the, uh… prize... I won for her?
The rag-stuffed piggy? It's lovely, truly. I've always dreamed of owning one.
Master witcher, we ain't seen such pig-chasin' skill in a long time.
Your family had an ample pen, didn't they? Go on, admit it.
My family had many pens. But that in no way means I had any practice chasing pigs.
However it were, the crown's goin' to a good man!
And the king's chosen maid deserves a fitting favor. Here.
Just don't go hidin' it in some pouch. Brandish it on your horse, so that all folk may see!
What do you say to that, Shani? Ever witness such agility?
You're clearly a natural at chasing pigs through muck. You were a joy to watch.
Whoa, master witcher. What were the trickery back there, the fancy finger twistin'?
I know. Seen that afore. Witcher told a lad to go hang himself. Drew some flowers in the air with his hand, and the man lost his mind.
Meanin' you cheated. And shan't be crowned King o' the Swineherds.
Shani? What is it Geralt says in these situations? "Dammit"?
Yes, that's it.
Dammit!
Now for what I say - go shove rakes up your arses, you peasant curs!
Do I look anything like a swineherd? Come, Shani. I've had enough of these hayseeds…
Damned cretin creamed me. Embarrassing to take a licking from a boor.
And with a maiden watching…
Fence boards! The perfect weapon for sweaty-arsed swineherds!
Perfect fit for your gob, you ploughin' gentle-fuck!
Never in my life have I reveled so fiercely! Step up, who else wants a shave?!
Ahh, so good to shake the kinks from one's bones.
We must find more, more fun.
Gotta be her… Dammit.
You wished to see her - here she is.
A man should frame his wishes carefully. It forestalls disappointment.
This some sick joke? Why didn't you tell me she was dead right away?
You didn't ask.
Ugh… And why hasn't anyone buried her?
We can't. As for the Caretaker, the one you cut down, while still alive she ordered him to stay away from her for all time.
Iris' wrath - what was it born of?
Her ghost's restless, angry. Attacks intruders. Know why?
Lady von Everec has endured much hardship. She's unaccustomed to guests and not fond of strange folk.
She can't hear us.
Why are you helping me?
The deeper I get into this, the more I gotta wonder… why're you even helping me?
We were summoned to serve Iris von Everec. Our mistress died, but that did not free us from her service.
Got it. You wanna leave this place… leave these bodies.
Surprised?
No. Not at all.
Seems I gotta speak to Iris' ghost.
It's no easy task to contact the mistress. Rage and bitterness fill her.
Got my ways. To make contact with Iris, I gotta bury her body. But that Caretaker's macabre little cemetery won't do. Too much blood, too much fear.
She spent much time in the front garden…
Hm. Maybe there.
Wait. Take this key. It opens the front door.
Good dog.
Need to talk to Iris' ghost.
How did she die?
How did she die? Don't see any wounds, evidence of a fight.
Her heart burst.
Meaning what? A heart attack?
No. It simply burst.
Find that hard to believe.
Yet that's precisely what happened. One day Iris locked the front door, lay down here and… died. From grief, from loneliness.
Bedchamber… Iris was supposed to be here…
This place seems suitable…
Yes. She loved to paint.
Did Iris von Everec have any last requests? Say how she wanted her remains disposed of?
She feared death. Worried none would see to her burial or say a kind word in parting.
Guess I'll be the one to do that.
Can't say much about Iris von Everec. But I do know I like her paintings.
It's a shame her art couldn't bring her greater comfort.
Iris von Everec was a talented painter…
I didn't know Iris von Everec, but the paintings here show amply that she and Olgierd were a loving couple.
Iris must've been happy, once.
Iris was Olgierd von Everec's wife…
I didn't know Iris von Everec…
I didn't know Iris von Everec, so I can't say much about her.
Fate had it a stranger now lays her remains in the grave.
At times fate muddles our path, and life turns toilsome, hard to bear.
Yet all deserve respite and peace in death.
[Place her sketchpad on the grave.]
Your name's inscribed in this sketchbook.
Perhaps you'd like it to be buried with you.
[Place the painting of Iris and Olgierd on the grave.]
I don't know if you want to be buried with a painting of your husband.
But you lived together, so maybe you want to be with him in death as well.
[Place the ornamented hairbrush on the grave.]
I can't be sure this brush was yours.
But if you liked pretty trinkets, you might not mind this one lying at your side.
The remains are interred. Let's summon her.
Tormented spirit! I've laid your bones to rest! Forget your wrath, forget your grief! Show yourself!
Forgive me for tearing you from your realm. I need to ask you…
Should I follow you? All right.
Let's try to summon her.
You two got anything to add?
You two - got any last words for your mistress?
We don't partake in human rituals.
Trusting that what you've done is in keeping with your customs.
You know the master of the house, the owner?
Olgierd von Everec? Yes, we know him. But he left, and his wife became mistress of the house.
Great. So, Lady von Everec home? Could you announce me, say she has a guest?
Why do you wish to see her?
I'm here to get the violet rose Olgierd gave Iris just before he left.
Iris is inside. In the bedchamber upstairs. Take his key… it opens the rear door.
Guess I'll make my own introductions.
Looking for a violet rose.
What about this thing? What can you tell me? Friend of yours?
We called him the Caretaker.
Doesn't look like any creature I've ever seen. Where'd it come from?
From very far away. He was summoned to guard Lady Iris and the home. He tended the garden, took care of unwanted guests.
Very far away - meaning where, exactly?
The name of this place would mean naught to you.
The creature - what was it?
You two are a little mysterious.
What's with the show? The pretense that you're animals. You couldn't have warned me?
No. We're obliged to maintain discretion.
So why talk to me at all?
Why…? Well, we get so few chances to talk to humans. And we're curious to know what brought you.
Gonna need a better answer than that.
Later.
What the fuck was that?
No eyes or nostrils, deformed organs… Damn thing had no right to be alive.
Well… philosophers do still debate what it means to be "alive," exactly.
Normally, I'd be shocked, but… not after what I just saw. Who are you two?
Clearly not animals. Think of us as… friends of the house.
She liked to sit here. But this is not a good place for a grave.
Too close to the house.
I'll keep searching.
Iris von Everec adored flowers.
But she would never want to destroy them.
Hm, all right. I'll dig the grave somewhere else.
Hey, witcher! How 'bout joinin' our band?
What a pickle…
You've seen war, mate. And it shows.
Rein her in, squire!
Grub and hooch - life in a nutshell.
You all right, friend?
Tosser!
What demon?
What demon?
Feigned ignorance? Hmph. Please. You know.
Gaunter O'Dimm… Evil incarnate.
He didn't send me, but he is why I'm here.
Thanks. Helped me a lot.
Good. Very good. Ah, to feel useful after so many years locked up, living in fear - why, it's pleasance itself.
Thanks for your help.
How can I get rid of this mark?
O'Dimm left a mark on my face. Any way to get it off?
A mark? No mention in the tomes… Strange… Unless… unless it will disappear once your pact is fulfilled.
If I challenge him, end the pact that way - will it go away?
That I do not know. The one man who's succeeded bore no mark.
Why was Olgierd out to get rid of O'Dimm? He'd gotten what he wanted.
Had he? Hmph. His heart had turned cold as ice. His feelings for his wife, for whom he'd sacrificed his brother, had withered. He'd lost all he'd loved. Had he wanted any of this?
No. O'Dimm grants what you wish, not what you want. All who sign a pact learn the difference - and die by it.
All? No way to get rid of him?
Kill him, you mean? Kill Evil? Hmph. No. Yet the annals tell of a man who dissolved his pact - by defeating O'Dimm at his own game.
Meaning?

O'Dimm wields contracts, word-traps, duels of wits. Challenge him to such a duel. He'll agree - and can be beaten. But remember, there is only ever one stake. The sole thing he truly desires - human souls.
Olgierd wanted to break his pact. Why?
Olgierd tell you all that?
He had to. How else was I to diagnose his case?
Make it sound like an illness.
It is worse. Many illnesses are treatable, but play with evil… and medicine can be much harder to find.
You know all this from Olgierd?
Vlodimir - did Olgierd kill him?
So, did Olgierd kill his own brother?
No, no, no… Deduce, witcher. O'Dimm acts directly or indirectly? Hm? Olgierd merely signed the blood letter, the next day his brother was dead…
Olgierd sign one of these pacts with him?
Brilliant deduction. But have you guessed why? You must know he came from a wealthy, influential line. He must have if the family of his betrothed accepted him.
Yet did you know his fortunes soured? He himself became an outcast, impoverished. Iris' family, a powerful house, could not accept this, would not marry their daughter to a nobody.
Olgierd wished to elope - the further away, the better. Yet Iris refused to cut her family ties.
Quite the predicament.
Indeed. Their luck turned yet darker when a wandering witch mentioned a solution - a man who would grant any wish. His name - Master Mirror.
The rest follows naturally. Olgierd and O'Dimm - a meeting at a crossroads, a wish, a pact signed in blood, and a price to be paid.
Olgierd was to sacrifice one he loved… O'Dimm delights in difficult choices. He knew Olgierd loved two in this world - his betrothed, and his brother, Vlodimir…
Olgierd chose, and soon thereafter married his beloved Iris, his fortune restored…
Olgierd make one of these pacts with him?
Know anything else about the man?
Gaunter O'Dimm is no man! He is Evil! Evil which assumes various forms. Forget about him, or die.
You're alive.
Alive… yet I live in constant fear born of what I've learned about him.
What else do you know about him?
Magic circle on the floor - what's that about?
What's with the surroundings? These runes - what do they mean?
They protect me. Here, Evil cannot touch me.
How do you know?
He told me himself. Paid me a visit once. A fascinating meeting that was. I was blind already but saw him clearly. He smiled at me.
Said he was honored I'd taken such an interest in him. He wished to thank me and explained he'd taken a similar interest in me.
He drew the circle and said I'd be safe within it. His way of "repaying" me, you see…
Ever tried to leave it?
If you'd heard how he said it, you'd be as certain as I am what leaving would bring.
Came here 'cause I need information. Think you might be the only man who has it.
Hm, a witcher. Then it follows I needn't fear. I'm hardly a post-Conjunction creature.
What did Olgierd von Everec want from you?
I curse the day I first set eyes upon the man!
He appeared at my doorstep one day, offering a sack of gold were I only to find out who Gaunter O'Dimm is, and how to get rid of him.
I agreed. Such matters are my speciality. And I needed the coin. I pored over countless tomes, delved into obscure incidents and analyzed folk legends.
I went so far as to travel to Nilfgaard, the library there, where at last I hit upon the mysterious entity's trail.

There are records of encounters dating back thousands of years, in many cultures, under many names. But always as Evil incarnate. In this land we call him Gaunter O'Dimm. At times, Master Mirror, or the Man of Glass.
In deciphering the ancient scrawlings I went blind. Yet I learned a great deal. For example, that he plays with his victims. And thrives on pacts above all else.
Seemingly harmless contracts which drive their parties to madness.
Came to talk.
You a prisoner here?
Why are there guards outside your door? You a prisoner?
Protective custody, that's the phrase. Protective, hmph! When I cannot decide my own fate, cannot breathe without their permission.
What do they want from you?
You may not be aware, but I am one of the foremost experts on the occult. Living experts, that is. My mentor was the outstanding Professor Lionel van--
And you're cooperating with the witch hunters now?

Cooperating, hmph! As if I had a choice. They're ignorant, but not enough to ignore what I know about magic, witches, sorceresses, what have you. Knowledge they use for barbaric ends, but that's beyond my control.
I'm a witcher.
Hm, a mutant? Hm, hm… Yeah… could be…
No one sent me.
You lie. I may be blind, but I sense unclean powers better than anyone. Why do you think the witch hunters guard me like a treasure?
No one sent me.
Franco? Is that you? Leave the bedpan in the usual spot.
And take the platter, I shan't be eating today.
Professor Shakeslock?
Who the blazes--?! How'd you get in?! Get out! I know nothing. Don't wish to know anything. Understand?! No, no, no - out!
Not gonna hurt you.
That demon sent you. I'm sure of it!
Poor wretch…
What do they call you?
Geralt of Rivia.
Bit of advice, Geralt of Rivia. Once you meet Olgierd, try and pique his interest.
I gotta pique his interest? He's the one wants a monster dead.
Aye - but he don't need you to kill it.
So, you want this job, you gotta grab his attention. And he's one to get bored mighty quick.
Gotcha.
Ouw se on coq é coq là sé rwa an lè pil fimié ay.
Shen ggonia monerie, ara scdebi.
Man amaran nai. Nir sauyn fala fashtama azdahznan.
Begone. You've lost.
Gggrrrraaaaaggghhhhhaaaarrrr!

In a certain cellar located near a nest of drowners, Geralt found a body. Quite curiously, the deceased had not been torn apart by the monsters, but seemed to have died of thirst, having been barricaded in the cellar by some third party. Near the body Geralt found a key and some notes, all of which he took with him.
Geralt had found his fair share of hidden treasure before, so he found the chest without too much difficulty and took its contents for himself.
From the notes Geralt learned about a treasure hidden in a locked chest on a ship. He suspected the key to that chest was the very one he had found by the body.
Find the sunken ship using your Witcher Senses.
Read Brother Anselm's letter.
The Sword, Famine and Perfidy
Think I placed it wrong.
A scrap of paper… Part of a document?
And one more …
And another …
Another piece…
Another one …
No. Something's wrong…
So this is when he started smoking…
Iris' father was holding the document. Gotta put the pieces in his hand.
So that's how he whiled away the long winter evenings…
Furthermore, it is agreed that Iris shall be accorded the respect she is owed, that you shall heed her counsel and requests, and--
Get to the point, father. My patience runs thin.
Gladly. On Iris' request, I declare this marriage null and void.
You vowed to remain with me "till death do us part."
And I've held to my vow. The Olgierd I married is no more.
Breaking a word once given does not come that easy. Believe me.
You shall stay here. Forever.
Enough! You will not command us, you will--
Father! Father! Nooo!!
Servants! Take this carcass and feed it to the beasts!
Hmm… Nope.
Olgierd, Iris… and her father?
Drained… to the last drop.
Not quite. Memory's still incomplete.
Hmm… a marriage contract between Iris and Olgierd…
Her father must've been holding the contract…
So that's how he whiled away the long winter evenings…
A knife… covered in blood. Guess Olgierd got the scars on his shoulders that winter…
A beer tankard… but there was vodka in it.
Tools're so organized it's scary.
Looks like someone cleaned it. Recently.
Fresh manure.
A grave? Here?
Someone dragged a wounded man through here.
Prints from cleated boots. Leading from the back of the garden.
Rope looks new, bucket's been repaired.
Seeds and bulbs. Someone's still planting flowers.
Another intruder buried by the caretaker.
A lock pick? Must've been the other thief's…
Thug
Well, here's where our Paths part.
Shut up.
Was I that bad?
No. But you came awfully close, Ewald. Survived by a hair.
You ever have a basilisk hide or fiend horns and want a good price? Look for me at the auction house!
Mhm. Consider it noted.
Take care, Casimir. Here's hoping Euphemia sees the light, comes back.
Och, plough her moods and ires. With the gold I've got, "love" just ain't nothin' I need.
Heheh. In that case, you and your coin purse live happily ever after.
Pretty sprawling, this estate.
How'm I gonna find that rose in this fog?
Somebody's still taking care of the place.
Gardener's hut. Could it be…?
No violet rose here. Maybe somewhere out back.
Mhm?
Greetings, greetings.
Whoa now!
Princess
Quinto
Where'd you get the rope?
Long story.
But we've done well. Professor Shakeslock's house is at the end of this street.
Witch hunters guard the door. Doubt I'll be able to sweet talk them.
Been a huge help already, Shani. Thanks.
It was nothing, really. You'd have done the same for me.
If you wish to see me again before I go, I'll be at home. Packing'll take some time yet.
All right. Be seeing you.
Geralt! Psst! Are you there?
Yeah, I'm here.
Grab the line!
Geralt! Coming or not?
Yeah, hold on.
Vimme, listen. Forgot to ask you - how's this auction going to work?
They'll bring out three lots to start with. Once they've sold - or not - there'll be an intermission. Horst Borsodi'll probably appear then. That's when I'll introduce youse.
Counting on it.
In the meantime, have ye got a budget? Ye prepared to bid?
O' course, pal! And at a very favorable rate of interest! Just one crown on ten when ye pay me back.
Here. Ought to do you for a bit of dafferie. Happy huntin' to ye!
Hmm, if you think you can spot me a couple hundred…
If you can spot me a couple hundred.
Esteemed ladies and gentlemen! Welcome back! I hereby open the auction!
[Do not bid.]
[Do not bid.]
Going once! Twice! Going thrice!
The honorable Yaromir enters a bid of three hundred! Any advance on three? Three hundred going--
Countess Mignole at three fifty! Going once! Twice!
Lot number one, the mysterious brass figurine - sold! To Countess Mignole!
Yes, the gentleman with the cat eyes. At twenty! Do I hear thirty?
Twenty going once, going twice, going thrice…
[Do not bid.]
Good folk, is no one tempted? Atypical in style, true, but worthy of the vestibule, surely!
Do I hear ten crowns? A mere ten?
Ah! At last, a buyer! Ten crowns once… twice… and going thrice!
Lot number two, "Starry Night Over the Pontar" - sold to Master Yaromir!
Thank ye for the tip, Geralt.
Yes! The banker Vivaldi bids twenty crowns. Going once. Going twice.
[Do not bid.]
[Do not bid.]
Sold! "Starry Night Over the Pontar" by van Rogh to a proud new owner - the king of Novigrad financiers, Vimme Vivaldi!
[Do not bid.]
Brilliant! With the gentleman with the white hair now at three hundred and fifty!
What? I didn't--
Three-fifty once!
Three hundred fifty twice! And three--
Four! Four hundred now with Countess Mignole! Any advance on that?!
Going once, twice, thrice… and sold! The Professor's spectacles go to the countess!
Lot number one.
Five hundred going twice! Going thrice! Sold!
Do I see three hundred? Who will give me three? Ah! Three hundred from the monocled gentleman!
I congratulate you on your successful acquisitions and invite you to partake of the refreshments during the intermission.
So how goes it, Geralt? Didnae find it irksome, I hope?
Course I did. As always with sophisticated company. But, it was about what I expected, so…
Geralt, I hope that painting's no source of grief. Quite the opportunity, that.
Mhm. Couldn't pass it up.
Oh, the excitement! With the three lots behind us, we'll go to an intermission. Amenities abound, please partake. We'll resume shortly.
Incredible! With the white-haired gentlemen now, good folk, at three hundred and fifty crowns!
A generous offer, indeed. Any advance? Three fifty going once, going twice…
Sold! Invaluable spectacles to the white-haired gentleman! Exceedingly glad they'll be useful, may they serve you well, sir!
[Bid.]
Lot number three, ladies and gentlemen - a true rarity, scarce as hens' teeth!
Spectacles, a frame of gold, mountain crystal lenses polished by the tiny dextrous hands of the gnome masters. Once the property of the famed hired assassin known as the Professor!
Starting price of two hundred crowns! Anyone tempted?
Gwent maestro Hilbert offers an advance of fifty! Do I have three--
My! Haven't we livened up! Three hundred from Yaromir Ivanovitz Zaytsev! Going once! Twice!
Sold! Van Rogh's "Starry Night Over the Pontar" to the gentleman with the cat eyes!
Oh! We've a right bidding war here! Sixty! The excitement! An advance on sixty?!
Sixty going once!
Sixty going twice!
Och, all yours, Geralt.
[Bid.]
Aha! The white-haired gentleman bids forty! Who will bid more?
Forty once! Forty twice!
Vivaldi the banker's not about to give up easily. Fifty! Any advance on fifty?
Fifty going once! Going twice! Last chance, ladies and gentlemen…
