[Bid.]
Oh! We've a bidder, cat-eyed no less! At twenty! Do I hear thirty?
Forgive me, Geralt, but business is business.
Thirty! From Vimme Vivaldi! Do I see forty anywhere?
Thirty going once, going twice…
[Bid.]
Proceeding now to lot number two. A canvas by the young Novigrad artist van Rogh, "Starry Night Over the Pontar." Charming piece. Truly a bargain at… twenty crowns.
Ladies and gentlemen, twenty crowns! It's practically naught!
My, my! This is lively! I've three hundred! Going once!
Going twice! Do we have three fifty?
Three hundred thrice! And sold to the white-haired fellow! Lot number one, the mysterious brass figurine!
[Bid.]
The white-haired gentleman enters a bid of two hundred! Do we have two fifty?
Two hundred once! Twice! Thri--!
Splendid! Countess Mignole bids two hundred and fifty! Do I hear three hundred?
[Bid.]

Ladies and gentlemen! Lot number one is a brass figurine from the collection of the infamous Count Romilly. Rumor has it the figure harbors a treasure inside. A rumor one may prove or disprove solely by destroying the beautiful bauble itself.
Starting price - quite the bargain at fifty crowns. Any advance?
With Master Hilbert at one hundred!
To Countess Mignole now at one hundred and fifty. Do I hear two hundred? Might I have an advance?
Monster hunting doesn't pay all that well. Think I'll let you wealthy folk play. I'll wait in the back.
Och, Geralt. You and yer saggin' coin pouch. A financial advisor, that's what ye need.
Finances - that's actually what I'm lacking. Don't worry about me, go. I'll see if there's any caviar left.
Nah. I'll wait in the back.
Course I will.
Course I will. Went to the trouble to sneak me in here, I'd be an ass not take a stab.
Hah! I knew the bug'd get ye!
Greetings, ladies, gentlemen, and the rest.
We've an exceptional auction ahead, dear folk.
Och, Geralt, look! Horst Borsodi. Come on afore some other cocksuckers steal him. Just-- Well, don't expect a warm welcome.
Greetin's, Horst! Allow me to introduce a dear friend and associate - Geralt of Rivia, who--
…comes uninvited.
Exactly, pretty serious oversight. I see no reason why the faux pas should taint our new-found acquaintance.
Acquaintance? I honestly don't know what you think this is, vagrant.
Exactly! Serious oversight.
But you've gained by my presence. Dropped a hefty pile of crowns here.
I'm not like Vivaldi. Profit alone only goes so far for me. I seek more. The auction house is primarily a meeting place for the local elite.
I needn't tell you an itinerant mutant doesn't quite fit in.
That may be so, but you gained by my presence.
Forgot my manners.
Forgot my manners. Forgive me. The teachings at Kaer Morhen, well, etiquette wasn't high on the list. Scandalous.
Mhm. That's plain to see.
Eheheh-eh, got the distinct impression the two of youse started off on the wrong foot. Perhaps we should raise a toast to--
What's one like you want from one like me?
From Olgierd von Everec.
From Olgierd von Everec. Name mean anything to you?
It does.
Guards! Escort the witcher out! And he's not to enter, not alone, not hand in hand with Hierarch Hemmelfart!
Honestly, he asked a question, it were a simple inquiry.
One more word and I shall move my accounts to the competition.
Sorry, mate, but…
No reason to trouble the guards, Horst. I'll go willingly.
I don't recall giving you a choice in the matter. Kick his swiving mutated arse out!
Doesn't matter. Willing to tell me what it is, or not?
Doesn't matter.
Right, let's dispense with the niceties. Maximilian Borsodi's House - gotta lay my hands on it, whatever it--
What?! Where did you learn of it?!
Gentlemen! No reason to lose our composure, raise our voices, heh.
I ask you - where did you learn of it?!
Whoa. Come on, now--
Where?!
Need to find Maximilian Borsodi's House.
This isn't working for me. There another Borsodi I could talk to?
The Borsodis' Auction House - I'm assuming the name's no coincidence. Got a relative I could talk to? Someone - how do I say this - a smidgen less irritating?
Haha, ahem. Name's a historical legacy, Geralt. Auction house was founded by two brothers, Horst's father and an uncle. In this generation--
I and only I am it. So get to the point. Now.
Esteemed ladies, gentlemen! Kindly take your places, the auction will begin shortly!
Och! At last. Come to the fore with me. I won't see nowt otherwise.
Och, Geralt. It's nothin' personal, but I've this principle, got to have it. I dinnae extend additional loans to existin' debtors. You still owe me two hundred crowns, remember?
Hm. Yeah, that.
But, ye'll bid anyhow, won't ye? If only for sport?
Hired me to find out what happened to Folkert. Never mentioned murder.
But one will happen, soon. You want naught to do with it, that is your right. But I aim to round up folk who still give a damn.
It's a couple of old folks. Doubt they'll put up a fight.
All the better. Now, I wager you want your coin, eh? Take it. And get out of my sight.
Had an accident.
Ran into trouble, a freak event.
Of what type? Did monsters attack him?
Mhm. Could say that.
Found some witnesses. Claim wolves attacked him. He survived at first, then went back in the woods to harvest more herbs… His luck ran out.
Ah… A treasure, that lad - dutiful, mannered. Such a shame. Well, here's your gold. I trust it will serve you well.
I did.
He's been avenged - there's that. Eh, your coin. Take it and… and now please be on your way. I must write to Folkert's parents.
He was-- Agh, really no gentle way to put this. Cannibals ate him.
Cannibals? A short ride from Novigrad? In Velen, that would be one thing, but… but here? Gods!
You slew them, right? Tell me you killed them!
Cannibals ate him.
Know what happened to Folkert.
Folkert, your apprentice - I know what happened to him.
Out with it! I've gone near daft with worry!
Monster deck, usually.
Frankly, I usually play my monsters.
A witcher who plays monsters? Hm, interesting.
Prefer the Northern Realms.
Not a bad deck, Nilfgaard, but… I'll take the Northern Realms over it any day.
Ah, understood. A patriot!
Scoia'tael - that's what I favor.
Crap guess. Scoia'tael's my favorite.
Right, right. A solid knock to your foe - nothing like it, eh?
So be it.
Well, you did help with the guards at the door… All right. Ten percent of any winnings is yours.
Any chance for fifteen?
Don't push it, Vimme.
All right. Game on.
Awfully resourceful of you, Vimme. I'm impressed. Gotta refuse, all the same. No offence.
Dinnae make a fuss now. I'm a dwarf and a banker, so I've doubly thick skin. Good luck to ye!
No chance.
Hm. Suppose it's not whether you win or lose… Sure, I'm game.
Brilliant! I'll lay my cards out.
Naturally. Geralt… might I have a wee word?
What is it?
Well, mate… seein' as I brought youse together, I do believe I'm owed a share of your winnings, if there are any. Ten percent? A finder's fee o' sorts, ye ken?
Mhm. Pretty clear now why you wanted us to meet.
One cardinal bit I've learnt in my trade, friend - coin dinnae stink. So, what'll it be?
Why not.
Sorry. Another time, maybe.
Hm. It is what it is. I'm off for a nosh. By the by, watch those little black balls. Strange, them.
Agh, to spurn the caviar of the Koviri sturgeon! They're castin' pearls before swine!
Come, Geralt. Let's have a blether with another.
Maybe another time.
Hm. We got a minute afore the auction starts, so… nudge nudge wink wink - maybe a round?
Skinned me of my prime card, he did, imagine that! One you gave me as collateral a time back!
I've heard. Tourney at the Passiflora. Sat in on that, didn't you?
Mhm. Pretty special as events go.
That were nothin'!
You ought to know, Hilbert - Geralt here's a positively superb player. Su-perb!
Seen right through me.
Hah! I knowed it! You don't look like one who easily agrees to a draw.
Seen through me.
Frankly, don't find gwent the least bit interesting.
Oh? Shame, that.
Good to see ye again, Hilbert… Time we were goin'. Listen, if ye decide to buy intae that fund we discussed, ye know where to find me!
You call that interesting?
Bloke's not scintillatin' in conversation, I'll grant ye, but he's a right fiend at the card table. No matter, maybe next time.
Not interested in gwent.
Hilbert! It's been years. Allow me to introduce youse… Geralt of Rivia.
Enchanted.
Pleasure's all mine.
How's it? Got yer eye on any sparkly bits the day?
Not really. I buy what strikes me fancy. I need something right sumptuous for me walls, just now.
Nilfgaard. I get it right?
Excuse me?
Your gwent deck - it's Nilfgaard, innit? Come on, admit it.
Egh, ain't about to play you no more!
Well, what's it you want?
By my reckoning, that Countess Mignole's just a mad old bat!
Speaking of percentages… your share, Vimme.
You're not at all bad. But it ain't enough to outplay me.
That so? How about a rematch?
Apologies, mate, but I only ever play any bloke once. Vah file, as them pointy-ears say.
Aww! Hard luck, Geralt. Yer cards, though - ye find them in the crapper? Didnae line up, did they?
Unbelievable! I don't buy it! You cheated, you must 'ave. Something! Hexed me or whatnot!
Oo, I'd be careful with the gab, Hilbert… Afore Geralt takes a mind to demandin' satisfaction.
Pff! You give it to 'im, you damn midget! You bearded pinchfist!
Oo, interest'll be a right bit higher when that bugger next comes round askin' for a loan.
Elite Guard
Merchant

Though Vlodimir had returned to the nether realms, the night was still young and the wedding not yet over. Shani, dejected at the thought that Geralt would soon return to his many pressing concerns, was sitting alone at one of the tables, staring glumly at the crowd of merrymakers. Master Mirror advised Geralt that a bouquet of flowers or some tasty liqueur might cheer her up.
Geralt, remembering Shani's love for rowan blossoms, brought her a branch of them, which she delightedly plaited into her hair. Oh, if you'd only seen her then… She looked lovely, radiant, even.
Geralt decided fortified beverages make the best pick-me-ups, and so brought Shani an ample flask.

The witcher took Shani on a long walk by the river and then… then they got in a boat and, as Geralt told it to me, rowed to the moon. Could my friend be turning into something of a romantic? Or perhaps he always was one? One way or the other, a pleasant afternoon and eventful evening spent together lasted until the break of dawn, during which time they... you'll forgive me if I spare you the details.

The witcher took Shani on a long walk by the river and then… then they got in a boat and, as Geralt told it to me, rowed to the moon. Unfortunately, it seems something about moonlight disagrees with Shani's belly... Or else the poor thing was simply overcome with how romantic it all was. That unfortunate incident aside, both she and Geralt enjoyed the outing, and their pleasant afternoon and eventful evening stretched on until the break of dawn, during which time they... you'll forgive me if I spare you the details.

I don't know if Geralt simply didn't notice Shani's sour mood, or deliberately chose to disregard it, but one way or another he left her to work through it on her own and returned to his own concerns. It is a shame he did so, for something tells me that evening might have had a very moving finale...

Geralt took Shani aside for a long walk by the river – and a heart-to-heart chat. This turn of events was the natural conclusion to a day full of emotions and discoveries – after all that, who wouldn't want to sit down in a quiet spot with an old friend and talk about past times? Shani and Geralt certainly did, and so they talked and laughed until night turned to day, then parted, each returning to his or her own life.

Geralt decided to lift Shani's spirits and, following Master Mirror's advice, brought her some flowers. Shani mocked him a bit, since the blooms he chose were ingredients for a mellowing herbal tea, which doesn't exactly scream "romance," but appreciated the gesture.
Use your Witcher Senses to find something that will cheer Shani up.
Give Shani the present.
Go on a walk with Shani.
Read Shani's Character entry in the Journal to find out what might cheer her up.
Give Shani the alcohol.
A Midnight Clear
What do we have here? Bolt in the back. Went in deep, so a close range shot. Seems it came from the village, or that general direction.
Scar on his forehead. Must be Kluivert.
Bolt in the back. Went in deep, so a close range shot. From the village, or that direction, looks like.
Flaming rose on a red field. Who would've thunk.
Flaming rose on a red field. Knights've found a new pastime.
Stopped here for a second, hid, then ran on.
Hoof prints. Leading towards the hill. Someone's still there.
Tracks lead in that direction…
*Sniff* Smells like… solutions, reagents. Wonder what's cooking.
True as true can be. Dangerous trade, narcotics.
Something bad happened here…
Open window. Boot print on the bed. Somebody was in a hurry.
Crossbow bolt… and footprints - deep. Shooter must've been wearing heavy armor.
Cut down with a sword. Swollen, red nose - snorted any fisstech lately?
Smells of… Huh, they were cooking fisstech. Took most of the equipment. Only left what was broken.
Footprints… uneven. Someone ran through here.
Professor Shakeslock
What're they doing?
Playin'. Overgrown weans, you see…
Have you any children, Geralt?
None.
Oh yes. Forgot witchers're sterile. Well, don't just stare at me - tell me what brings you.
Need to chat.
I'm all ears, witcher.
Interesting, the company you keep.
Your band - chosen some interesting specimens.
Interestin'? How so? Common carousers and roughnecks, every last one.
Where'd you dig them up?
Some have been with me ages, others I gathered on the road. And a few found me themselves.
They're company for drink and sport, at least. And ever since I began traveling with them, my old enemies have sat quiet as moles.
Nice saber.
First time I've seen a saber like that. What's its origin?
Ofier. It was a… gift.
Any soft-armed craven can hang a blade from his belt, prance about feignin' danger.
But my saber's a promise - if I reach for it, heads will roll. Mere sight of it quells the urge to duel in shavers eager to face Olgierd von Everec, the infamous outlaw.
My medallion seems to think it's magic.
Heh. It thinks, eh? And I think you've never seen a better weapon.
You and Ofier - curious about the king there.
Tell me, how'd you meet the Ofieri you turned into a beast?
Aren't you a nosy one.
What's it matter? You like to talk about yourself.
That I cannot deny. Ofieri was a dauphin on a voyage through lands unknown to learn of their cultures and customs.

He fell for a lass. As it happened, this woman was already important to me. But at the time I was nowt compared to a noble from a foreign land. So her parents promised her hand to the Ofieri, though she loved me.

If you'd only seen his feeble attempts at charm. When she asked why he traveled disguised as a common merchant, he said he was like the frog from the fairytale - one kiss from her and he'd turn into a prince.
Wanted to be a frog? Became a frog.
If you fulfill wishes as well as you play gwent, I venture I've naught to fear.
We'll have to play again.
Shite. Not much I detest more than losin'.
Well, my congratulations. This card's yours.
Thanks.
Now, ready to listen, or do you still not give two shites about what I've got to say?
I'm ready! I'm listening!
Good. You'll return to your lord and tell him as follows.
His demand was brazen, hurt me to the core. For I was brought up to respect the sacred law of hospitality. And I shall not bend to an uncouth boor's dictum. Understood?
I will pay him a visit shortly to test his willingness to adapt. So you ride off and announce me, and don't spare your horse. Got it?
Aye… Got it.
Give this man a mount and leave him go!
Come, witcher. We must talk outside.
Come on, none of this dallyin'.
Ohh….
Third wish - time you stated it.
A moment, Geralt. I must see to somethin', then we'll chat.
You, there! Yank the herrin' out o' the barrel!
Third task - tell me about it.
Got something for you.
I love gifts, but I prefer to unwrap them in private.
Oi, lads! Mind the barrels! Goin' out for a jabber with Geralt!
Come.
Got Borsodi's house for you.
Vlodimir sends his love.
You spoke to him? Impossible.
Did more'n that. Fulfilled your wish. And talked to him extensively. Curious what he had to say?
Vlodimir sends his greetings.
Hm. You ever play gwent?
An immortal demands you fulfill three wishes, and you've the gall to propose a round of gwent?
Afraid to lose? No problem. I'll find someone else.
Believe that's the worst wind-up I've ever heard. Lay out your cards.
So, care for a round of gwent?
Why not.
Let's play gwent.
So long.
Farewell.
How'd that Ofieri prince turn into a monster?
Keep wondering how you turned the Ofieri into a beast. More I think about it, more I'm sure it was no run-of-the-mill curse.
This professional curiosity, or nosiness as common as the clap?
Desire to improve. Information could prove useful down the line.
In the future? You under the delusion you'll complete your tasks, live happily ever after?
Remains to be seen. So for now, admit it - a mage helped you, right?
Give you a hint - you're not the only one to fulfill wishes around here.
O'Dimm transformed the Ofieri? It was your wish?
Nay, it was my doin' alone. But you're right, it was no ordinary curse, though I'll say no more. A curse I uttered in a moment of rage, with no thought to it actually takin' hold.
How much for a herring?
Crown apiece.
Huh. I'll wait for it to drop.
What's all this kickin'?
Herrin's gotta turn and mix from time to time!
Empty herring barrel. Stinks of fish. Hm.
Hm. Tidy. And everything's clean, ready for a meal to be served.
Caretaker must still set the table.
Hm. Seems I can't pass back through.
Ugh… Hope I'm near the bedchamber.
Hm. Someone out to stop me?
Hm, fire damage. Interesting.
Guess thieves tried to lower the statue with ropes, but something scared them off.
Don't know this deity. Strange, Olgierd doesn't seem the pious type.
Someone's still tending to the flowerbeds. No violet rose, though.
What the hell was that?
Must've been the way down to the cellar.
Water's ice-cold. Mountain stream cold.
Dammit.
Sketchbook's signed "Iris."
A hairbrush. Floral ornamentation. Pretty.
Beehives. Well-maintained but dormant.
Rather worn… Used often. Wonder by who.
Lovely couple.
Bench was wiped clean recently. So was the floor.
Wood's rotted, completely.
Mighty rusty and covered in creepers.
Need another way in.
Cat
A busted lamp… and the ground's trampled.
Somebody dragged something this way… a body?
Damn. Locked.
I'd scooch along, kitty. This place--
What's that? That… digging?
Merchant

With two wishes down and one more to go, Geralt reported back to Olgierd. There he received his third and final task, which, following in the vein of the its predecessors, seemed nigh unto impossible to complete. Olgierd wanted Geralt to find and bring him the violet rose he had given his wife the last time he saw her. As this was many years ago, and flowers are not noted for their longevity, the rose had certainly disintegrated by now. Yet since Geralt had grown used to finding the unfindable and doing the undoable, he nevertheless set out to try to recover this flower of yesteryear.

Olgierd's abandoned residence was haunted by the ghost of his wife, Iris von Everec – or more accurately, by deadly spectral emanations coming from her dormant spirit. Geralt had to overcome many obstacles before finally awakening Iris' ghost from her tortured sleep so he could talk to her about the violet rose. After he did so, he traveled to the world of the ghost's imagination to revive memories repressed within it and defeat the embodiments of Iris' fears. In short, it was one of Geralt's more unusual adventures. At its end, our hero emerged from the imagined world with a very tangible rose in hand, ready to deliver to Olgierd in completion of his wish. The price of obtaining this rose? The ultimate end of Iris von Everec.

Olgierd's abandoned residence was haunted by the ghost of his wife, Iris von Everec – or more accurately, by deadly spectral emanations coming from her dormant spirit. Geralt had to overcome many obstacles before finally awakening Iris' ghost from her tortured sleep so he could talk to her about the violet rose. After he did so, he traveled to the world of the ghost's imagination to revive memories repressed within it and defeat the embodiments of Iris' fears. At its end, our hero emerged from the imagined world not with the rose itself, but with a very faithful likeness of it painted by Iris von Everec herself. In this way he fulfilled the letter of Olgierd's wish – the rose had been delivered, though in painted form, and with the eyes of Iris von Everec staring out of its canvas.

Search the area around the memory using your Witcher Senses.
Use your Witcher Senses to find a way to restore the memory.
Use your Witcher Senses to find a way to restore the memory.

Use your Witcher Senses to find a way to restore the memory.

Use your Witcher Senses to find a way to restore the memory.

Use your Witcher Senses to find a way to restore the memory.

Use your Witcher Senses to find a way to restore the memory.

Scenes From a Marriage
I found your fire belcher, yet I fear he proved a common coward.
What's his bravery to me? I paid him to eat fire, he need do just that.
Sadly, he's not only a coward, but a cheat as well. Soon as I found him, he lifted his skirt and ran.
And I went to such expense… What's with Daemon?
The missing fire blower is missing no more.
It was my doing, if I may say so myself.
And Daemon? What's with him?
Haven't a clue. He'd chased the fire eater up a tree, so I chased him off. Assumed he'd wandered home.
He hasn't. No one's seen hide nor hair of him.
Then he's a shite poor excuse for a dog!
Aye, true. Never did like the little fleabag.
The dog's small beer - no fire eating, that's the grief.
Aye, grief, no show, oh no… What can we do?
Come now, stiff upper lip. A silly sconce swiller no wedding makes nor breaks.
Silly to you, but it means prestige to us. We aimed to show we're to be taken seriously, that we're more'n just milkers and ploughers and goatherds.
A torch tonguer would change nothing. No circus performer could possibly turn a peasant into a noble.
You think us bumpkins?
Never uttered the word. Yet you are not of the gentry - a simple fact.
Let's go, dumplin'. We're clearly not fit company for our dear lord witcher.
Stop your blubbering. Stiff upper lip.
Hm. I can't help but wonder - must it be a fire eater who performs? What if, instead, there was - oh, I don't know - a juggler?
Just where would we find a juggler at this hour?
But say you did, would that do as a replacement for the fire sniffler?
Well… I suppose it might.
Then I shall perform!
You? First I've heard of a juggling witcher!
Today I'm no ordinary witcher. In my youth I had a great many friends among circus folk. They taught me well.
I shall gladly save you from your troubles, now.
If that's the case, I'll announce the performance!
Perhaps I can be of service?
Lovely wedding, even without the fire drunk.
I regret the loss as well. But there, there, you've put on a lovely wedding even without him!
You think so? Truly?
Wholly! I haven't reveled so thoroughly in ages! You've nothing to be ashamed of. There are vittles, musicians, and all enjoy themselves - as should you.
You marry your daughter off today. Be glad, for sadness can only bring her worry.
Witcher speaks wise words, my dear. Come, let's see to the guests.
Yes, let's. Thank you, witcher, for your trouble. And your kind words.
It'll be midnight soon. The capping will begin.
Then tally-ho to the barn. I must cap my night off with a last hurrah.
Just… easy with the comments, all right? Please?
Your attention, please! I invite all to witness a spectacle unrivaled, a man so bold as to eat fire!
We must watch the trickery. Never saw anything like it while alive.
He failed to return?
No, he did. He's just acting mighty strange.
Seems to be in a muddle o' sorts. Got as much life in him as a carrot.
Might've eaten some nightshade or whatnot.
I found your fire licker, but he gave up the ghost on the way back. Too much vodka.
Just my luck to hire a drunk… And Daemon? What's with him?
Told you we'd 'ave done better to spend the coin on a stove fitter than a fire eater. Our hearth's near shot.
Hm. Truth be told, I'd hoped a fire eater would've done somethin' more… riveting.
Last time I've paid a penny to any such parasite.
For the coin he took, he should've ridden in on a fire-breathing dragon.
Boar
Trail's gone cold… Need to look around. Ask. Maybe someone's seen him.
Brought you more coin. Put it towards better equipment?
Thanks in the thousands! Too kind you are to me, truly.
Your work's worth the coin.
Painite crystal I shall need also.
Huh?
Painite, a mineral. In my lands quite rare, here impossible surely to find. Lenses I make from it, the powder residue I blend into my mixtures.
See what I can do.
Got the funds for advanced tools.
Made good use of my coin by the look of things.
The return to my craft - know you not the pleasure it brings. I thank you!
Don't mention it. How's the work going?
Several lesser runes I've forged already - practice, you see. Heheh. Yet I sadden in thinking the tools and ingredients I possess are not fit to create better.
Got lucky - found you some jade. Here.
Thank you, I do. If you to gaze wish at my handiwork, to do so I invite you.
Novigrad Guard
Redanian
Living tableau's gotta look just like the painting…
[Apple on the right.]
This goes here…
[Choose a place for the goblet.]
[Goblet on the left.]
Maybe this…?
[Goblet on the right.]
Here?
[Back.]
[Goblet in the middle.]
Maybe on this side…
Smile a bit wider.
Like this?
You were meant to smile, not bare your teeth.
No, still wrong. Smile like you did when Papa agreed we could marry. Please?
Hm?
You're useless. I can tell something's bothering you.
I've a bit of work I should see to.
Again? Olgierd… we agreed not to keep any secrets from one another. We promised.
Forgive me. I don't wish to discuss this.
Olgierd…
Olgierd!
Finally. Just like the picture.
Fits, I think…
[Grapes on the left.]
Let's try this…
[Grapes on the right.]
[Back.]
[Grapes in the middle.]
Maybe here?
[Choose a place for the grapes.]
[Leave.]
[Choose a place for the apple.]
[Apple on the left.]
Let's try this…
[Apple in the middle.]
Hmm…
[Back.]
Hm. Pretty in the summer, the von Everecs' manor.
A portrait of the married couple.
Another blurred memory.
Home-made paints. Strange… can still smell the turpentine.
Fresh… as if someone just rinsed it.
Hm. Still not right…
She painted Olgierd… but the details are off. Living tableau's missing something…
Dammit… Gotta go around.
Goblet - like the one in the painting.
Towel should hang here.
Towel should lie here.

Geralt was racking his brains for a way to defeat Master Mirror when Shani came to his rescue. She knew of a professor from the Oxenfurt Academy who had spent years scrutinizing every manifestation of black magic and surely would be able to help. Unfortunately, the witch hunters had decided the professor's knowledge was best used for their goals and their goals only and had placed guards outside his home. Officially he was a free man, but in reality, no one entered or left the house without their permission.

The professor told Geralt of the long hours he had spent scouring old tomes for accounts of Gaunter O'Dimm, alias Master Mirror. He had been set on this trail by Olgierd von Everec, who paid him handsomely for his labors. This research had borne fruit in the form of a great many secrets about the mysterious O'Dimm, including a possible way to outsmart him. Sadly, however, the professor did not live to see if this trick would work for Geralt in practice, for during their conversation Shakeslock made one step outside the runic circle drawn on the floor of his residence and died immediately. We will never know if this step was accidental or deliberate – by the time Geralt met him, he had become a tired and tormented wreck who just might have considered death a relief.
Professor Shakeslock
Hunter
Doppler
…And might ye, miss, be 'midst the unattached? I am… though only a wee spell now.
Is that so? Impossible! Only a fool would loosen their hold on a mate like you.
And Countess Yvonne of Lan Exeter's necklace. Your handiwork, wasn't it?
It was. I scaled a gutter, entered her bedchamber.
Hah! I knew it! I knew it.
Ah, at last. We're all here. Time to begin.
This heist, it's no jest. So if any of you has any doubts, isn't sure, now's the time to leave. Won't be able to after.

The Borsodis' Auction House, its vault - that's our target. Eveline, you'll enter through the tower when the patrol rounds this corner. Drop us a line. We have to be inside within five minutes. Is that enough?
It's plenty.
Splendid. Once we're all in the tower, we'll proceed to the auction house. Shouldn't see any guards inside. If we do, we'll have Geralt and his blades.
Then downstairs to the vault. Quinto will crack the lock. We get in the vault, take the loot, disappear out the back through a secret passage.
What about wearin' masks? Not a city in the North that don't have wanted posters with my likeness hangin' about.
If you're so damned scared somebody'll talk, let's all go there together. Now.
Any objections? Anyone need more time?
On our way, then.
I say we go there together. Now.
Huh, sure know how to motivate a crew. No matter. See you there.
Meet you all there.
Ah, one last thing.
Inform the City Watch, blabber anythin' about this over an ale, and I'll kill you. With me own hands.
Geralt, I see, has come prepared.
Think it's a fetish of sorts?
And I will bring masks for the rest.
I'll tend to that.
What about masks? Got a rather recognizable mug myself.
All right. Let's get to work. Wanna be done with this soon as possible.
We'll reconvene in the gateway beside the tower. Midnight sharp. And everyone's to make sure they're not followed. I'll get word to the cook in the barracks.
Let's get to work.
What about the vault? How is it secured?
With a door. But you ought to be able to handle it. Any other problems we resolve as they come.
Anything else?
And the vault? Is it secured somehow?
Even if it is, my blend of saltpeter, cordite and fulminatin' silver'll do the trick.
Additional security measures, traps - any inside? Anything we need to watch out for?
Nothing particularly dangerous. Here, on the ground floor, there's a rope linked to the bell in the tower. Anyone sounds the alarm, there'll be trouble.
How do we stop it from ringing?
Don't pull the rope. As I said, the auction house ought to be empty. I don't expect any problems.
Any security measures inside?
But if you were to--
Find that location, I wouldn't need any of you. Believe you me, I've tried. Time and again.
Anythin' else?
Aye, but you could--
Got a horse sense take on this. Secret passage - if we plan to use it on the way out, why not on the way in?
Excellent question. Why not?
Every corridor has two ends, right? Like a rope. I know the location of just one end. It's in the vault. The other, it's somewhere beneath the city. But I can't tell you where.
Mhm. Great.
Secret passage… why not get in that way? Seems dumb not to.
No plan B? If something goes seriously wrong?
Hm. All good and fine, except… what if something goes wrong? Seriously.
You're on your own. We all are.
Just like that?
No room for friendship in this business.
I've said my piece. Any questions?
Then downstairs to the vault. Casimir blows the vault door. We go in, take the loot, disappear out the back through a secret passage.
Why'd they send you down here? Only if it's not confidential, of course.
I need a venom sample - from the beast that prowls these sewers.
It doesn't just kill those who come down here, you know. The water in so many wells is contaminated. Folk're getting ill, Redanian soldiers among them.
Plan to kill the beast. Bring you a sample of its venom after I do.
Nice of you to offer, but I'd rather go with you, collect the sample myself.
Creature's dangerous - you saw what it can do.
I'm a big girl, Geralt. I can take care of myself. And you know I'll get my way, so don't try to talk me out of anything.
Eh, fine, your choice. So show me where the monster attacked you.
This way.
Your mission - what was it?
What attacked you? Get a good look at it?
No. I started running as soon as it appeared. It was huge, spat venom and… made these… slurping sounds. That's all I know.
Hm. Doesn't sound like a major necrophage or a pack of drowners…
No, this was one "thing" - big, but one. Somebody threw a torch at it. Monster couldn't have cared less.
All right, not afraid of fire. Good to know.
His injuries - how'd he get them?
He someone important to you?
The soldier… he someone important to you?
His name was Nols. Supposed to go on leave next week. Now he won't - nor will the rest of his unit.
How many were they?
A whole squad, six brave boys. All dead.
Oh no you don't! Hear me? Don't you dare!
Please don't do this to me.
Shani?
Geralt?
What're you doing here?
Trying to save his life! Help me!
Shani, calm down. He's dead.
I'm sure… something… can be done…
Let it go.
Dammit! All for nothing!
You did all you could.
Thanks, Geralt.
It's, uh, good to see you.
You, too. Lost track of you after I left Vizima. Where'd you go? What've you been doing?
Um, long story short? I've been treating the sick and wounded, as always. Mainly at my clinic in Oxenfurt. But in Redania I'm called on to help the army at times, as well.
I'll want to hear the long story long, too.
Sure, but, uh, once we're out of these sewers.
Redanian army force you to come here, too? Or you just down here for a pleasant stroll?
Got our orders this morning. I came down here with a whole unit, but… something attacked us.
Death! Death to you!
You'll die here, vagrant!
Welcome, welcome! What would you say to a hand or two of gwent?
Uhh… not gonna try to sell me something first?
My goods are not swallows, they will not flit nor flee.
Cards won't, either.
Do you wish to split hairs all day, or play gwent? Hm?
Like to take a look at your wares.
Like to take a look at your wares.
Like to buy something.
So, should we lay 'em down?
Yes, yes, yes! You needn't ask twice!
Sure, gwent it is.
Should be going…
If ever you need a partner for gwent… you know where to find me!
See you.
Quite the card lover, aren't you?
Feels like you might've missed your calling.
Oh? Curious conclusion. Why?
Well, should be hawking goods. Instead, gwent's all you talk about.
Hmmm… You're right! So, care for a match?
Well, then? Shall we lay down some gwent?
Fool!
Die…
Lebioda's wounds!
Oh, whoreson!
C'mon! Get 'im!
Own mam won't know you once we're done!
What the devil was that?!
I beat up the doctor, I shat on the mountain, I spit on the children, I pissed in the fountain…
Uh-huh?
Phew… A taker, at long last! Poverty on everyone's lips, but when you've a job to give, no one's eager! Folk're lazy, that's the truth of it!
Stick to the point. If you don't mind.
Right, right… Sorry for the chatter. I'm anxious, is all. Been so long without any word… ehh.
It's my apprentice, Folkert. I sent him to the Deadwight Wood - you know, the forest near Martin Feuille's farmstead. I'd run out of han fiber, see, and the damned stuff grows thick as weeds there…
Lemme guess - hasn't returned.
Yes-- No-- He hasn't. Please, find him. And bring him back, safe and sound.
No promises… but I can certainly look for him. Any distinguishing features? How will I recognize him?
Hrm, got to think on that… Well, he's a halfling, as I am. Light hair… Will that do?
It'll have to. So long.
Fine. I'll look for him.
Sorry… No time for this now. Things change, I'll come see you again.
Sorry, don't have time for this now.
So? What'll it be, eh? Will you look for Folkert or not?
Here about the notice.
Here about the contract.

Unfortunate accidents happen to even the most gods-fearing of men. This realization came to Geralt when he happened across the corpse of a priest. On the body he found a journal, and, after a moment of silence for the deceased's memory, he tucked the document into his satchel.

From the notes he learned locals were having a bit of trouble in the form of a haunted cemetery. Led by a sense of duty, Geralt decided to see what was disturbing the dead's peace and endangering the living's lives.

It turned out the crypt was haunted by a powerful ghost, an Accursed Mother. The wraith jealously guarded the treasures laid to rest with the dead and attacked all intruders. This time, however, she had met her match.
Search the crypt's underground passages.
Read the priest's notes.
The Cursed Chapel
She's dead. Grew weak, weaker, then - pfft! - like a spark. Devils take your soul.
It is, to see you again, quite the pleasure.
You're a long way from Ofier.
A long way and with dangers fraught. But in our homeland they say, "In risk there is honor."
Got a ring to it. Not true in my experience, though. Face plenty of risks. Honor - not so much.
Because risk issues from intent - important is this intent! The long passage I braved to admire the unknown and bring glory to myself and my liege.

The world we must explore, virgin lands discover, new knowledge garner among our brothers then to spread. For is there in life a beauty greater than to admire the new, to stand in awe of the never-ending creation of the world?
That mean I've landed in a camp of explorers and philosophers?
Indeed. Your customs we come to observe, knowledge to exchange, and goods, naturally, to trade.
Willing to tell me about your homeland?
Your homeland - be glad to hear some tales about it if you've got the time.
If time you have. For of my home I could speak until your ears withered and your legs failed you.
What here they call Ofier in truth is many diverse polities and peoples.
A land it is of vast steppes, mountains forbidding, lakes clear as crystal and wild lands untouched.
A land of fallen empires, kingdoms at their peak and tribes that know no monarchs yet remember in myth a time when the world was young.
You call any of these lands home?

Yes, a town with towers to make Nilfgaard weep with envy. Of philosophers, doctors, mathematicians and mages an enclave. But about these last you should my friend interrogate, for one among them is he - a runewright.
I'll make it a point to talk to him.
Fine horse you've got.
Quite the mount you've got.
Ah yes, a loyal friend I have in Babiyetza. And she is wiser than many a man.
Countless races we have won together.
So, an explorer and a jockey in one.
From where I come, small children ride, and not a gathering is by a horse race not crowned.
Wouldn't mind a look at your wares.
What'd you bring from Ofier? Mind if I have a look?
Our craftsmen's goods, you see worth in them?
Quite a bit, I'd say.
Ah, these are nothing compared to what I could offer had I not lost my prized diagrams.
How'd you lose them?
To thieves. In our travels, I and my companions surprise attacked by local ruffians were. The diagrams, their loss, I bemoan not so much as I do one of my comrades, killed in the violence.
Sounds like a real loss. Sorry.
I might have been more cautious. Should you encounter the diagrams, return them, and thankful I shall be.
Duplicates I will make, with markings your craftsmen understand. A gift for you.
I'll keep that in mind.
Shame. Unfortunately, can't really look into this now.
These diagrams - might be able to recover them for you.
See if I can't find your diagrams, recover them for you.
These instructions when followed produce items worthy of a king.
Tell me where you were attacked. Remember?
A crossroads, not far. Forgive me, for this area I know poorly. Detailed directions I cannot provide. North of the spot stood a residence, a near ruin.
Should be able to find it.
You won, congratulations. And you were right all along - Ofieri mares are swift as the wind.
Ofieri mares may be swift as the wind, not quite as fast as my Roach, though.
I congratulate you! A saddle for your mount your reward, our contest to commemorate. It will make you a rider even swifter.
Thanks. Like your new gear, Roach?
Hah! Much may be said of a man by how he treats his horse.
Our myths tell of a time when love brought together the skies and the steppe. And from their union was born the first mare.

Weak were the creatures called men, they fell prey to countless dangers. The mare nursed them, her milk fed them. Strong they grew, and she let them saddle her. Warriors they became and gave fight to their foes.
The myths teach us to respect our horses, noblest among all beasts.
Beautiful story. Thanks… for that and the race.
Heard a lot of good things about Ofieri mares, their speed. Care to race?
Hmhmha. Swift as the western winds are our mounts. To prove this would be an honor. So race we must!
Care to race again?
A pure pleasure it would be!
Up for a horse race?
Farewell.
Take care, now.
Go and in the world glory. Its never-ending creation be praised. Farewell.
All four recover and a reward shall be yours. Duplicates I will make, with markings your craftsmen understand.
Dammit! Stupid bugs.
Don't like this place.
Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.
Painting's destroyed.
The parlor.
Well, well… did not live in poverty, those two.
What now?
Come inside.
You'll find more memories in there.
Then he went upstairs.
So let's follow him.
He lied.
Didn't want to involve her in this.
He deceived her. And himself.
Oh, never mind. Let's go to the study.
To sink the Borsodis, naturally.
You see, I learned of an interesting clause in old man Maximilian's will.
It states that his sons must meet and shake hands in agreement at least once a year at Belleteyn. Failing that, the auction house must be auctioned off. The proceeds to go to Vilmerius Hospital.
Guess the old man sensed what might happen.
Ah, that's better. All right, what do you have for me?
Max Borsodi's House. As requested.
Dying to hear.
No, dying to hear, though. Always liked a tale with a thrill.
I'm in no mood for jests.
Neither am I. Did my job, Olgierd. Delivered what you asked for. To the letter. Unhappy? Hell, should've chosen your words more carefully.
His brother Ewald was worse.
Was?
Horst killed him. With his own hands.
Horst's brother - did you know about him?
I should think so. Ewald was famous in certain circles.
Which ones?
The kind noble witchers don't usually associate with.
He murdered for coin. No questions. Without batting an eye. Always extravagantly, though. If not for his damned surname, I believe I'd have invited him to join the company.
Did you know Horst had a brother?
The Borsodis - what's your gripe?
Pretty sad story.
Sad story.
Isn't it? Truthfully, I'm surprised I retained any cheer in my soul.
Finish up.
Summing up, you went broke, your woman dumped you, then you got drunk and did something stupid. Heard it all before.
Hahaha! And folk say I've a heart of stone…
Well? Why do you stand there? Do you need something still?
Well? Why do you stand there? Do you need something still?
You need something?
Nothing more, don't think. I'm off to entertain your brother.
Break a leg. Literally.
What happened then?
Argh, what happened then, witcher, was one big stinkin' pile of shite.
What happened then?
Wouldn't have asked if I wasn't.
Hah! Cheeky as ever.
My family, they took on some debt. A poor investment in a sawmill, a bad crop one year, a lawsuit lost. You know how it is - when it rains, it pours.
We needed but a few weeks to recover, but Horst Borsodi had acquired our debt. All of it. Demanded it be repaid immediately.
I pleaded, I begged, I tore open my shirt at his threshold. Agh, it was like talking to a wall.
I went to the auction. Saw those perfumed pricks buy my father's sword, my mother's death mask, my brother's horse tack. Ah, Horst earned a pretty pile selling our mementos.
No surprise the animosity you feel for him.
That was but the start. My Iris' parents learned of my family's misfortune, and our betrothal was no more. They found her another suitor. One from beyond the sea.
The anger I felt, I thought I'd go mad. Went to the tavern. Drank a round, a second… I brawled, then had another tankard. And then… then, I asked the wrong bloke for help.
Yeah.
All in all, not really. Just asking out of courtesy.
Mhm. Commendable manners.
No, not really.
The Borsodis - what's your gripe? Get kicked out of an auction?
Worse. They evicted me from my home.
Are you really interested?
The Borsodis - what's your gripe?
Why'd you even need those papers?
Why'd you need those papers?
Did you know Horst had a brother?
Awfully noble of you, showing so much concern for the needy.
I couldn't give a rat's arse about the needy. May they wither and disappear along with the city.
I wanted one thing. Revenge.

Horst and Ewald are gnawing on soil now. But thanks to these papers, their relatives won't get the auction house. Family's lost it for good. And the hospital will have the funds it needs to treat orphans and beggars pro bono.
Huh. It's progress.
Made a deal with his brother. Who then beat the living shit out of Horst with a gold candle holder.
Yes. I should have.
I assume you came to an agreement with Horst. Shame. A right whoreson, that one.
Dunno. Ask for legal advice? Looks to me like you might need some.
You signed the contract, Olgierd. I'm just fulfilling its terms. To the letter. Unhappy? Hell, should've chosen your words more carefully.
Ask for legal advice?
The papers - where are they?
Left them in the vault. You wanted the House, you got the House. Never mentioned its contents.
You're a quick study. Already as tricky as O'Dimm himself. Keen to ridicule a man.
Do you know what I and the company do with your type?
Ah, Horst must be livid.
He's not.
No?
He's not anything, except dead. His brother - same thing. A few others too.
Stones you've got. But I didn't think you'd have the stomach for a massacre.
Oh, think I might find the stomach for another. Once your final wish is fulfilled.
Hah. You really don't like me, do you?
Hate smartasses, hate it when they try to use me. It's why both brothers are dead. And why you should tread carefully.
Noted. Now I've some advice for you.
You underestimate me.
Had no choice.
Situation got out of hand.
Hah! Oh, sounds familiar. There you are, drinking, puffing on henbane… and then - Surprise! - heads rolling across the floor. And none know how or why!
I'm not amused.
No? Why not?
Cause unlike you, killing gives me no pleasure.
The Borsodis aren't worth your tears. Sons of bitches, to a man.
Why'd you need those papers?
Why did you need those papers?
Aimed to deliver those papers to the right hands. Borsodi would've landed in the streets. And the hospital would've gotten the funds it needs to treat orphans and beggars pro bono.
Ah, that's better. Do you smoke?
No. Supposed to be bad for you.
Hah. You see? An advantage of being immortal.
So, what have you brought me?
A moment. I need to smoke.
So, what have you brought me?
No chatterin'! Kill!
On your guards!
Plough me!
I'll shit on your grave!
Come to papa! Come on!
Thou shalt not suffer a mage to live!
Faster, dammit! Faster!
No! Nooo!
Iris' Greatest Fear
Shani
Kestatis von Everec
You seen the ol' ball and chain?
The old sot's probably sleepin' under a table somewhere…
Hey! Donkey! Lookin' for my geezer. Seen him?
Help!
Spells! Spells!
Rise, brothers, and trample the serpent!
We shall gut you, vermin!
How do you wish to die?
A grave error, witcher!
Faster, for fuck's sake!
Death!
Endrega Drone
Guard
Wealthy Townsman
I shall do the impossible! I shall breathe fire!
Mark this day, good folk, for your eyes will not witness a feat so daring anytime soon!
Ladies and gen'lmens, gather 'round! You're in for marvels and wonders!
In just one moment I shall devour… fire!
Never seen a thing quite like that, have you?!
Tracks lead to the water. Dammit.
Hugo's sleeping with the fish. No two ways about it - gotta find Eveline.
Blood. Someone knocked their head on this beam. Open cut.
Bare feet. Fresh prints.
Looks like Hugo ran into trouble. Gotta find him. Fast.
Blood… still moist. Nothing beyond that.
Trail ends here… or continues underwater.
Whoa, mate. Stuck your prick where you shouldn't have.
Hey! Anyone in there?!
Blood? Hm. This does not look good.
You're going down.
We shall see, my friend.
You must find me before the sand in the hourglass runs out.
Ready? Let's begin!
Let's do this.
Repeat the riddle.
Didn't quite catch the riddle. Mind repeating it?
To all things and men I appertain, and yet by some am shunned and disdained.
Fondle and ogle me till you're insane, but no blow can harm me, cause me pain.
Children delight in me, elders take fright, fair maids rejoice and spin.
Cry, and I weep, yawn, and I sleep, smile, and I too shall grin.
Wha… what's happening?
You wished to play, so let us play.
I shall tell you a riddle. Solve it, and both you and Olgierd will be free.
And if I don't?
Hahahaha, then we'll all three go for a wild ride. It's what you proposed, is it not?
The riddle - lemme hear it.
To all things and men I appertain, and yet by some am shunned and disdained.
Fondle and ogle me, till you're insane, but no blow can harm me, cause me pain.
Children delight in me, elders take fright, fair maids rejoice and spin.
Cry, and I weep, yawn, and I sleep, smile, and I shall grin.
What was that supposed to be?
You tell me. What am I?
Ugh… I sold my arse for a side o' bacon.
Aah... aah... Aaah-choo!
Flrrrp. A bit o' sauce'll drain the snot.
Bacon don't fall far from the pig…
Huh?
What's new, witcher?
Now you've fuckin' done it!
Ahh, don't fuck with me.
Herbalist's cart. Got some blood here.
Don't like it when you're glum.
I'm not. Have you seen Olgierd? Told him you fulfilled his wish?
Don't be sad, Shani.
I'm fine, really. And you were going to see Olgierd.
Pretty, I guess. Thing is, will it cheer her up?
Fine, I'll pick some. Becoming quite the romantic…
[Pick.]
Think I'll pass.
[Leave.]
A sip of something strong never hurt anyone. Question is, will it cheer her up?
Here's hoping Shani's a happy drunk.
[Take.]
Good idea? Maybe not. She might be a sad drunk.
[Leave.]
Chamomile, looks like.
A lad clutchin' stems is a lad caught at mischief… They never think to offer blooms 'less their stones're in a vice.
Rowanberry brandy… Shani loves the blossoms, might enjoy this as well.
A rowan… Shani mentioned she used to weave the berries into necklaces.
Good mead oughta lift her spirits.
Trail ends here. Hmm. Dirt and ground cover concealing a hatch. Secret passageway?
Nowt? Sold us tickets, they did. Shiteaters.
Could've apologized, the least.
Meh. Artists - thievin' scum an' whores, every last one of 'em!
Well, what's the hold up? Shoot!
Are you cross-eyed or what?!
Aim for the apple! The apple!
Are you completely daft?
Wonder if they need a new elf come every show.
Most like. Just go to the forest an' trap 'em, like rabbits.
Gods ha' mercy!
Shoot him smack in the noggin, the mangy squirrel! Hehehe…
I can't watch this! Tell us when it's over!
Pfff. I could do that.
Were I that elf, I believe I'd plain shit in my trousers.
Were I that witcher, I wouldn't aim for the apple!
Aye! Pointy-ears've shot droves of ours from the brush. Retribution, I say. Give 'em a taste of their own medicine!
Folk say there's a rubbin' woman 'midst this troupe.
A rubbin' woman? What's she do?
You know. The kind that bends, does splits, wraps her legs round her head.
Ah! A rubber lady! Tasteless however you cut it.
What're you doin' here, Nemuel? Not at work?
Afeared I'm out a job. Sawmill burnt down - thanks to the good knights of the Order of the Flaming Rose.
First I've heard. What now?
Agh, nothing. 'Twere monsters, we could hire a witcher. But none'll drive off those tin men.
While searching a body he found in a ravaged campsite, Geralt found a key and a journal. Thinking the latter might shed light on its writer's fate, he slipped it into his bag.

Many tuck coin away for a rainy day. Most, however, choose more accessible places for their stash than the cellar. Geralt didn't ponder this choice of hiding places long, however, but instead pocketed the coin and went on his way.

The notes contained information about a fortune hidden in a hut a griffin had roosted in. The coin had belonged to the deceased's aunt, but since neither she nor her nephew had any use for it now, Geralt decided to kill the beast and take it for himself.
Search the ruined hut's cellar.
Read Knut Kreutzman's notes.
A Surprise Inheritance
Ran into your friend Countess Mignole.
Ran into an old friend of yours… Countess Mignole.
Huh? Impossible. Where?
Auction house in Oxenfurt. She's an… aficionado, a collector. Witcher gear - imagine that. Old School of the Wolf armor, for instance.
Hmm, right. A fine gambeson, that was. It had sleeves of chainmail and… Agh.
Love letters conveyed by a governess, trysts in garden nooks, you scampering out a window… Heh. Last person I imagined dabbling in that sort of thing.
Mgh, you might find it hard to believe, but… I was young too, once. Well, younger.
She still lives in Oxenfurt. No itch to go there, see her?
Later, maybe… Once it's over, once things're calm again.
Sssssaah!
You'll die here, fleshbag!
So, the eastern front, and then…?
Depends where they send me.
Wherever it is, take care of yourself.
Always do. So don't worry.
Geralt, where do you think you're going?
We were bound for the academy!
To Radovid, there's little difference between the two.
Seems to tolerate you well enough.
Because he needs me. For now.
So how're things at the academy these days?
You mean since Radovid shut it down?
I mean, is it well guarded.
Might be all it is. Many of the faculty fled to the far north. The braver ones stayed, but assumed the guises of tailors and laundresses. Why?
Just curious. Scholars seemed to have adopted mage tactics. They in the same bind?
Guard
Alexy von Everec
Burned to a crisp. Everything…
Ugh, reeks in here.
Then von Everec ceased to be human.
Though he still loved his wife.
No. He merely remembered that he should love her.
Let's go upstairs.
Damn candles…
Vimme Vivaldi
Imlerith
Need to talk to this professor.
We'll go together. Redanian guards all over the academy. Doubt you'll get in alone.
Guards've never stopped me, you know that.
Mhm. But wound these, and I'll have to patch them up.
Besides, we might run into a friend. Get inside free and easy.
Need to see this professor.
Mage hunters - why're they at his door?
Mage hunters at the door… He under house arrest?
I can't say, really. Some of the faculty think him a traitor - say he sold out to the hunters for a hefty pouch of gold.
The assistant, on the other hand, insists the professor wants them there to protect him. I don't know what from.
What's your guess?
He's certainly useful to them. A specialist in black magic and the occult? Must be a trove of knowledge.
If he's really gone off his nutter, I wouldn't be surprised to see them using him.
So, learn anything about Olgierd?
Well, I abandoned the books quickly. Decided that if I was going to learn the truth, I'd need to find someone who knows him.
Find anyone?
Turned out I didn't need to look far. A colleague at the academy, an assistant to Professor Premethine Shakeslock, claims Olgierd von Everec met with the professor multiple times.
Apparently Olgierd asked the professor to do some research. Professor got so worked up doing it, he went daffy. Started jealously guarding his notes. Wouldn't even let his assistant look at them.
The professor - where'll I find him?
Here in Oxenfurt. Cloistered inside his house on Academy grounds. Mage hunters guard his door.
Learn anything about Olgierd?
This departure, so sudden. Why?
Never mentioned you'd be moving. Any intention to, either.
I didn't know I would be. Found out this morning.
Two soldiers came to my door. Said Redania needs me again.
Couldn't turn 'em down, just say no?
Ah, perhaps I could've. But I didn't want to. Treating the ill and wounded, it's my calling. No place I'm needed more than at the front.
Can't you reconsider… and stay?
Geralt, what for?
The wedding, the time we've spent together… it was nice. But you have your life, and I have mine. We-- This doesn't make sense long-term. You know that as well as I do.
Well… you take care of yourself.
You too, Geralt.
Don't go.
I see.
I understand. Any chance we'll see each other again?
Someday, I'm sure.
Shani?
Oh, Geralt. Good thing you're here.
What happened? Somebody break in?
This? Ah, no. Just getting ready to move.
What? When? Where to?
Ah, not what I wanted to talk to you about, or at least not only, but…
I'm leaving, Geralt. The eastern front beckons. I'm Kaedwen bound.
Nothing better to do?
Don't you have anything better to do?
Not at the moment. Make no mistake, you cannot evade this. You must answer my questions, promptly and in full.
Might've, once or twice…
Might've… once or twice. Definitely no more than three times.
And did you then file a WIPT-30/c form with the Revenue and Customs office for your place of residence? No? As I thought!
Unfortunately, I have.
Yeah, unfortunately, on occasion. But I didn't know it was illegal.
Ignorantia legis non excusat, as the ancient Vrans would say. Ignorance of the law excuses no one!
A couple times, maybe…
A couple times… But the owners never protested.
In the eyes of the law that is no excuse, my good man!
And done. Here.
What's this?
A summons to pay back taxes. Please report to the Vivaldi Bank with this document posthaste.
But-- But I've never paid any taxes, not one copper!
Precisely! Yet you've had the obligation always! Thus the arrears! I advise you well - do not treat this matter lightly!
Ugh. Paper pushers.
It adds up… to the crown! I say, good sir, you are exceptionally upstanding!
It'd be rude to disagree.
In these times, such civic virtue is a rarity. It must be commended, rewarded. Here.
Wha… what's this?
A diploma. I bestow on you the title of Taxpayer in Good Standing. I'd suggest you frame it, hang it in a place of honor. Congratulations!

Now, if you could wait for one moment… Compare column B to Table VII, apply the rate for confirmed, childless bachelors, a tax credit of seven-point-three percent for practitioners of hazardous professions…
Gotta be kidding! The witchers' code forbids it!
I'm pleased to hear you abide by your guild's by-laws.
No, nuh-uh, never.
Now, for the final question. Have you ever unlawfully acquired another man's movable goods, chattels?
Hmmm. Meaning?
Agh. Meaning, have you ever waltzed into someone's home and taken something without their permission?
No, never done anything of the sort. Witcher's honor.
No, never.
Right… next. During the current fiscal year, have you engaged in the acquisition of bivalves with the express intention of selling the pearls therein?
Even if I have, what's wrong with that?

Article 86, section 3 of the Tax Code: "Whosever purchases goods at an unseemly low price to take advantage of the seller's ignorance, shall be subject to a fine equaling two hundred percent of the earnings from any such a transaction." Sound familiar?
And now, please answer. Have you, or have you not, dealt in said pearls?
This some kind of joke? 'Course not.
Me? Never!
Profession?
Witcher. Monster slayer.
Mhm… Sole proprietorship, service sector. Type of services rendered: rat/pest/monster removal.
Moving on. Have you at any time engaged in the wholesale trade of rawhide in the White Orchard area?
I get how that might've happened. Be glad to clear them up.
Be happy to clear them up.
Halt! You there! Please wait! You're Geralt of Rivia, are you not?
Depends who's asking.
Revenue and Customs for Occupied Temeria, Dorian branch. Represented by yours truly, Deputy Tax Enumerator Walthemor Mitty.
Honored, I guess. What seems to be the problem?
In brief, undeclared income.
Scuse me?
We've had reports, numerous, that over the last months you've come into a great deal of coin - quickly. So quickly it's raised suspicions.
Bilge Hag
Halfling
Girl
Nerha hel sata hle!
{lmerte! lmerte!} [Die! Die!]
{Semahab tefan ish azer!} [May your loins grow foul with rot!]
Nahaz a'zaza!
Brrrp! And tomorrow, we do it all again!
Brr, pickled herrin'. No better chaser for vodka! Ech.
Oh, love them ears, mate! Heh…
Looks bleak to me.
Looks bleak to me. Tower wall's smooth as glass. Don't know about you, but I can't scale that, and--
And I've not asked you to. Let me finish.
Well, you've returned. What's this mean? Decided to join me after all?
All right, I'm off. Got a bit to do.
As do I. Get it all done, and we'll meet back here.
What then?
Then we'll bugger Horst up, down and sideways. All together.
Time I was on my way.
As far as I know, his troop's made camp east of Oxenfurt, on the right bank of the Pontar.
Ah, right, the famed Hans. Went out with his pals to hunt monsters. Turned out they were shit at it. I know the man.
Hm. So I'd have to rip one from his cozy home, the other from a cozy cage. Need to think about it.
Hans or the beast?
Both, actually.
I know the man. Slew an archgriffin for him. Mean fiend, pretty much.
All right, opening the vault - who do we have?
Let's start with the fact that one of 'em's a dwarf.
Casimir Bassi, native of Mahakam. A specialist in controlled explosions. Folk say he could blow Novigrad to the high heavens with but a pinch of saltpeter. Vault door for him should be a cinch.
The problem is Casimir apparently hung up his detonators some time ago. He married, sired some littler ones, and settled in the village of Alness. Might plain turn us down.
Any options?
Quinto. The North's most famed safecracker. Arrest warrants out on him in Kaedwen, Lyria, Angren and Kovir. Sadly, he got nabbed a few days back. By one Hans of Cidaris, a prick mercenary.
Opening the vault - what're our options?
What's this about culling the patrols? Told you - no one dies.
Easy. I don't want anyone's death. Just need some folk to be temporarily indisposed.
Spit it out.
You've got to approach the garrison's cook, convince him to spike the soldiers' nosh with somethin' to keep some of them bedridden. One in two, let's say. Wouldn't want to raise suspicions.
Hmm. Know the formula for a potion that might do the trick.
There, see? Brew up a bit o' that, hit the town, find the cook, then convince him to do you a favor. I don't know, cast a spell, toss him some coin… you could also use your fists.
Culling the patrols - what's that about?
Getting inside - who do we have?
Break-in artists - tell me about them. Assuming lack of vertigo to be the first requirement.

Mh. Precisely why my favorite's Eveline Gallo, a circus artist known better as "The Ermine." Just now performing with her troupe somewhere near Oxenfurt. Her specialities - rhythmic gymnastics and tightrope walking.
Uh, breaking and entering?
Not officially, no, but… I've compared the route her troupe's taken with a list of the most audacious thefts in recent years. A perfect match. Highly doubt that's a coincidence.
But if she's reluctant, we've another option in Hugo Hoff, alias "Beef Patty." A halfling.
Think he's fit? Pudgy face - doesn't really match my image of a criminal.

You'd be surprised. Hugo's notched up more break-ins than you've felled monsters. More importantly, two years past he nicked the gold-plated cock from the roof of the town hall in Novigrad. So, the half-man's a climber.
Word has it he's holed up in Oxenfurt in a house near the Novigrad Gate. Be careful. He's modest in size but apparently wicked dangerous.
Agh, don't really have any other options. So be it. I'm in… but on one condition - no one dies. That clear?
As the Great Sun of Nilfgaard. How about we knock back a round - toast a mutually beneficial relationship?
Rather get to work. What comes first?
First you've to assemble the crew, then… there's the Redanian patrols to cull a bit. Too many wanderin' round, we could get noticed.
So be it.
Hm. Gotta give it some thought.
I get that. Think it over. You know where to find me.
Lemme think about it.
For this to work, we need two more accomplices. One to scale the tower, drop us a line. The other to open the vault - a safecracker or a demolition specialist.
I've already identified some promising candidates. All we've to do is select and recruit the best among them. Also your job. I'd, uh, prefer to remain largely out of sight.
Mhm. Assumed as much given your hood. Anything else?
Aye… But that's among the details. Which you will learn just as soon as you declare.
Not all bad, except… sounds like a lot of work for two.
I'm fully aware of that.
Sounds solid.
I'm not a thief.
It's opportunity makes the thief, witcher. I speak from experience.
Ugh. Talk.
Twenty Redanian soldiers guard the auction house. Day and night. Patrols walk in circles around it, and here, past this corner - barracks.
Brute force is out. Gotta get in quietly.
Exactly. Not the simplest thing, though. Main entrance - armored door. Windows - dimeritium bars.
But, not a fortress out there without a weakness. This one's no different.
Patience happens to be my weakness. So dispense with the dramatic pauses and talk.

Ahem. Beside the house stands a tower, from which we can enter the attic. We can't hope to enter the tower from the street on account o' the patrols. But there's a window sixty feet off the ground. No shutters, no bars.
We've got to get up there and sneak across to the auction house. Then down the stairs to the cellar. Crack open or blow off the vault door - and voilà.
I'm no thief.
Before we go any further - you even know what Max Borsodi's House is?
I know it's in the vault.
Didn't answer my question.
Neither have you. Willin' to help with the heist or not?
Maximilian Borsodi's House - know what it is?
The vault - what's in there for you?
Something that was stolen from me.
Hm. Oughta go to the City Watch, tell them a crime's been committed. Not organize a heist.
I've tried. Repeatedly.
I see. Cheated by the system, wronged by the world. Doesn't matter. What'd they take?
List'd take a good while… so I'd rather change the subject. You in, or not?
What do you want to take from the vault?
Don't even know your name.
Come on. I don't even know your name.
What's that matter?
Matters 'cause you're clearly hiding something. Not just from me, either. Wouldn't be sitting in a cellar in this shithole otherwise.
We've all some stain on our conscience. But I've not asked for your hand in marriage. Just for your help in a heist.
We break in, each take what we need, then go our own ways.
Try to trick me anyway, anyhow, you won't go anywhere, you know that. 'Cause I'll take your head off right where it meets your neck.
I'm aware of the risks. So, now that you've threatened me and all… are you in or are you not?
You've come. Good.
Remains to be seen. Aimed to tell me something, I think, so talk.
How do I put this… We share a goal. We both need to get into the Borsodis' vault. Both want something that's in there. Why not pool our strengths?
Sorry, but what exactly is yours?
I've a plan.
Spent the last year working on it - on paper. Time to set it in motion. You one I can count on?
Maarten
Hilbert
Ancient Leshen
Ulrich
Geralt.
Blast it all!
Hey!
Hahahahaaa!
Hah! Pathetic tricks!
Beautiful! Do it again!
Till the bitter end!
You do not strike, sir! You flail!
Harder! Strike harder! Hold nothing back!
En garde, Geralt!
Time to die, witcher!
Come on, onward!
Ha!
Ptooey. Time to fight, Geralt. May the better man win.
Let the music play on!
You fight well, Geralt.
I've long not faced a foe so fierce.
Bravo, Geralt! You force me to strive!
You're fierce as a devil!
Excellent!
Nicely done!
Afraid?
Damn it! Closer, witcher!
Finish it, sir!
Fight, damn you! Ptooey!
Farmer's Wife
All together - at him! Teamwork, for fuck's sake!
For the king! For Redania!
Cheeky bastard!
He's conjurin'! Run for cover!
Just as bored as you, mate.
All right, move along.
Stop that.
Nooooo-argh!
Don't interrupt.
A moment, a moment, please.
Save me! Gods!

Geralt has escaped a great many predicaments, sometimes of his own doing, sometimes aided by others. One of the strangest helping hands was that extended to him by Master Mirror. The witcher was on an Ofieri ship, held captive and bound for a date with the gallows... when, out of nowhere, in came Master Mirror. He reminded the witcher of their first encounter, when he helped Geralt find Yennefer in White Orchard. Now he was offering help as well -- this time, for a price. In exchange for freeing Geralt from the ship, he demanded Geralt meet him at a certain crossroads. When the witcher agreed, a strange mark appeared on his face. It was as though Master Mirror had put a stamp on him to show they had entered into as pact – a suspicion later confirmed beyond all doubt...

Gaunter O’Dimm explained he and their mutual acquaintance, Olgierd von Everec, had entered into a strange pact. Their deal stipulated O’Dimm would have to grant von Everec three wishes. Yet he could not do so on his own, having to call instead upon the services of a proxy. And who better to provide such assistance than a witcher? Since O’Dimm made agreeing to be this proxy a condition for receiving help off the Ofieri ship, Geralt had little choice but to agree.

Master Mirror appeared once again – suddenly and out of nowhere, as usual – after Olgierd proclaimed his first two wishes. Mirror told Geralt of a way to show Olgierd’s brother the time of his life, even though this life had in fact ended years earlier. He equipped Geralt with von Everec blood and the knowledge of how to summon Vlodimir’s ghost. Just how O’Dimm had managed to collect a vial of von Everec blood was never made clear, but then again, burning question marks hung over everything this strange figure did.

Master Mirror made an appearance at the wedding Geralt attended with Shani and the ghost of Vlodimir, who inhabited Geralt’s body so that he may enjoy one last night of earthly revelry. When midnight struck, Vlodimir was unsurprisingly in no mood to abandon the pleasures of the witcher’s flesh. Yet Master Mirror intervened to put an immediate and cruel end to Vlod’s stay among the living. Geralt later told me the cries of torment Vlod’s ghost made haunted his dreams for months to come.

Geralt came away from his meeting with Professor Shakeslock knowing of a way to outfox Master Mirror. The demonic pact-maker could be lured into a wager: win it, and he would be defeated once and for all.

Geralt decided to deliver Olgierd to Master Mirror's murky hands, thus completing their bargain. Geralt knew it was over at once, for in that moment the mark which had appeared on his face on the Ofieri ship disappeared like charcoal smudges drenched in a rain shower. That was the last Geralt ever saw of Master Mirror. I do not think he was missed.

Geralt soon discovered Professor Shakeslock's words were true. Master Mirror could indeed be defeated at his own game. Geralt made a bet with him, wagering everything on one battle of wits, and won. By solving Master Mirror's riddle, he drove the demon from our dimension – though I fear he may yet return. His kind always returns.
Gaunter O'Dimm - Master Mirror
What sport is this? Blustering about after pigs, are you?
Lads're racin' to be crowned King o' the Swineherds. And win the prize that comes with it for their wench - um, lady, meanin'.
And the rules? One must be a swineherd's son to enter, I suppose?
Naay, any man can try his luck. All you need is to herd the piggies dabbed in yellow into the pen.
The prizes - tell me more.
King of the swineherds, eh? And what's this king get, exactly? A king's ransom, I would hope?
No coin. Honor's the prize. King gets a crown o' laurels he pins to his saddle, rides about with pride that he's King of the Swineherds.
You mentioned some trifles for the lasses - are they worthwhile at least?
For certain! Lovely, every last one, pretty as a painting! Win and see for yourself!
Let's chase some pigs!
Sounds like damned foolish nonsense - but why not give it a try?
We'd be honored!
Get that cripple outta there! Couldn't chase his own wench into a bed, let alone a pig into a pen! Let the witcher give it a run.
A witcher with ass ears chasing swine… hahaha. Better than a goddamned circus.
What's that you say, peasant?
Me? Uhhh, nothing.
Good. Keep it that way.
Look at the fools fallin' over themselves to catch a painted pig!
Smearin' their wedding garb with muck!
Aha! Finally, a manly man's sport!
Stupid swine. They infuriate me anymore, I'll whack them with some sign.
You see that, Shani! One pig penned!
C'mon, piggy. Got a nice and cozy pen for you.
Shame there's no painter here. It's a moment worth immortalizing for posterity.
Watch my movements, Shani. I'm spry as a cat and sly as a fox… I'll show these imbeciles how one chases a porker.
Adela
{Heze kei toa ish.} [Let us end this.]
{lmerte mustak teh!} [Death comes for you!]
{Teh nethen shlahab!} [You reek, paleface!]
Guard
Ah! I did not expect that.
Locked.
You must find another way out.
Manor was depressingly gloomy in the winter.
Chalk.
Olgierd didn't let them in. They froze to death.
Blood Pacts, or On Foreign Presences.
Hm. A tome about parleying with demons.
The Gates of Mystery, "Between Worlds"? The library of an occultist.
Blood? For some kind of magic, I bet.
What about this…?
Hmm. Not even a fizzle.
[Place candles on the vertices of the pentagram.]
Go away! I wish to be alone!
Not this time. Come out at once!
Leave me be. I merely want to work in peace.
Oudoianu feus! Soba camisa iada! Soba camisa aberaasas!
What other spell must I use, dammit?! I've tried them all! I wish to end our pact! I summon thee!
Damn it!
Fire! In here, quickly! The flames, douse the flames!
Come back! We must talk!
How about this…
[Place candles on the circle surrounding the pentagram.]
Maybe this?
Nope. Botched it, I guess.
[Place candles on the vertices and the circle.]
Hmm… need to think this through.
[Back.]
[Place candles inside the pentagram.]
Let's try this…
Nothing.
All right, let's try this again…
Egh… Black magic.
That should do it. Now for the candles.
Beeswax candles…
Dammit - smack in the middle of a raging blizzard! Gotta find shelter, get inside.
Locked. Damn it all. Cellar - maybe I can get in that way.
Pentagram's here to bind summoned beings.
Lines aren't all clear, though. Need chalk to fix them… then I can set out the candles.
Master von Everec's study. Here he immersed himself in the arcane arts.
The ataman - he's the one to talk to.
Hm? What is it?
Heard you witchers are stand-up chaps. That so?
Get a lot of things in our band. Bored isn't one of them.
As the dwarves say, down with all whoresons!
Watch where you put those mitts!
Oh, mate…
Townsman
Funny! Duke Kluivert declared bankruptcy. But that ring on his finger! Shite, is it fat!
Hrmph. All so tall ye'd think the room was full o' horses…
Och… Smell it, Geralt? That's the scent o' coin!
Geralt, ye thought o' buyin' real estate? Could get ye attractive terms on a mortgage.
No such thing as attractive loan terms, Vimme.
What about in Koviri marks?
Come on. You know damn well that makes no cents.

How doth the little wild boar
Improve his shining tusks,
And rut them ‘gainst the forest floor,
And on the trees’ rough husks!

How cheerfully he seems to grin
How neatly spreads his claws,
And welcomes little lasses in,
With gently smiling jaws!
Louis of Charolle, mathematician, author and poet

These woodland beasts are as “wild” – untamed, nasty and aggressive – as their name indicates. To this day, many peasants in outlying Kaedweni villages believe wild boars persist on a diet of young maids, though in truth they most often slate their hunger with roots and acorns. Do not think this vegetarian diet makes them harmless, however. In fact, these animals’ stout build and sharp teeth render them veritable fur-covered combat machines. Mother Nature has additionally equipped them with dual pairs of tusks - upper "pipes" and lower "sabres" - and this weaponry's sum effect is to make the beasts the terrors of the woods, a threat to all who venture or dwell there, human, humanoid and otherwise. Boars also have hard, club-like snouts, which some peasants call their “whistles,” though no boar has ever been heard to make such a noise. Instead, they emit a characteristic grunt, which sounds to some like the snoring of an extremely overweight man. Another peasant belief claims boars have extremely prickly natures, and, if offended, will vent their anger by knocking down fences and gobbling up potatoes. Though they sometimes live alone, boars usually appear in small groups of 3 to 5 specimens.

Boars move with lightning speed and can attack a foe from the rear with a powerful kick of their hind hooves and slice those coming at them from the front with their sharp tusks. A wise strategy is to catch a boar (or boars, if fighting a pack and the possibility arises) in an Yrden trap, or to set alight their fur with the Igni Sign.
Wild Boars
Another memory…
Got anything else for me?
I do. Also took care of Vlodimir.
Need something else?
Need something else?
Is that all, or have you something else?
Gonna work on getting you Borsodi's House next.
Best of luck. Enjoy.
Your dead brother had himself one more day like those of old.
Very easy to say. But have you got any proof?
I do.
Vlodimir's hand… It's unmistakable.
You've done well, witcher.
Fulfilled your wish.
I've almost got 'er pinched, man!
Fuck off! You're breaking my concentration!
Can't a man shit in peace around 'ere?

His smile fair as spring, as towards him he draws you
His tongue sharp and silvery, as he implores you

Your wishes he grants, as he swears to adore you
Gold, silver, jewels - he lays riches before you

Dues need be repaid, and he will come for you
All to reclaim, no smile to console you

He'll snare you in bonds, eyes glowin', afire
To gore and torment you, till the stars expire
Should've stayed in that cage.
You said--
I damn well know what I said! At them, afore they sound the alarm!
Well, that's that. We're buggered.
… yes, but we shall raise the starting pri-- What's this?! Guards! Guards!
Another memory…
Hugo Hoff
Armored Arachas
This some sorta sick farce?
You that mad cunt who hunted kings?
That bloody Nilfgaardian 'imperior' can kiss me down there.
Black puddin' - cures any hangover.
Keep her down, you'll burst a vessel!
You seek somethin', mate?
Sod off!
Father

The Ofieri runewright provided Geralt with very good runes and glyphs, but still was not able to exercise his art to its fullest. To forge the best tools and components, he needed painite, a very rare mineral. Geralt was interested in the best of the best, however, so he set out to visit Novigrad market stalls, in the hope that one of them would have painite crystal on offer.

Geralt's hunt for painite crystal ended in success. The mineral cost him quite the hefty sum, but from then on the Ofieri master had everything he needed to create runewords and glyphwords of the highest quality.
Visit Novigrad merchants and see if any have painite for sale.
Take the painite to the Ofieri runewright.
Enchanting: Mastery Demands Sacrifice

The nature of Geralt's trade means finding corpses is a normal part of a day's work. This time the body was found atop an observation tower near the village of Mohrin. Upon closer inspection, Geralt found the man's throat had been slit – and had some highly interesting papers in his pockets...

Geralt was able to find the spy's stash, which he then eagerly emptied of its contents. Not the noblest of actions, perhaps, but was it not better the coin went to the witcher's pouch and not the grubby paws of the Order's bandits?

The letter revealed the man had been a Nilfgaardian spy. Disguised as a tinker named Krister, he had been following the movements of knights from the disbanded Order.
